description:
I love this place. This is our go to "we are long overdue for a date night" spot. You have to time your arrival right because the wait can be long, however they give you complimentary white wine while you wait. Once you've been sat, they are quick to serve you bread and butter. 

We are super predictable and I always order the Halibut en papillote with shrimp in a rich cream sauce. My fiancé always gets the salmon with shrimp. Cesar salads and clam chowder are standard, but not disappointing. I've tried the Newburg once and it was tasty.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Excellent food, just excellent. I only gave my review 4 stars because the hold time is far too long (we waited for more than an hour). I appreciate the complementary wine  that was provided though. 
The place itself is cozy and romantic, with dim lighting and complementary bread  and butter. The meal portions are quite big, but because the food is so fresh and well cooked you would finish your meal before you know it! 
The chairs by the dining tables (not the booths) are quite small and not very comfortable, some cushion would have been nice.
Other than that, the customer service is great and you'd be dining like a royal .

Enjoy! :)
author: Daniela S.

description: This is my go-to spot when I'm in "must have seafood" mode. Don't be put off by the fact that this place doesn't take reservations. There's a pleasant little area where you can sit while you wait for a table, and staff will offer you a complimentary glass of good wine to make the time pass. (I've never finished my glass before being seated.) The fish is always fresh and prepared perfectly to whatever specifications I give. Side dishes are also usually quite tasty. Great place for dates or for just having a night out with your BFF.
author: Laurie S.

description: Visiting from out of town and highly disappointed in the food, the service and the establishment. First we were sat at a table by the kitchen and the first thing we saw was a roach on the wall. Second we asked multiple times for water refills and never got any the entire time we were here. Third the food was ok which is why I'm giving 2 stars. Nothing to talk about but not terrible either. There has to be much better in the city, go somewhere else.
author: April B.

description:
1. If there's a line, sign yourself up for a table on the paper inside. 

2. Expect a long wait, most likely out in the cold/fog/both, because their inside waiting area is tiny.

3. Free wine while you wait.

4. The wait is LONG; it took 1.5 hours on Friday night.

5. Complimentary house bread and butter, and it's delicious.

6. The Crab Cakes appetizer was great- my favorite dish of the night.

7. Meals include soup or salad.

8. Entree prices are high, even taking #6 into consideration.

TL;DR would not come back. A lot of our food tasted of chlorine, particularly the jumbo shrimp and spicy snapper.
author: Nic Z.

description:
Finally tried this seafood restaurant in the outer Richmond.  Have heard great things about it, especially the free wine while you wait.  Nice touch.  Super friendly service.

I had the petrale with mushrooms and capers, perfectly prepared, nice portion with rice and a delicious caesar salad to start.  My fish was so good, will order that again.  My husband had the swordfish, nicely grilled with veggies, he also enjoyed his caesar salad.  We ordered a bottle of white wine, their bottle prices are very reasonable!!!  The whole evening was really nice, happened to be Halloween, maybe why we didn't have to wait so long, I hear there is usually a line, no reservations.  Worth the jaunt to the outer Richmond, excellent seafood, reasonable prices, and great service.  Old school, nice to have a true SF experience.
author: Carole W.

description:
We had a great time here. They make it a point to be gracious even though everybody working is busy running around. We arrived 20 minutes after they opened and there was already a restaurant full of people dining and 12 names ahead of us on the waiting list. 
Shrimp cocktail: mini shrimp, be aware.
Clam chowder: not creamy, small bits of clam and tender celery, warmed us up after waiting an hour outside.
Calamari steak: the highlight. I don't think I've had more tender calamari. My husband said the flavor reminded him of pancakes lol I don't know about that but it was delicious. Broccoli side comes as whole crown steamed.
Parmesan halibut: great crust, simple, good.
Blackened snapper: the Cajun flavor overpowered the fish but still good. The rice is like big pilaf, perfect side.
Random: bathroom is clean, bigger than expected, updated it seems.
author: Grace P.

description:
Today, I called in to try and order a to go order for me and my family. Based on the reviews I was pretty excited to try the place! The person that picked up the phone said that they were extremely busy and not able to take orders in a rude tone. He then said he'll put me on hold and check with the cooks, instead he just hung up on me.

Never again will I try to eat from this place. That's just horrible customer service.
author: Christian Y.

description:
We came around 530 like old people and it was just what we needed, honestly. White wine and a nice hostess greets you upon arrival. Baskets of sourdough and pads of soft butter, maroon tablecloths and spacious booths. Only serving wine and fake plants hanging from the ceiling. 

The Caesar salad and clam chowder were run of the mill. For mains we got fried oysters and parmesean halibut - again - fine enough and just what we needed. Nothing crazy amazing about this place, but sometimes you just need a good meal.
author: Christen G.

description:
As Delicious as I remember!  Brought Spouse here awhile back when we were dating and we enjoyed dining here then as we do now!
Complimentary glass of wine...good!
Basket of sourdough bread and plenty of butter to start!
The shrimp dinner salad was delicious!
She ordered Shrimp Scampi,  I ordered initially the pan fried oysters but then saw the pan fried fresh  trout and ordered that.
Both were delicious!
The waitress, brunette with glasses,  was very nice and helpful!
Lovely dining experience and will definitely return!
author: Gary L.

description:
Delightful and very popular little gem of a seafood place.  Okay, they had me as soon as the hostess greeted us with glasses of chablis. It helped that we got there early so we were seated immediately. (No reservations taken, folks.) Then, WOW, the salmon bisque!  I recommend you get the amazing crab cakes although my husband would insist you order the melt-in-your-mouth grilled scallops. *Lose one star for bad french fries.* 
You will love the service and great seafood so get going!
author: Trish B.

description: The shrimp was amazing but the clam chowder sucks! Service is friendly and the complimentary wine is a great idea. Price is reasonable and good location.
author: Sherell G.

description:
A repeat visit to this quaint Richmond establishment.  Apparently this year it celebrates 40 years in business!  Neither the food nor service disappointed!  Frank is the consummate professional waiter.  This business is well orchestrated.  The crab cake was again amazing.  My wife had the prawn scampi- the sauce is amazing the prawns cooked perfectly!  The only thing that would have made the swordfish steak better would have been the thickness- regardless it was delicious and not overlooked.  The vanilla bean ice cream was a great way to top off the meal!
Cheers until we meet again!
author: Todd L.

description:
This was one of the VERY BEST Restaurants I have been to in SF...We were welcomed with a complimentary glasa of wine, what a Fabulous touch....The Shrimp Scampi was the best I have ever have, and I ordered it with extra garlic and it was perfect.  My Mom had the Abalone, and she said it was Amazing. My guy had the Parmesan Halibut and he said it was excellent and one of the best he has ever had.
We were here to Celebrate my Mom's 85th Birthday, and she was Surprised with ice cream and a candle, and I hope all of her wishes come true.
Thank you Pacific Cafe for making our night so very Special, we will be back!!!!!!
author: Les G.

description:
Not sure what you like, but the prawns scampi is great, the sauce is insane.... need it with the rice pilaf to soak up the flavor: oh my.... mmmmmmmmmmmmmm, sooo good. And the sourdough with butter also a nice meal enhancer 

Plus the free wine. Which tastes pretty nice as well. Enjoy yourself and take it easy ! Good times
author: Erik B.

description:
This place is so cute and I can't wait to come go back. I ate here last night with 2 friends. I walked in around 7:30 to put my name down on their waiting list. There was only 1 party in front of us and I was immediately asked if I wanted a glass of complementary wine while I walked for the table - so cool! The glass was a good pour as well, almost to the top. We were seated maybe 10 minutes later.

I was advised by my friends that the Halibut Parmesan was one of their signature dishes so that's what I got. It was delicious. It came with a choice of a side: broccoli, rice, or fries. Also comes with a soup (they had clam chowder or salmon bisque) or salad. I got the clam chowder and it was really nice with the free fresh sourdough bread and large amount (!) of butter at the table. The clam chowder was more on the light side (not that white creamy Boudin-style) but it was still very tasty and felt homemade. I liked it!

The wait staff was very attentive and I had a lovely evening with my friends. We sat in one of their cozy booths. Reasonable prices for what you get. Great neighborhood restaurant and I can't wait to go back and try some of their other dishes.
author: Cicely T.

description:
We arrived at 450p on a Saturday as a party of 5.  The wait was out of the front door!  Once the tables were open around 515p, we were able to be seated immediately.  The wait time was bearable with a complimentary glass of white wine.  Many didn't care for the complimentary wine, or even the wines they offered...I didn't come for the wine honestly.  I was interested in their seafood offerings.

We ordered the spicy grilled snapper, baked snapper with creamy sauce, prawn scampi, and clam chowders.  Everything was exquisite!  The creamy snapper comes wrapped in a non-edible pouch and there was no doubt that everything was fresh!  Prawn scampi was very rich, but not overwhelming; the grilled snapper was also quite divine.  We wanted to do dessert, but the fresh bread and stellar chunks of salted butter did us all in.  Service was outstanding as well.

Once we were ready to leave, there was still a wait time of over an hour.  That should give you an idea as to the type of following this place has.  Come early and be ready to wait if you don't make it during the week.

Thank you!
author: Ghaffar G.

description:
Super long wait and surveying the senior citizen crowd wasn't sure if the food would be tasty. Given that the wait was torturous and they distribute wine-I wasn't sure I could trust the reviews.

After the wait- once seated, the food came out quicker than the anticipation. As a previous reviewer mentioned the style here is more old school with the classics/basics.

Having said that, the fish were fresh and quite tasty.

Come if you want to spend time catching up with a friend so that you don't notice the wait. Don't come if you are super hungry.
author: Summer S.

description: Very pleased with the food quality and server Maureen who's been here for 25 years! Yummy dinner, free wine was house, but awesome, and extra wine was great quality at super prices. We didn't have to wait on a Wednesday night. Just a really cool locals experience!
author: Stacy P.

description: The best fish place in San Francisco! And nice thing - you will be taken free drinks when you wait)) I like it) and escalops with veggies - the best I have ever tried!
author: Irishka M.

description:
My husband's family loves this place and have been coming since it opened in 1974. As far as I can tell, nothing has changed in those 40+ years - the menu is still basic, perfectly prepared fresh seafood with a basic side (boiled potatoes, fried potatoes or rice) and the same option of appetizer - potato based clam chowder that is really quite splendid, or a side-salad. (Go for the chowder!!!) The bread is fresh daily and brings me to my childhood - it's traditional sour dough San Francisco style (like Boudin always made) with a dense, moist center and a super chewy crust. Our recent visit, two at our table had the fresh crab - cooked and then served cut into pieces, shell in tact, in a dish full of butter and garlic. One person had fried oysters and raved about them! I had grilled prawns - cooked to just done, staying tender and moist and juicy. 

We arrived at 4:30 (they open the doors at 5:00) and were not the first in line but we did make first seating. The wait as we left was up to 1 1/2 hours - but they do provide free wine while you wait which is why, I'm pretty sure, folks are willing to wait this long!

Interesting crowd - mostly older folks who all seem to have some propitiatory feeling about the place and always talk to the "newbies" with an air of knowing. (My in-laws were always excited to share the history and let others know how it is done!) There are impromptu conversations in line as you're hanging around a looooooooong time if you miss first seating! Overall, it's a fun evening out but know what you're getting - very well cooked, but VERY basic food.
author: Amy H.

description: Pacific Cafe was perhaps the best restaurant I've been to in SF. PC has exceptional food and very solid service. The atmosphere is classic, timeless, and true. There's no BS frills and uppity waitstaff. PC is no nonsense great food with class. I can't think of a better place to spend 2 hours!
author: Patrick W.

description: Love this place. The soups are really good and so is the calamari steak. The wine is good while u are waiting for a table
author: Ryan W.

description: A charming place that is so loved by the neighborhood. Get there early and put your name down - then grab a glass of complimentary vino while you wait. It took a bit longer than we anticipated to get our table the first time I went with my friend, but we caught up on our lives while we waited and sipped our wine. I had the fish on the chalkboard special, and we had a good time! They have such a full menu of seafood and variety of dishes like tacos that it was hard to choose, but we were happy with our entrees. I can't wait to come back again!
author: Maile N.

description:
Best seafood and local restaurant I've ever been to. 

Yummy fresh crab cocktail and yummy shrimp Louie salad (it's the sauce)!

Sweet people. I didn't know the abalone dish I ordered contained so much butter. Sadly, I can't eat high fat dishes as I will get heartburns. I didn't say anything, but they noticed I wasn't really touching my dish. They asked if everything was okay and I said it's fine. I didn't want to lie, and I felt bad for them to take it back. 

They were really, really sweet and awesome. They insisted and even recommended a grill trout that's light and good for my tummy.

The grilled trout was so good and fresh and was crispy and juicy. 

Completely recommend!

PS - we got free wine with tops since we waited for some time. Awesome service.
author: Linda C.

description:
This place is a classic SF neighborhood institution. Friendly people, simple classic seafood menu and free wine while you wait? yes please! 

Bonus side note: 
I used to live down the street from this place and one night when the whole street lost power and I walked by the restaurant to ask them if they had any news or updates, they offered me a place to sit with wine and bread in their waiting area--that's true hospitality.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Came here for the first time on Sunday night for 7pm dinner. It was packed. And we waited for about 30 mins. Wait wasn't so bad since they give you wine. They are very generous with the portion. 

Portions are big enough to share. I shared the night's special of salmon and prawns.  We got it with fries and salmon bisque soup. Everything was delicious, esp the soup and salmon. The minute you are  seated, there's bread for you. Wish the bread was warm though. 

The cheesecake was divine!!! It literally melts in your mouth. Highly recommend getting dessert; good thing I saved room for it.
author: Caitlin P.

description:
This restaurant is located on the west side of SF on Geary. There is street parking only and can be difficult to find as this is a residential neighborhood too. 

When I walked in the restaurant for dinner, I was immediately welcomed and seated. It was about 6:30 pm on a weekday evening. Immediately, I was brought a glass of white wine that is complimentary (first glass only) which is a very nice touch. I ordered the Fillet of Petrale Sole Newburg for about $24. A basket of sourdough bread arrived along with butter which was very good (4). 

The food arrived about 15-20 minutes later (see pic). The Newburg sauce with crabmeat was very good over the Sole. I thought the food was creamy and tasty and enjoyed it and rated the entree as a 3.5. My table service was a 3. The interior of this place is of a nautical nature and gives the vibe of a cozy and comfortable neighborhood restaurant. 

Most of the menu items were in the $20's and low $30's. Considering the free glass of wine this restaurant is a pleasant place to visit and I would be happy to return. I give my overall experience here a 3.5 but will round up for Yelp purposes to a 4.
author: Mike M.

description:
It's true. They really do serve you wine while you wait - for free. Good stuff. We should probably all stop writing about this so the line doesn't get too long. And they come around and refill it from a giant glass bottle. Also amazing. My suspicion is they have a whole barrel/keg of it in the back and they just refill the bottle for refilling the glasses of those waiting. Yes for suspected wine on tap.

We came at 7:30/8pm on a Friday night and the wait really wasn't that bad. Half an hour max.

It's a cozy place - wood paneling, dark colors, soft light.

We got the shrimp cocktail, the salmon special and the tuna special.  All of it was alright.  The food did not blow me away, but it wasn't bad. The shrimp cocktail was just exactly what you would suspect. The Tuna (that I got) was just not quite as flavorful as I wanted, but at least it wasn't overcooked.  The wasabi butter that came on the side was REALLY strong, so I didn't actually use much of it.  The Salmon that my husband got, I felt was better.  The clam chowder had a really good clam flavor - it was not on the creamy side (which happens to be my preference) but I still thought it was well done.  

Really what struck me about this place is that it was NOT filled with hipsters. How fun. I'm sooooo used to hipsters in San Francisco that it was nice to see a different demographic (albeit, not a very diverse other demographic).  

The staff was nice. It's on the spendy side, but as would be expected for sea food.
author: Sarah C.

description:
This place earns 5 stars in my book for its consistently good food, great service, and fantastic off-the-beaten-path location and old-school neighborhood feel - the restaurant itself looks like it just jumped out of a vintage episode of "McMillan & Wife" or "Streets of San Francisco" (and this is a GOOD thing!).

If you want a fancy gourmet meal from a fancy up-n-coming chef, go someplace else.  But if you want a satisfying meal of simply-prepared seafood (much of it fresh-off-the-boat), all the tangy sourdough bread you can eat, and great sides, then this is your place.  The complimentary wine that's happily served to folks who are waiting in line outside for a table in the cozy space doesn't hurt, either!  (We call it "Sidewalk Wine," and we've had some of the most pleasurable conversations with other patrons who are enjoying their Sidewalk Wine while they wait, as well.)

Some of our favorites include the bisque (always made from some type of seafood such as salmon, shrimp, or oysters - all versions are delicious!), shrimp louie salad (packed full of small bay shrimp), sand dabs caught down the CA coast (they'll bone them for you at the table, using just a spoon), and Dungeness crab in season, served whole in a pyrex pie plate, bathed in cayenne-dusted melted butter (a.k.a., "crab diablo") - scrumptious!  Though everything is honestly delicious - we've never had a bad meal here.

Highly recommended.
author: Paula R.

description: This place is really a taste of old San Francisco. You just don't see places like this anymore. First of all, it's reasonable. $25 for a good sized entree, choice of soup or salad and choice of side dish? Plus unlimited sourdough bread and butter. Seems like a deal to me! Incredibly...you get a free glass of wine while you wait for your table and that includes if you're waiting outside on the sidewalk! The food is great and the portions are big. We had the Salmon newberg and the Sea Bass with a nice mushroom sauce. Yum! We've lived here for almost 30 years and this is the first time we've been here...I guarantee we'll be back!
author: Jim M.

description: My parents came here the year it opened, and from all reports this place has remained the absolute best. No reservations and be happy if there's a line because that means free delicious wine so soak up the fog and booze and get prepared for some delicious seafood and sourdough bread pungent enough to make the young pucker. In winter I recommend the whole garlic crab, which is Platonic happiness incarnate, or as close as one can get, and in all other seasons, go with the Petrale Dore.
author: Spencer J.

description:
It's old school and if you don't understand it and must have new American then don't bother. Honestly it's very San Francisco. It's as old as Herb Caen quotes and the famous twins that ran around downtown. Wooden booths with ocean prints and a melting pot of employees makes this spot a golden gem. 

First of all for an entree, you get a starter of soup or salad- read the menu board. Then you get a protein listed on the menu or again on the daily specials. You choose to have a side of potatoes, rice pilaf, a vegetable or French fries. And, if you're waiting to be seated, the will give you house wine. 

It's mostly seafood, again I love this. The portions are generous, the staff is friendly but not overbearing. No sodas, just water or four different wines to buy by the glass. Again it's not fuss and thrills just down to earth cooked meal. They also have Mitchell's ice cream- four flavors to choose from. Two scoops per portion, don't say I didn't warn you.

Now come during the week when it's less crowded, no reservations are taken, so being a jacket.
author: Carolina S.

description: Crab cakes are super good! The wait on weekends can be long if you get there when they open.
author: Marissa M.

description:
There is a wait here for a reason, and the food is worth the wait. The fact that they give you wine while you wait is always a plus(props to Roy).
The seafood is delicious and their cooking really brings out natural flavors. We are huge fans of the salmon and prawns. Pacific Cafe is our go-to for seafood in the city. The staff is friendly and the atmosphere is lovely. Local gem.
author: A R- T.

description: What a great and small place! Everything was fresh and good portioned along with a low affordable price. Provide wine for you while you wait.
author: Nicholas k.

description:
In business for over 40 years, Pacific Cafe has a cozy neighborhood charm that still draws a steady dinner crowd. To keep patrons happy, while waiting for a table, complimentary wine is served. 
The ambiance, bread and butter are the total extent of any appeal here.
Our meal tonight thoroughly disappointed me and my two companions. 
The clam chowder was thin watery potato soup, I'd call it vichyssoise lacking in flavor.
The salmon bisque was bland dense and nearly as thick as porridge.
Salad, I have never seen such a colorless salad. The lettuce was the palest part of iceberg.
Next we had petrale sole stuffed with crab meat. There is nothing exciting about sole. Which means it's the perfect candidate for jazzing up by stuffing with crab. Sounds delish right? Wrong! This dish would be sent back at a hospital cafeteria. Smothered in a pink tasteless creamy sauce with no distinctive flavor. The starchy crab stuffing did nothing to enhance the bland mess of this pasty glob. 
Dessert anyone?
author: Sandra S.

description:
Dishes were uninspired, poorly seasoned at times (very salty and one-dimensional). But.

The service was great - staff was so friendly! I really love that about these Richmond neighborhood places. And a glass of wine on the house - these are nice folks.

Seems like it's mostly folks in the neighborhood who frequent this place, which is cool, since I'm in the hood, too. All on the older side, or small family groups. Sure, I can see the appeal - it's easy, relaxed, good service. So, thumbs up there.

But, the food. I mean, I get it - it's tough to compete in this city, tons of new, unique, experimental restaurants open every week. It's okay that this menu is more or less straightforward and classic. But, I wish it simply tasted better. Sorry!
author: Nami S.

description:
Everyone talks about the wine.  
Yes, of course I remember the free wine.  
PC doesn't take reservations, so they serve you white or red wine while you wait.  On the house.  And bottomless.

But that's not the highlight for me.

For me, it's the crab cakes.

I didn't have high expectations.  I knew this joint was an institution, & that it's heavily seafood focused.  But it's so busy, & the wait is so long, that my initial impression was "churn & burn."  Not my thing.

Turns out, PC was a surprise on many levels.  It's very neighborhood.  And very San Francisco.  You're not too far from the beach, & it gets nippy, & before you know it the fog sets in...

And then it happened.  I was served maybe the best crab cake that I've ever had.

Neighborhood service, complimentary wine, & outstanding crab cakes.  A great night.

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
Patronizing this place since 1978, I think, and it still has the same homey feel and ambiance.
I remember the branches in Kentfield and at Ghiradhelli Square, but this is the nicest.

I have always gotten prawns of one dish or another, and they have always been fresh and never "iodiney".

Get over here when you can, because places like this is what made the City such a nice place to dine in.
author: George T.

description:
The food is okay, but bringing it up to a solid 3 stars for the "free" add-ons, like the complimentary wine while you wait and with your meal, and that each meal comes with choice of salad or soup (which worked perfectly for me because I wanted to try their soup anyway). Came here with a group of 5 for dinner around 6:30 and didn't wait long for a table. I had the Filet of Sole Newburg which was a creamy dish that went well with the side of rice (you get choice of rice or potatoes...possibly something else but I can't remember right now). Be careful when you eat this, because I did find some bones in there that I almost swallowed! For the soup, I went with the chowder which was fine- nothing special, but good 'cause it was nice and hot.

I doubt I'll be back but it's a cute little spot that kind of brings you back 'cause it's been around so long. It's on the expensive side for just okay food.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Pacific Cafe is an absolute neighborhood classic. Yes, they ply you with cheap wine while you wait - perhaps this is why no one seems to mind. The crowd is convivial and talkative - not at all impatient, even when they are out in the cold.

Sumptuous seafood dishes abound. My favorite entree is the Filet of Sole Newburg - $23.27. It's rich, creamy and an absolute silky delight. It comes with soup or salad - both of which are served up in generous sizes.

The atmosphere is warm and cozy, and the staff makes you feel like a regular from the first visit.
author: Carole B.

description: The food is awesome and service is great.  Good food good people what else can you ask for.  My family and friends have been visiting the Pacific for  years and we have never had a disappointing moment.   Highly recommend to anyone.
author: David M.

description:
Yummy!

I ordered the spicy snapper (It was just alright) and the french fries. The fries were the best french fries I have ever had. Delicious! 

The ambiance was amazing and the complimentary wine was a nice treat. Also, my entree came with an amazing shrimp salad as a starter.
author: Rachel R.

description:
My review is based solely on the food.  The free wine while you wait is a nice touch, not the best wine, but it is free so you can't be too picky about it.  I ordered the filet of sole with the clam chowder, one of my friends had the spicy snapper with the chowder, while another friend ordered the same as I but with the bisque instead.  

The clam chowder is not cream based, interesting flavor but I prefer the traditional chowder.  The sourdough is nice but the butter is not warmed for easy spreading, straight out the refrigerator.  The sole newburg sauce was good but if it wasn't for the sauce I would have been disappointed with the dish.  My friend said her snapper just tasted like fish with seasoning on top, nothing stood out to her about it.  She wanted to order the potatoes with it but our waitress said they weren't seasoned.  

I felt bad for the woman at the table next to us as she was with a group and said she was vegetarian, not pescatarian.  She asked for the vegetarian options and it was broccoli. When it came it was a heaping mound of steamed broccoli and nothing else.  Not recommended for true vegetarians.  

My main gripe I have with this place is it is a limited menu.  If it's a limited menu the food should be outstanding, it should be the best of the best.  I wouldn't go back because I could go to the pier and get something better for equal or less.
author: Shonda B.

description:
A close friend who travels on board cruise ships as the boat doc once recommended this low key, low profile restaurant. He was very specific. "I have traveled around the world many times and I'll dare say their Petrale Sole is one of the best I had anywhere." I have to try PC, as I can't ignore my doc's orders! The restaurant was not fancy schmancy. In fact, it was basically no frills and down-to-earth.... like starting dinner off with a boring loaf of sourdough with plain ol' butter. The quaint exterior of the building gave PC a charming and old-fashioned appearance, shrouded occasionally by the enveloping fog. The interior is congested with many tables and antique booths tightly jammed in every nook and cranny. It did exude a cozy and welcoming aura once you step inside not to mention the cool glass of complimentary white wine in your hands for having to wait for a table.

I was amazed as to how simple the menu was. There were only three basic styles of cooking.... Baked or grilled or pan-fried.  Add in a couple of soups and salads and there you have it, the whole menu of PC in a nutshell.

We wanted to start off by sharing an order of sautéed and pan-fried calamari steak. Since it appeared in the menu only as a dinner entrée ($18.75), my server cleverly suggested ordering the entrée without the sides and she knocked $6.00 off from the entrée price. Sounded like a deal! Calamari is relatively cheap, in abundant supply and ecologically sustainable. PC's calamari was first pounded, egg washed and batter dipped and lightly fried to give the calamari a golden brown crust. In spite of its tough or rubbery reputation, the texture of PC's calamari was so super tender that a fork was all you needed. Coupled with the lip-smacking egg batter, the tender steak earned a well deserved 5 stars. I was told the abalone was prepared much the same way but at $45 a pop, I'd rather stick with calamari and try my luck at diving for abalone off the Mendocino coast!

Petrale sole ($24.95), a Pacific Coast fish, is prized for its delicate, mild and sweet flavors. The fillets were quickly sautéed and pan-fried with a sauce of white wine, shallots, butter and herbs. PC then plated the fillets with sautéed button mushrooms, a sprinkling of capers and a gentle squeeze of lemon. The sauce wasn't overwhelming so I can still taste the natural flavor of the fish. Even though the prep sounded so simple, I can't somehow make it to taste this good at home! The carb of choice was rice pilaf that tasted exquisite like fried rice and good to soak up the excess sauce.  I guess my doc was right about the sole, though I think I had better elsewhere. (4 stars). Besides, the calamari had the edge! 

The Spicy Red Snapper ($20.68) didn't have the "wow" flavor I'd hoped for but my wife said it was still a keeper in the menu.  I personally think that the fish was a tad over grilled and the meat a little drier than I would like. It was labeled as spicy but not in any true sense of the word. The outer crust of the snapper had a robust, tangy char of some kind of mixed Cajun spices and herbs, cayenne pepper perhaps being the most discernable. (3.5 stars). The red snapper's meat was a little firmer and did not have the melt-in-your-mouth quality like the sole.

All in all, a great seafood place.... the price is right; the food is unpretentious and seafood perfectly executed. I just love old established restaurants like this one.  Parking can be a challenge in this neighborhood.  No reservations are taken and the system is kinda funky and disorganized. A lady comes around to take your name without writing it down and then pours you a glass of white wine!
author: Geoff G.

description: Pricey, but worth. Just an all in all good seafood place. Went with family so I got to try a little bit of everyone's. Sourdough bread and butter sitting on the table when we got there and there's also COMPLEMENTARY WINE. Each entre comes with soup or salad and then your choice of sides. The clam chowder was interesting, there was no cream in it but it was still good. I ordered the crab cake appetizer, large patties of crab, add some lemon and tartar sauce and it's perfection. The only other really noteworthy dish was the calamari steak, nothing I've ever seen before, a giant thin steak of pan fried calamari. Extremely tender and the right amount of chewyness. I could tell the restaurant was filled with locals, but if you are nearby you should def stop by!
author: Angie H.

description: I hate to give a bad review to nice people but this was probably one of the worst clam chowders I've had.
author: Taylor R.

description:
NO Res
As there were a  decent amount of tables at Pacific Cafe, we understood why they don't do reservations there. There's a decent amount of tables in this small corner restaurant, but it took awhile 'til the next table was available. The local crowd are those who love to enjoy their dining AND time hanging out.

The Waiting Wine
Just after 5pm, and on an empty stomach, the complimentary wine they gave us made us happy and cheery while waiting for the next table to open. Afterwards though, you'll need to pay for more wine, once seated at the table.

The Seafood
We ordered the Crab Cakes and Fried Oysters as appetizers. For Entrees, we ordered the Petrale Sole Newburg, the Parchment Snapper, and listed as a current special at the time, the Salmon Newburg. ALL pretty good, but not spectacular.

The Cheesecake
If you're a native San Franciscan and have merely read light and fluffy, you probably know that this is Zanze's Cheesecake. Best cheesecake in San Francisco. And if buying Zanze's alone, it's pretty wild that you STILL have to buy Zanze's through the "secret door." I love it. Anyway, you get a good sized slice for dessert. Buy one slice for each of you. If dining with someone who says he or she will pick off of YOUR plate, bite his or her hand off.

Scoring
3 stars for the food. 1 extra star for the friendly service, the bribe-wine, and having Zanze's Cheesecake on the menu.
author: D. A.

description:
We have been living in the neighborhood for over 20 years and it was our 1st time at the restaurant. Food is good. Restaurant is very outdated. Does not feel clean, sticky table cloth and around the table. Waiter could have been a little more friendlier. 

Poor selection of wines and a complimentary wine is a "Complimentary Wine".  I would rather pay for nice glass of wine then drink this. 

Well overall, it's ok nothing special. Better customer service, better wine list, a little makeover and it will be a Diamond.
author: Olga H.

description:
The one nice thing is that they are always busy after they open so they give you a glass of wine while you wait.  The waiting area is small and a few chairs outside.  Parking can be a challenge.

The salmon was good but not for the price they charge.  The fish was too cooked for me because I like it  moist. The service was good.
author: R P.

description:
One of my fave stops in the Bay Area, and definitely top fave seafood restaurants of all time. On my last visit I ordered grilled salmon. I am picky about salmon, it was moist and seasoned just right. As usual, I was more than satisfied! Three others in my party ordered Parmesan crusted halibut which they all enjoyed. 

The staff is excellent. Some of them have been there for decades and their commitment to the establishment is a testament to why it's such a great place. 

Get there early and be prepared to wait a while to be seated. They do serve wine while you wait, however, if that's your thing.
author: Chenoa L.

description: Excellent food. A little bit of a wait but worth it. Staff was very good at their positions and dessert was awesome too. Will definitely be returning many times.
author: Elf L.

description:
Reasonably priced seafood with complimentary wine while you wait. What more can you ask for?

Reservations not accepted. Larger groups should go at opening unless you don't mind the wait/wine!
author: Cassandra T.

description: Absolutely the best crab cakes in the city! Quaint little restaurant that's been in business for over 40 years. Expect a long wait but definitely worth the fresh delicious seafood.  Enjoy a wine while you wait. Spicy snapper and clam chowder were also really good.
author: Christa B.

description:
Five Star Service here at Pacific Cafe !!!

The staff are friendly and accommodating with a gratis glass of white wine while you wait for a table, and can even bring that glass once seated and finish it off for free too.

The food here is excellent, 'tho because it is fresh seafood, the menu I think varies and changes as well as not having the most robust of selection to choose from, but adequate enough to find something most people (who enjoy seafood, whether fish or shell fish) can find appetizing.

I had a SOLE and it was under $20 and was deliciously prepared, coming with some sourdough bread as well as fresh fries (and options for other sides) and a salad (I had a shrimp louis).

The portions are satisfying as well, and prices are reasonably fair.

Parking in the area, the outer Richmond district can be tough at times, but if you have luck, karma and perfect timing on your side, you may be blessed with a front space, but if not, and you're willing to talk, a free non-metered space can be had fairly easily.
author: Rick S.

description: A great find in the Outer Richmond district of San Francisco. Great home style comfort level seafood that does not disappoint.They do a brisk business most nights and they do have a loyal clientele that keeps coming back. You don't come here for the view, although Ocean beach is probably less than a mile away, you come here for the service that is run by a friendly staff and an Italian style seafood menu, of course, that is tried and perfected over all these years this establishment has been here. Lastly they have a very small waiting area and people will wait outside, some seating provided, when it is as usual crowded. The upside to this wait is that you will get served their house red or white wine on the house while you wait. Find that somewhere in San Francisco!
author: Jerry M.

description: Great place for a nice night out. Went here for a birthday and the food was excellent!  Wine selection was right on. Q
author: Gee W.

description:
Love the halibut, shrimp, and sole dinners
...& Chardonnay while waiting for a table. Delicious. Great food, great conversation, great local restaurant!
author: Anne V.

description:
Love the service. And free wine when you wait? Hell yes!!! After having a fourth of a glass, I was buzzing before I even sat down. 

The bf and I ordered spicy snapper. I choose mine with broccoli, and he got his with rice. It comes with a side if clam chowder or oyster bisque. We finished the night off with a slice of fluffy cheesecake. 

I will definitely be back!
author: Vivian L.

description: Just had dinner there and the food was super bland, zero flavor. Giant tree of broccoli as our side. Very dissatisfied as we heard great things. Desserts were great and the atmosphere is vibrant. A bit pricey for the food which is fine if it tastes good. Free wine is the highlight.
author: Nancy C.

description:
This place was recommended to us by a friend.  Boy, let me tell you I am so happy they did.  The crab cocktail was amazing! Everything we ordered was great!!
This place has made it on my faves list :)
author: Sandy Z.

description: I think people only come here for the free wine while you wait.  The food is decent, but a little overpriced for what you get.  Nothing mind blowing, but the atmosphere is cozy and the service is good.
author: Jenna C.

description: Free wine while you wait. Best seafood in SF! Great local spot, even better for date night. Bring your girl here and for sure she will be impressed!!
author: Tom S.

description: Don't get the crab cakes!  They tasted frozen, even though they were on the specials board.  No lump crab in them either.  My boyfriend really enjoyed the abalone, but it was $47.  The clam chowder was not very good.  Stick to the salad.  Service was personable, and it was fun talking to the locals while waiting for a table.  It's a good place for a meal after a visit to the Legion of Honor.
author: K W.

description: Let me start off by saying, this was my favorite restaurant during my stay in San Francisco. It was amazing. The atmosphere was mesmerizing, it baffles me how you can have such a great experience just waiting to be seated. The food on the chalkboard (the specials) are all fresh and very good. The crab cake entree, while expensive was creamy and melted in your mouth. The cream chowder may just have been the best I have ever had! The woman who took our orders was very polite and nice, checking in to make sure we were alright often and happy to answer questions about any item. Over all this was a great restaurant and most definitely worth your time.
author: Owen B.

description: Have looked forward to eating here for a long time! As an sf native w relatives in the Richmond district this place has been on my radar to try... but WOW! Really bummed my food allergy was not taken seriously and I was basically shamed for asking about ingredients. I get super sick, you are are  in the food service industry... this approach of flippant disregard is DANGEROUS and definitely Really unprofessional. Nice ambiance, too bad the food was seriously underwhelming and the service was really ter
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Just arrived in town and looked for something close to our vacation rental house. GREAT CHOICE. Greeted at the door with a glass of wine and the evening only got better. Group had a variety between the prawns, sea bass and a combo of salmon & prawns. Server Joe was busy but friendly and helpful. Highly recommend.
author: Jim M.

description:
Amazing, delicious, excellent!!! We started with crab cakes that were out of this world!! Then clam chowder obviously homemade with a potato base, lots of clams, seasoned perfectly! Then the Dover sole in white wine sauce with mushrooms and capers was so good I couldn't stop!  I almost forgot to mention, we were greeted at the door with a lovely glass of wine (on the house).
I look forward to going back!!
Ask for Ann- great service and she'll lead you to the perfect meal!
author: Tammy V.

description:
A cute, quaint local restaurant that features excellent food at very reasonable prices.
The Parmesan encrusted halibut is the finest meal I have had in San Francisco. Tasty, light Parmesan breading on a tender fresh piece of fish can't be beaten.
My gf got swordfish, now I have a problem when I return! The swordfish was tasty and moist without being slimy on the inside. She also had Shrimp Louis which was excellent!
And if you have to wait for a table, no problem! This restaurant serves free wine while you wait! That's right ....I said free 
Enjoy!
author: Drew F.

description: This is place amazing! We go at least once every other month,  we live two houses down so we pace ourselves.  Everyone associated with the restaurant makes the experience great!
author: Kamron W.

description: Adorable little old school spot set in the residential area of Geary St. Love this place. First time there yesterday... loved the ambience and the super friendliness of the staff. They even have a glass of wine for you as you wait to be seated! The food was amazing... I had the snapper in parchment... and my friend had the rainbow trout. .. both were oustanding! The soups are absolutely delicious... but my favorite was the salmon bisque. We couldn't resist trying the flour less chocolate truffle torte... I think that's what it was called... so delicious! All in all a great dinner! A definite one for the "gotta go again" list.
author: Shannan J.

description: We've been coming here for 20 years.  I like that they give you a glass of wine while you wait.  They have the best crab dish - crab diablo.
author: Nancy M.

description:
I dare say that this place is a San Francisco institution as I have been coming here since the 80s and the food and service has remained consistent for decades.  This place is not trendy, but a great neighborhood establishment with a devoted clientele.  It can be a challenge to find parking and the restaurant does not take reservations; however, they will pour you glasses of complimentary Chablis until you are finally seated at your table.  Hint:  First seating is at 5pm when they open - thus if you miss the first seating, try to get there around 6pm for seating around 6:30pm which gives you time for the complimentary Chablis!

Tables are arranged in sectioned off booths with table cloth on each table.  Bread and water served immediately and the menu (a small white board with hand written items) is brought to your table.  Boston Clam Chowder is good while the Oyster Chowder could stand for more oyster brine.  Entrees of sauteed, grilled, fried, or steamed items have always been consistent with each visit.

On our latest visit, we had Grilled Jumbo Scallops and Steamed Mussels (nice Wine? base with lots of mussels).  So sopping good!  We then closed out by sharing a slice of light Chocolate Mousse Cake.  Service is excellent and unpretentious.

A San Francisco institution like the cable car......
author: Scott L.

description:
We loved this place. It felt like you were stepping into the San Francisco of forty years ago, with worn wooden booths, dishes like Petrale Sole Newburg, and a very hospitable staff. As a young family in San Francisco, you often feel like your being tolerated through bared teeth until someone cooler can take the table. This was not the case here - this is definitely not a "kid's restaurant," but they could not have been nicer to our two-year old. They don't have a kids menu, so they just grabbed some fries and put them on a plate for her, gratis. There was a free scoop of ice cream at the end of the meal as well.

We will definitely be back...who passes up a free glass of wine?
author: Alex L.

description:
Early this evening, I took my son and his wife to dinner. Great seafood selection. Use to go there 30 years ago when it was in Kentfield, Ca.
We shared crab cake( all crab ), clam chowder, Caesar salad, French bread, Petrale sole in parchment, ahi tuna, stake fries, and salmon bisque soup. Clam chowder was full of clams and ahi tuna serving was large. Seasoning was great.
Service was also perfect!
Best seafood that we have had in ages!!!!!
Clifford R. Den Otter, 805-835-9811
author: Clifford D.

description: Come here once every few months with my roommates and/or my boyfriend. Nothing too special. Very basic seafood. Fries. Cheap rice pilaf (tastes like minute rice or boxed). Steamed potatoes. Steamed broccoli. It's nothing to rave about and nothing you couldn't make yourself.  but it is a cool casual place to come since it's only a few blocks away and it's a sit down seafood restaurant, which there isn't an abundance of around here as you get deep into the avenues. Also I don't always want to make fish or crab at home and have the house smell of fish. Anyways,I would have given it 3 stars. Being a professional cook, and coming in with my roomie, who is also another chef, I wasn't too thrilled to see the salad lady make salads and serve soups, while eating at the same time and then with her pinky finger, pick something out of her teeth and just continue to assemble salads without washing her hands. Not thrilled as I said. Docked a star for that. I'm not a germ-a-phob by any means, but I would have rather not seen it done while she was right in front of me. That's all. Try the shrimp scampi. It's tasty. Or the crab Diablo when they have it!
author: mel l.

description: Pretty popular place, but my fish was pretty bland.  I got spicy snapper.   Fries were fine.  Shrimp salad was alright.
author: Michael E.

description:
WoW. Just wow. It has been about three years since I dined here with my mother in law. This place continues to stay the course and AMAZE. A buddy of mine lives in the neighborhood, and I suggested we grab dinner here. Short story: he loved it. The wait was long, about an hour, but that's to be expected. This place doesn't take reservations and has been rolling strong for 41 years! As noted in the previous reviews the staff is friendly and kicks down complimentary wine while you wait! Smart move on their part, it's like a waiting room time machine. Now to the meal, we started with the crab cakes they were huge and delicious. I chose the salmon bisque for my meal starter and it was everything you could want, rich creamy with delicious salmon flavor. My buddy had the clam chowder and kept making yum yum sounds. 

For dinner I had the petrale sole in the mushroom sauce on the recommendation of the waiter. So freaking good. Have you ever had a meal so great you want to run into the street and tell a total stranger about it? Well, it was that good. My buddy had the scallops and continued to make yum yum sounds. We walked out stuffed after all the aforementioned courses and about a loaf each of sourdough bread. Needless to say it was a short night out after, as we were both wine laden and heavily food drunk. I can't wait to go back again soon!
author: Johnathan D.

description:
A nearly perfect dining experience for seafood lovers -- it's no accident the place has ben around for 40 years! The crab cakes: excellent. The clam chowder and oyster bisque? Meh, at least on our most recent visit. But the entrées, including lightly breaded, perfectly cooked abalone medallions and two different seafood Newburg preparations, quickly drove any lingering soup-related disappointment from our minds. Even the sourdough bread and butter were great.

The best seafood is always fresh, cooked perfectly, and prepared in ways that showcase the main ingredients. If you want some of the best seafood available in one of the best seafood-loving cities in the world, go to Pacific Café -- and enjoy the complimentary, surprisingly tasty free wine if there's a wait!
author: Michael D.

description:
I went to the Cafe in a group of 4. It took us about 45 minutes to get seated, but we were given wine while waiting. Get there earlier than when you want to eat. This place gets crowded quick, and for good reason!

Once seated, the host was very friendly and funny. He kept filling our wine glasses and keeping us updated on the wait time while continuously joking with us. The food is pretty much all seafood. The wine isn't bad, but be careful! They keep filling your glasses and you'll get drunk real quick.

Verdict:
The atmosphere is cozy, but it can get noisy if the place is full. I'd recommend it to anybody who likes seafood and wine. Make sure you have some money to spend, because you'll rack up a pretty sizable bill.
author: Christian K.

description:
If it ain't broke, don't fix it.

Pacific Cafe hasn't changed much over the years. Why should it, the line is still out the door, the free house wine is still appreciated, and the service is still friendly and speedy. I love this place. The fish is fresh, and the bread is amazing!!! If you don't come right when they open (actually, just before they open), be prepared to wait for a long time. The cooking staff care about cooking, not about churning out plates to move people. But if you have some time to kill, want a nice, intimate dinner, and don't mind a small space, this is a nice place to take someone special. The prices are a bit high, but in the end, the quality makes it worth it.
author: cg w.

description:
Best seafood in san francisco!
No swiggles, just seafood done right. 
I tried almost everything on their menu and was always beyond satisfied.
Staff is very friendly and know what their doing.
author: Zeek I.

description: We came here because a local recommended this place. We arrived a few minutes before opening and there were customers already waiting. The hostess greated us with a house white wine. Our waitress was friendly and I loved her accent. We both got the special which was excellent. Highly recommend this place. You won't be disappointed.
author: Laura Q.

description:
Pacific Cafe has a simple, small menu, homey atmosphere and few bells and whistles. What they focus on is FRESH, deliciously prepared food!

Their portions are generous, try the crab cocktail. There was no shortage of meat and they didn't just serve the small crumbly pieces, there were big chunks of claw meat. YUM!!!

Each dinner we've ordered we've loved!

Entrees come with soup or salad. Their clam chowder was full of clam and instead of being a creamy broth they seem to have puréed potato to thicken it up. I know clam chowder is subjective, so I will just note that this particular one is a favorite of mine!

Their Cesar salad is done just right. Nothing fancy, just tasty!

They take great care to make sure their customers know they appreciate their business and apologize if they've had to wait. Their gratitude is shown through complimentary glasses of wine. 

Just a perfect touch to a perfect meal!
author: Lindsay D.

description: Another really great seafood place.The friend fish and fries was great.I went back for the shrimp with seasoning in broth I saw that made me gruel so i had to have it! I couldn't stop considering it after seeing another reviewers Yelp photos they posted! -LOL Free wine-yep! Good service-Yep! Friendly environment and even a little scenic! I recommend if you dig fish and are in this area even though there are piles of fish serving restaurants around here,this is a memorable tourist like atmosphere and fun!
author: Brian D.

description:
I enjoyed eating here, or maybe it was all the wine I consumed.  

I must confess, I was incredibly underwhelmed by the seared Ahi I ordered.  It was almost medium well.. sacrilegious in my eyes, I probably would have sent it back if I wasn't so hungry.   But it was served with my choice of Crab Louie or Cesar salad.  And I LOVE Crab Louie salad, and this was pretty delicious.. so 5 stars for salad, 2 stars for ahi, and 4 stars for free wine! My dream come true.
author: Christina P.

description:
Went in on a weekday evening. No wait. Service was still annoyingly slow. We tried to flag someone down over the course of 15 mins or so, and it took me glaring at the owner for someone to come over.

This was food that I could have prepared at home, but it would have tasted better (and been healthier) had I done so.

I had the Salmon and Baked Shrimp combo. I don't eat dairy, so they prepared the food with olive oil instead of butter. I'd guess that this was where I went wrong, but my girlfriend had the newburg, and that was smothered in cheese and also super greasy.

My food was somehow both oily and bland. I'd shake this off and give it 2 stars normally, but the bill for this not so great meal came out to $90. There's good seafood in SF. Go find it elsewhere!
author: Scott H.

description:
Sustainable seafood.

Loved by all since 1974: www.sfgate.com/food/insidescoop/article/Owners-neighbors-toasting-S-F-gem-Pacific-Cafe-5596954.php

Loved by me since 2015: Free wine as you wait, petrole with tasty interior and amazing crusted parmesan exterior, choice of side and salad all for a more than reasonable $30.

In fact the biggest issue is trying to choose. Fortunately my companions were willing to give samples of the fresh salmon and grilled shrimp. Both would have been delicious alternatives.

Service was prompt, informative and focused. More time is spent making sure you order the right thing rather than small talk. Surprised there was no wait at 8pm on a Friday. Still got wine.

You get four stars.
author: Jason B.

description: A bit too far on the expensive side but the fish here is fantastic. Really one the hidden jewels of San Francisco - this restaurant has great service and fish. I had the grilled salmon here and it passed expectations. I will come again surely.
author: David G.

description:
Don't really get the hype about this place. Yes, free wine is awesome, and yes, the servers are pretty nice. The clam chowder was not normal clam chowder and tasted like chicken soup. I ordered the scallops which, for over $30, I thought were going to taste like god. Yeah, nah. They were skewered and thrown on a grill, resulting in rubbery, burnt tasting scallops. Cassava does scallops way better and way less expensive.

My boyfriend ordered the parmesan halibut, which tasted like chicken was encrusted with what tasted like Kraft parmesan. He got "steamed potatoes" as his side which was literally two red boiled potatoes plunked on his plate. Like, not even cut up or anything. It was actually funny. 

Salmon bisque was the one highlight of the meal.

In retrospect, my boyfriend and I are still disturbed by how expensive this meal was in comparison to the food.
author: Jenna H.

description:
I came here for my birthday and Easter celebration (yes my birthday was same day as Easter). My mom and I thought since it was my birthday and Easter we would splurge a little bit more because it was a special day 2x. We got there when they opened, they gave us white wine before they seated us and when we were seated we ordered champagne also. 

The food dishes started at $18, the average cost per dish is $25. This place is overhyped, the dishes we had were ok, overall the place is ok I would go again but not wait an hour!
author: Alix J.

description: It's one of those SF restaurants you can count on for a consistent meal free wine while you wait although not good wine but it's free!!!
author: Amy H.

description: Another great experience at the Pacific Cafe! Such friendly service and delicious, quality food. No rushing! Reasonable cost and wine while you wait!
author: Disco B.

description: Good food, and excellent service. The wine while you wait is genius. We waited 45 minutes, but with them coming around to top off our glasses time flew and we actually enjoyed the wait.
author: Eric G.

description:
I love this place more and more, now and forever. 

The food is amazing every single time. The selection is fresh off the boat, literally that morning. 

Tonight, I ordered the Filet of Sole Nurmburg, the oyster bisque, and shared one of the Zanke's light, fluffy (yes!) cheesecakes. All three are beyond excellent. 

Finally, I nominate this place to be an excellent first date choice. The ambiance is dim, yet warm. The service is top notch, and everything possible you could order is guaranteed to be wonderful.
author: Cade P.

description:
The big draw here is, apparently, the free vino provided to waiting guests. I'm willing to bet people are thrilled when they arrive to find a lengthy wait, because it means plenty of wine to kill the time. I'm not much of a wino (my extensive knowledge consists of knowing that one is red and one is white), but their red wine was fine by me, maybe a little too sweet, though. We had time for two glasses before our table came up. 

They have a menu (duh), but the thing to do here seems to be ordering off the chalkboard full of daily specials. I could have eaten everything on there, but for some reason the king salmon with crab newburg spoke to me. It said "order me, and eat my deliciousness". Done. 

We ordered a bottle of wine for the table. Why? I don't know. Is the wine still free once you've been seated? They gave us some bread, which I normally avoid but I was starving at this point. Appetizers seemed like the thing to get, so we ordered up a shrimp cocktail, which was a little underwhelming. The shrimp were so tiny; like microorganisms. 

My entree arrived and I dug in. Gotta say, I don't remember ordering a crab newburg dish before, and I probably won't again. The salmon and crab were stacked inside a casserole dish, which was smothered in newburg sauce (whatever the hell that is) and baked. It's a heavy, rich meal that completely masks the flavor of the seafood. I mostly enjoyed it, but knowing what I know now I can't say I'd order it again.
author: Anthony A.

description: We have been coming here for more than 25 years though no more than a few times a year , and we've never had a poor meat! It's definitely the greatest seafood spot in the Bay Area!
author: Nina R.

description:
Pacific Cafe celebrating 40 yrs this year.  Still really good food.  
The fried Pacific oysters, $20 isn't as good as I recall in the past but didn't disappoint, very fresh. Hubby liked his spicy grilled snapper and Jr. Yelper had the grilled wild salmon.  We all liked the cup of Boston clam chowder included with the meal and sourdough bread.  

Lines still form before they open and they have the free glass of white wine while you wait.  The employee brothers, Roy and Renie also celebrate their 35 yrs with the cafe.  

To commemorate their 40 yrs, they have $15 t-shirts you can purchase. Hubby had to buy one.  Here's to Pacific Cafe', wishing them another 40 yrs. and more!
author: Ry T.

description:
A solid 4.8 star dining experience that rounds to a 5! I loves me some Pacific Cafe! This is my family's go-to spot for birthdays or any special occasion when we want to take a quick day trip to the city and enjoy some bomb seafood in a cozy, homey restaurant.

They recently added a new special (salmon & prawns) that I've gotten the last few times I've gone and that I will continue to get. I've always gotten the prawns fried (which their amazing cocktail compliments perfectly!), but my dad recently got his grilled and they came in this buttery garlic sauce of pure goodness that gave me a serious conundrum on how I should order them on my next visit. (Talk about first world problems!) Until, that is, my brother suggested that we each order the prawns differently so we can share them and have both. (I knew he would come in handy one of these days.)

The last couple of times I've been, the salmon has been very tender. There was one time that it was a little dry, but it's usually cooked right. A small knock is that it seems a bit bland to me. It does come with an herb butter, although I'm not really one for putting butter on fish. I prefer spices to give flavor. And I'll admit that my husband cooks just about the tastiest, moistest salmon ever, so the bar is set ridiculously high. 

The only other tiny knock I have would be the clam chowder. Please keep in mind that along with being a salmon snob, I'm also a bit of a chowder snob. (I blame it on all the times I've been to Oregon and gone to Mo's, which is the epitome of what the inventor of clam chowder envisioned it should taste like.) I prefer my chowders to be on the creamier side, and Pacific Cafe's is more broth-like. That's not to say that it isn't flavorful (because it is), it simply comes down to personal preference (aka my chowder snobbery).

Now back to the highlights, which include potato goodness that comes in fry form! In the name of Merlin's beard, get the fries! They're a must-have! We asked the waiter about them (the wait staff is incredibly friendly, btw), and he said that they're parboiled and then fried. They have a light, crisp texture with the perfect crunch. I was shocked to hear that they're fried because they're not greasy at all.

If you've never been, you've gotta add it to your list of must-try seafood restaurants in the city!
author: Megan M.

description: We went here for dinner tonight and had an outstanding meal -- the scallops and broccoli were my fave! Even more memorable was the kind, courteous service by Maureen, our waitress. Somehow she picked up that one of our party needed extra time to order, and she was so gracious. Yay for an awesome meal of fresh seafood and old-fashioned relaxed dining.
author: Joan O.

description: Sure the food is not new and exciting, but that's what I love about this place.  It's traditional seafood - pick your fish or shellfish, soup or salad, side of rice or potatoes - done.  The seafood is fresh and delicious and the price is not outrageous.  They give you a free glass of wine while you wait and the service is always wonderful.  We love the rainbow trout and fried calamari steak, so good!!
author: Kimberly J.

description:
The prices are great, but the food is so mediocre.  I was sorely disappoint. 

It's simply not worth it.  The fish was dry.  The sauce was oily.   

Maybe it's good for college students who don't want to spend much money.
author: Sara S.

description: Was expecting a lot more. We lined for a while for this place (grateful for the free wine!) but it just wasn't up to scratch. The bread & salad were welcome, but the entrees were just "meh" at best. My boyfriend had tuna steak which should be PINK in the middle but it was completely over done & gray colored throughout. I had the red snapper, which was nice enough but also a bit dry & uninspiring. Felt as though someone in the kitchen needed a refresher on how to cook fish perfectly. I can tell from the older clientele that this place used to be the bomb, but alas, not any more. I felt disappointed & I doubt we'll be back. Service was "fine".
author: Fi M.

description:
I've been here a couple of times.  Once when it was busy and once when it was slow.  

When it was slow, I had a nice time since the service was attentive.  We got a free glass of wine when we sat down!  I ordered the steak and my girlfriend ordered the crab cakes.  Both were really good.

When it was busy it was kind of a mad house.  There's not a lot of room to wait with you're waiting for a table so everyone is squished in the front or outside.  I got a glass of wine while I was waiting which is always nice.  This time, the food was lackluster.  Maybe cuz it was busy, but the steak was very plain and didn't have any flavor.  The crab cakes were still good as always so that was the highlight of the evening.

If I averaged out my 2 experiences, I have to give them 3 stars, Pacific Cafe is very close to my house so I will definitely be back when I'm craving those amazing crab cakes!
author: Elena N.

description:
Wow. What a great find. This is one of those places that seems to ooze institution. The free Chablis is a great way to start but we loved the ambiance. The easy neighborhood friendly style. 

The spicy snapper is indeed perfectly cooked. Not super spicy but delicious. And well cooked. The chowder is good and flavorful. Not drowning in cream. The calamari is great even though we ® allergic to butter we just loved it so much and will pay tonight!

The crust of the Parmesan halibut was perfect and it was most and delicious. 

A great neighborhood place. Enjoy!
author: Rich T.

description: I love this restaurant, but no reservations so you have to get there early. The petrale sole and calamari steak are so delicious, I can't bring myself to try anything else. Entrees come with a complimentary glass of wine and their yummy shrimp salad. One of my fave seafood restaurants.
author: Debbie N.

description:
OHHOHOHO!!! Be ready to drink and eat! Love this place!!!! Forgot his name-but he is the older Asian guy-he is the STAR!! When I think about Pacific Cafe-I think him and WINE!!!
Worth the wait since you get the wine on the house and food is always delicious!!! ALWAYS!
author: Natalya V.

description:
Food: a quaint local place that provides simple and hearty fare without any fuss. 

We ordered the English sole and the Newburg Sole, both of which we liked. It's a casual place so presentation is lacking but the fish were fresh, cooked simply, and delicious. 

Service: very friendly waiters who often checked in on us and offered us free glasses of white wine as we waited. 

Ambiance: it's very casual and the style is reminiscent of a Northern European pub.
It looks pretty British in my opinion.
author: C. K.

description:
I don't understand the wait for this place. Yes, you get free red/white wine while you wait, but the food I had was sub-par. 

It took a little while for the menus to come because they didn't have enough specials menus, so our table of 5 had to wait for them. When we finally got the specials menus and barely looked at them we were rushed to order. 

Our table got the filet of sole newberg, english sole, Parmesan halibut, prawns and scallops. Each meal came with either clam chowder or shrimp louie salad, red potatoes, fries, or rice with the main course. 

The clam chowder and shrimp louie salad was excellent. My main course was so bad I barely touched the plate. I ordered the english sole and it was the fish-est tasting fish I have ever ordered. Enligh sole are flat bottom feeding fish in the ocean and that's exactly how it tasted. Fishy and like dirt/sand. Disgusting. 

If fish is prepared well it shouldn't be fishy or dirt tasting at all. The best of the dishes was the prawns! They tasted exactly like they should. 

My advice is to skip the fish and go for the clam chowder, shrimp louie, and prawn main course.
author: Amy C.

description:
The boyfriend has fond memories of this place from when he lived in San Francisco, so we showed up around 6pm on a Wednesday for dinner.  Parking was pain, especially since when we arrived, there was a guy standing in a prime street spot, holding a glass of wine, loudly protesting that his wife was arriving imminently to park in that spot.  Ok, then.  Not the restaurant's fault, but not a promising start.

There was a wait, of course, so we settled down in front with a complimentary glass of wine.  Not the worst idea in the world!  We were seated fairly promptly, but then apparently forgotten about, since it took forever for a waiter to show up.  Despite the fact that most of the menu was on the handwritten specials board, he seemed surprised that we had questions, and overall was not very attentive throughout the meal.

The food was a mixed bag.  Soup (Pacific chowder and something else I've forgotten) was fine, but nothing special.  The seafood mains were excellent -- I had shrimp and scallops and the boyfriend had flounder, and it was all really good.  Sides, however, seemed kind of dated -- red potatoes were boiled and plopped on the plate, no butter, not smashed, nothing.  They should have just let the seafood speak for itself and not bothered with a side.

Overall, I think this place is living in the past.  They're clearly still popular, but the food and service were somewhat lacking.  It might be worth a nostalgia visit, but that's about it.
author: Karen L.

description:
It's so windy in this area. This restaurant doesn't take reservations, so be sure to bring a jacket because you'll be waiting outside for 30 minutes. And yes, they do give free wine while you wait. 

I came here on my birthday with my boyfriend, and the menu looked SO good, but the food disappointed.. :(

Crab cocktail: 4/5
Salmon bisque: 3/5 (too creamy?)
Clam chowder: 3/5 (tasted too much like minestrone to me, on the watery/salty side)
Parmesan crusted halibut: 1/5 (so dry and it's really just fish and chips...) We sent this back because it was just TOO dry and hard to eat. The waitress was nice and got us the Petrale Dole instead.
Petrale Dole: 3/5 
Filet of Sole Newburg: 3/5 (it's more crab than fish I think! The sauce is too heavy for me though..)
Strawberry Sorbet: 5/5 (they gave it to us for free because we sent back the halibut I think lol...)

Basically everything was average to me. Ambience is definitely on the casual side and it gets loud in the restaurant.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Excellent service. The wait is long as this is a very popular venue for delicious seafood. During the wait, free wine was offered and refills as well. Once my entire company was present, we were seated immediately. 
The service was great. The waiter gave me recommendations: petrale doré, halibut parmesan, and rainbow trout. I went with the halibut parmesan along with salmon bisque as an appetizer. The salmon bisque was very delicious. Lastly the halibut was great. Cooked to perfection and had just the right amount of flavor. 
I would definitely recommend this restaurant to any couple looking for a nice seafood dinner.
author: Alexander H.

description:
The family and I come here fairly often. The restaurant isn't very big on the corner of Geary and 34th. It's generally always crowded with a decent wait. But...waiting is one of the best parts! They give you complimentary wine (sometimes multiple if you're like my dad who gulps it down like water).

The food is pretty good and the seafood is always fresh. The filet of sole Newburg stuffed with crab is pretty good, if a bit rich and heavy (to be expected), as is the turbot in parchment. I've tried the grilled spicy snapper which is a good alternative to the heaviness of the other dishes. When they ask you what side to get, you should ask for one of the soups! Both the clam chowder and the crab bisque are really delicious here. Make sure to ask them for their Tobasco so you can add a little to the soups to give it that nice kick!

Service here has always been very good. Definitely come by for dinner after you've spent the day freezing out at Lands End or on the beach!
author: Vivian L.

description:
After the last negative experience with Cajun Pacific, we decided to explore other gems near us. A quick search on Yelp led us to this wonderful place. 

The food is excellent, pure, and delicious.  I had a big hunk of steak with a huge chunk of broccoli. So pure and simple.  The soup was delicious. The cheese cake was heavenly. Definitely five stars for food. 

The waitress (Irish!) was just a delight.  She's warm, welcoming, friendly, and with a great sense of humor (the exact opposite of the woman at Cajun Pacific). 

We will make this place our regular spot soon!!
author: William L.

description: Well was nice to get a free glass of wine on entry. And since we went early we found seats easily.. But food was so-so.  Was ok but i expected my sand dabs sauteed.  They were deep fried with a thick cover of bread crumbs and ?... My partners fried oysters were deep fried but looked and tasted ok....  But next time i go there and i will . I will ask for sauteed instead of their usual deep fried....The Clam chowder was the best i had in a long time (away from the east coast). Otherwise, A little to much grease for my taste ..
author: Peter N.

description: We used to love to come here. They have pretty good seafood. However, I am not sure what happened, they charged us $10 dollars more from what is on the receipt when we checked our credit card bill. They just added more tips to our bill secretly or what? This is not the right way to do if the restaurant wants more tip from their customers.
author: Tini L.

description:
If I had to sum up Pacific Cafe in as few words as possible, it would be: wine while you wait, and old school SF seafood.  The wine while you wait is halfway decent; and they continue to top you off as you wait!  When you consider the waiting experience, especially on a usual windy, foggy, and overcast night in The Outer Richmond, I think the wine is essential.

The seafood is decent.  We shared crab cakes as our appetizer.  They were tasty especially with the cup of tartar sauce.  For my entree, I had the scallops scampi.  Kudos because the scallops were not overcooked, which happens too often; and the garlic chunks were too big, even for a garlic lover like me.

To be fair, Pacific Cafe's seafood might be more than decent, but my perception may have been tainted by the fact that I had recently dined at Tadich Grill, which undoubtedly is an older and better seafood restaurant.
author: Christina L.

description:
This restaurant is about fish and seafood. There aren't many real seafood restaurants in this side of the city. Any other restaurant that says has fish in their menu it probably offers one  or two fish dishes. 
This restaurant doesn't take reservations, so the waiting time could be between 1 hr to 1:30 ( depending on the number of people per table) we were 2 and we waited aprox 1:15  for a table. I know, it's long time to wait, right? One good thing about waiting in this restaurant???? Complementary white and red wine while you wait! So the waiting time becomes more like a free happy hour, so the waiting isn't so devastating ( specially if you are hungry)
I see why this little seafood place is so successful and everybody loves it; free wine while you wait, a big menu with just fresh delicious fishes, seafood + salads, and veggies, but what I see the key here is, the owners are the servers and the workers. It feels much more personalized attention, and because they own the place the service is warm, outstanding and loving. A little seafood gem in the Outer Richmond. I loved it !
author: Coté M.

description:
Came here with the besty, visiting from LA, this place is so good! It's just around the corner and I had always seen so many people here so I wanted to try it out. Good thing we did. The hostess gave us each a glass of white wine while we waited for our table. The waiter who helped us was so nice and friendly. Everyone here was friendly. Although the food was a little pricey, it was fresh and really good quality. I agree with some of the other reviewers, this place is old school San Francisco charm. 
Highly recommend for groups or even a nice date. We noticed a couple of families having dinner with their little ones. 
There also wasn't much of a view but that didn't matter much because the inside was so warm and cozy. The restaurant itself is small and the wait on the weekends varies to several hours, but it is so worth it.
