Be warned, you can't call ahead of time to reserve, only putting yourself on the list physically in the restaurant will do.
author: Rose E.

description:
I enjoy coming out here and sip...chugging the free wine while you wait! The longer the wait the better.  The host or hostess does her rounds every few minutes filling up wine glasses. The food is very good too. It's a very enjoyable experience to
Come here.
author: Tanner B.

description:
Neighborhood place with a been here forever atmosphere   High booths. 
Met at the door with a glass of wine. Comfort food from the sea. I had an excellent petrale dore. Fresh, prepared with mushrooms. And capers   Wish we had one in our neighborhood!
author: Judi S.

description:
Extraordinary! !!! Every single dish has been perfect for us  - for years.  This is the way seafood should be served. The best. 

We would eat here virually EVERY TIME we want seafood if we were less than an hour away. Never better anywhere else.
author: Andie S.

description:
How have I not reviewed this place? It's a real gem.

I went here with my girlfriend and her mom, and we had a really wonderful dinner. We got free wine while waiting for our table... first good sign.

My GF apparently recognized the waiter, since it turns out he's been working at Pacific Cafe since they opened, many decades ago. Super friendly guy (forgot his name).

We had abalone, among other things. Now, abalone is not something you order every day. In fact, this is the first time in my life I'd ever had it in a restaurant - I usually go with family to get them ourselves and then cook them at home. 

Pacific Cafe knew exactly what to do with the abalone. VERY delicate handling (well, after tenderizing the crap out of them, of course) with very light seasoning. Can't get much better. 

The service was great. This is not a cheap place or an easy place to park by, but if you manage to make it here, don't skimp. They really know what they're doing.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Great food. Great service.
I ordered the spicy snapper and crab cakes with both being outstanding.
One thing that surprised me was how crowded it was for early on a Thurs evening.
The weekends must be crazy. Well worth it though.
author: Steve C.

description: Overwhelmed by the variety of food choices in San Francisco, we decided to try a place that seemed to be a local favorite. Wow, what a great choice. From the complimentary wine while waiting, to the great locals and great service, topped off by incredible food, I would highly recommend this restaurant. I had the sea bass dore and it was great. Five star atmosphere and five star food.
author: Tim S.

description: ALWAYS AMAZING. Everything I've ever had is delicious and it's so easy to eat gluten free, I'm ot worried about getting sick. The wine while you're waiting is never a bad thing. Ahi tuna is my fave!
author: Ashley F.

description: We arrived on a Friday around 6 pm and did not have a long wait.  This is a small restaurant and to appease those waiting in line they provide you with a complimentary glass of wine - an uncommon gesture, but most appreciated. We started with sourdough bread and butter which we devoured.  After a long day visiting the city there was no guilt!  The side salads were average and I was a little disappointed in the clam chowder.  It was a bit bland and tasted like canned soup.  Three of us ordered the parmesan crusted halibut.  It was a bit overcooked/dry, but generously portioned. I'm not typically a fan of the seafood and cheese combination, but the parmesan complimented the meaty halibut.  Another one of our guests ordered the salmon and shrimp.  They were both juicy and perfectly cooked.  Dessert of cheesecake and praline ice cream topped the meal off perfectly.  The service was attentive and personable, especially for one in our party that had extreme allergies.  A great place to end our visit to SF!
author: Janet F.

description: The food is spectacular. While it may feel like it's on the pricier side, it was absolutely delicious and very, very filling. You get complimentary wine, bread and butter, soup or salad and a nicely sized entree for the price your paying. It's totally worth it because of the friendly service you get as well. I'm traveling solo and stopping here was such a treat; I didn't feel like I was an outsider to their sweet and community based restaurant. If you want a nice and casual dinner with fresh seafood and good service, this place is a great bet!
author: Neha A.

description:
This is one of those needle in a haystack restaurants that you wouldn't know about it unless someone mentions it. I love supporting long established restaurants such as this one. My gf took me here for a date and it was a great restaurant. 

I read some reviews may say that the service is slow or that the dishes need more seasonings or what not. I say its great because its slow because the restaurant is small and many people are waiting, is that slow or is that because the restaurant is great. I believe its the latter. Besides you get free wine while you wait for your table, so that's another bonus. More seasonings, ladies and gentlemen its a seafood restaurant. The seasons were just right with a side of lemon left on your table. You can taste the fresh fish which I love. Any more seasoning it might as well be battered. haha

I digress. Let move on to the food:

Appetizer:

Crab cakes - To die for. So good. I've never had crab cakes like these before and I've tasted plenty in the east coast where you see them in every restaurant. 

With each meal you get soup or salad: We opted for the soup.

Crab bisque - To be honest I've never had a bisque so I had nothing to compare it with. Its definitely filling because of the heavy cream but its a bit too heavy for my liking. A cup is definitely a way to go if you want to try it with someone.

Clam chowder - I'm glad they call it Pacific Clam Chowder instead of Manhattan or Boston. It was so fresh and light. I loved it. Not so heavy on the cream and you can taste each clam in every bite.

Entrees: Each entree comes with a side, rice pilaf, red potatoes, and broccoli.

Scallops with Broccoli - The scallops were perfectly cooked. Crisp outside but tender inside.  I'm glad I was able to share that with my gf. The broccoli was good but I love broccoli so I had nothing to complain.

Spicy Snapper with Rice Pilaf - The rice pilaf was ok but I think next time I'll get the red potatoes. It might bring out the snapper more. But the grilled snapper was so good. The spiciness was not that spicy to me. I'd prefer have it hotter but I understand it may lessen the integrity of the fish itself.

Overall this place is cute for a nice dinner with your SO. While we were sitting there, I was telling my gf I wonder how this place was in its HeyDay. This restaurant has character and a long history. 

So my recommendation is to try it first before you make a judgement call based on people's comments. But if you like seafood without all the complications of being "fusion" then come to this place.
author: Angie P.

description: We have been here several times and enjoyed all the items on the menu.  The sea food is fresh and prepared well.  We had a party of six and even though it was a small dining room they were more than accommodating for us.  I've never seen it without a line, but go when there is a line and you will get your free wine.  They throw in a salad with dinner, something few restaurants do nowadays.
author: Shauna f.

description:
Pacific Cafe is quite a catch.

Who would've guessed that in the foggy Outer Richmond, you'd find such a cozy and homey seafood restaurant!  I knew from the warm greeting from the guy at the door and the complimentary glasses of white wine that he gave us that I was going to like this place.

Of course you want what's fresh so we checked out the blackboard with the dinner specials.  We went with some of the grilled options:  Ahi Tuna for BF and "Spicy" Snapper for me ($24.48 and $18.68).  A good deal since it comes with soup or salad.

The soups were great especially with the big hunk of sourdough bread that was already on the table.  The soup of the day was a Salmon Bisque that definitely did not skimp on the cream.  BF loved it but I preferred the Clam Chowder.  Not too creamy and well seasoned with chunks of clam, potatoes, and celery throughout.  One of the best I've ever had.

Our entrees were generously portioned.  They come with a carb of your choice (potato, rice, or fries) but they let me get the veggie of the day instead (broccoli).  BF's Ahi Tuna was supposedly medium-rare but it was a little overcooked.  He dolled it up with some of the delicious wasabi butter and some soy sauce.  My "Spicy" Snapper was indeed spicy with a generous amount of cajun-ish seasonings and nicely cooked.  The tartar sauce was addictive.

We were pretty full but of course I had to see the dessert menu ($5.25 each).  I was happy to see that they had my favorite cheesecake on the menu, Zanze's.  It was delicious as always.  BF had Fat Angel Bakery's Fresh Fruit Crumble which was like a mini blueberry and peach pie.  He liked it but it would have been even better warmed up in an oven instead of a microwave and with a dollop of ice cream.

Our meal was very reasonably priced (around $60 + tip) and service was efficient and friendly.  I can see why Pacific Cafe has been around for 36 years and I hope it will be around for many more.

(Thank you BF!)

AJ1

----------------

Update 5/19/11:

Adding another star!

Momma C. loves seafood and reasonable prices so we headed straight to Pacific Cafe which continues to rock.

Note to Greedy Self:  You do not need an appetizer.  The Steamed Mussels we got were t-t-t-tasty tasty.  However, by the time I ate that, plus the sourdough bread, and the cup of Pacific Clam Chowda that came with the entrée, I barely had room for my entrée.

It was a good one too:  Crabcakes.  These two babies were about the size of hockey pucks and chock full o' crab and herbs.  Delicious!  Momma C. and J liked their respective Spicy Red Snapper and Salmon and Prawns combo.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Amy C.

description:
I have a thing left over from childhood about sanddabs.  We always had fish on Friday (hellooo, Vatican II?  Not in our house!)  I think sanddabs must have been cheap back then because we had them often.  Which was great with me, because I love them.  

Fast forward waay too many years, and there I am at Pacific Cafe, ....and Oh My God, they have FRESH SANDDABS!!!!!  WOW!!!

And let me tell you, it's pretty hard to find sanddabs at a fish market, and this is the only restaurant Ive ever been to that had them... They are often on the menu here! They do them well, too.  

Ok, so  as established, I'm happy if there are sanddabs.  I call, they say yup, we have 'em, then I drag my family and friends along.  Typically, they are thrilled to come with me.  They like the free wine, the shrimp louie, the trout, the bisque, and the pilaf.  I like those things too.  I also like the tacky 70's decor, and the waitstaff.  
I don't like the parking, but it's not horrible. 

Yay  sanddabs!
author: El B.

description:
Free booze while you're waiting for this always crowded neighborhood spot!

We had clam chowder (non-traditional but yummy), crabcakes (!), a buttery shrimp bonanza, and the Cajun snapper, which was really really Cajun - hot hot hot! I like food that says it's hot and is. The snapper was extremely fresh and perfectly cooked. Many other places could take lessons from them on how to do blackened snapper correctly.
author: Rob C.

description:
Opens at 5pm and there is no waiting list. I arrived at five and got a seat on the first wave.
Seafood is fresh and seasoned to a good taste, I thought. Check out the special of the day. There are many items on it. I had grilled scallop lemon butter. Liked it.

This food won't knock your socks of so to speak but its pretty good. Don't think you'll be disappointed.
 Parking is street level and tough to find.

Pricing is moderate and seafood is sustainable catch.
Great wait staff! Very fast food prep to your table. Oh and wonderful bread.. wine is so so.
author: Doug H.

description:
I've always heard how good this place is and how they give out free wine! I finally tried the place and the wait was insane long! No reservations and no you can not put your name down through the phone. We got there around 7pm and started drinking our free wine! They don't mess around, they pour full glasses and they don't stop. After my hour and half wait I was WASTED! and starving. I think I had one bottle of wine to myself. When I sat I literally ordered everything I saw and ate the whole bread basket. I think this is how they make their money haha so wasted and starving I was ordering up a storm. The waiter came over and said something, I didn't even understand him haha. After filling up on bread, mini shrimp cocktail (I thought is was big shrimps, oops, I would pass on this dish in the future.) and crab cake, so good! I was full. I really wanted the parchment paper snapper, they ran out! Doh! I got the petrole stuffed with crab and fries. It was very rich I took 2 bites and packed everything togo. Oh my meal also came with clam chowder, it was good but not thick and creamy like boudin's clam chowder, it's a thinner broth. The bill came out to around $80 after tip and taxes. Not bad if you are a drinker like myself, worth the price because we are saving on alcohol money.

So food was ok, nothing exciting but good.
Staff was amazing and friendly
Free Wine and a place to get wasted earns them a 4 star.
Only come if you are willing to wait an hour and half
author: Karen T.

description:
Every time we drove passed this place there were people waiting outside to get seated.  We finally tried it and the food we ordered was OK.  We had higher expectations and were disappointed with the taste of our food.  It was rather bland with no taste.  I had one of their fish plates and I can't recall what my wife had.  At least we can check this place off the for places to try.  We don't plan on going back to try other dishes.

One plus is that we received a free glass of wine...but still, the food wasn't great.
author: Mike T.

description:
There's nothing pretentious about this place whatsoever. While you wait for a table, they give you free house Chablis. It's tasty, and they'll keep pouring until you sit.

The Food is straightforward. It's simple. It feels genuine. Everything is well prepared. 

I like the Ahi filet, with Wasabi Butter. Their pacific clam chowder is tasty. There's no butter or cream in it, so it's light. Everything is always ultra fresh.

Highly recommend if you're looking for a spot to dine in the Richmond.
author: Brandon B.

description: How could you not love a place which provides complimentary wine will you wait to be seated?  Well, there are many reasons beyond that to love Pacific Cafe, most notably the delicious fish entrees!  With a menu full of fish & shellfish options, Pacific Cafe provides stellar food in a low-key, old-school SF/ neighborhoodish setting, making it a great experience.  There is a reason the place was packed at 510pm, just 10 minutes after opening.  The Sole and Sand dabs dishes which hit the table were big winners! The salads were great, as were the crab cakes.  We didn't stay for dessert, but I'm looking forward to that next time.  I'm also looking forward to becoming a regular when I move to the neighborhood in a couple of months.  I'll be back for sure!
author: Andy S.

description:
o5.26.13

This little place is absolutely fancy and classy~ while waiting, they serve you unlimited white wines. How nice is that? Not only that, but we get to enjoy that glass of wine outside the street! WooohOoot for SF! :P Anyway, each one of us liked our dish except for the crab cake, that really tasted like In-N-Out's animal style fries to me. So my friend didn't really liked his dish. But my scallops was really fresh and sweet. It was a really delicious meal. :)
author: Emily L.

description:
We loved this place. A homey feel, tons of great food and free wine. Wonderful.

Also, for those of us with food allergies-they make clam chowder that is dairy free and tastes rich and creamy. I was in heaven.
author: Carol L.

description: Had the spicy grilled salmon!! It was yummy! Get there early because it gets crowded!
author: Diamond M.

description: Pacific Cafe is such a San Francisco Gem! We did have a bit of a wait for a party of 2 but the hostess was so accommodating with our complimentary wine that the time flew by. The food was absolutely fantastic, reasonably priced and the environment was intimate and pleasant. I would HIGHLY recommend this restaurant and will become a patron myself! Love this great find of a seafood restaurant!!
author: Lauren B.

description:
Pacific Cafe is certainly very old skool, but if you're a fan of "how we used to cook seafood" you'll enjoy it (that is to say they make things like sole doré and newburg), and you can also get more modern interpretations with less rich sauce 'n such. 

My sole doré was DELICIOUS, and after the shrimp louie salad, included in the meal price, I could only eat half of it. The other 3 in our party were members of the clean plate club so tho I didn't bother to ask anyone else how they liked their fish, I think they did!

I appreciate that their desserts - Mitchell's ice cream and Zanze's Cheesecake, are provided by local oldey timey traditional SF purveyors. As it should be. 

I know lines here can get long, and I hate waiting in line. So going on a winter Tuesday at 6pm: no line. Still a free glass of white wine tho! Yeah!!
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Love this place! Its cute inside and I love all the old school photos/signs adorning the walls -definitely gives the place character. Wait staff was incredibly friendly and we were seated quickly even though we didn't have a reservation. I think we came late on a Friday night? The seafood was solid and I would definitely go back.
author: Amanda L.

description:
The menu is not extensive, but the food is absolutely delicious, the wine is very good and the service is perfect.

The atmosphere of the place is nice and quiet and also it's a very good place for a romantic dinner.
author: Victor D.

description:
Came here on a foggy Saturday evening with the gf. Got there at about 5:05 and there  was a mass of people outside holding their complimentary glasses of white wine. Thankfully it was packed because the restaurant didn't open yet. Once they let people in, we got second on the waiting list, which still resulted in a 45 minute way. At least the wait was accompanied by the wine. 

Service was good. They kept the wines filled constantly and the staff was attentive and friendly. Ambiance was dark but felt cozy with all their decor. 

We got seated and ordered the crab cakes, spicy snapper, and parmesan halibut. The crab cakes were the highlight of  the night. So fresh tasting with shreds of crab meat. The snapper was good and so was the halibut, but it did not compare to those delicious disk shaped treats. 

If you come here, definitely go early to get your name on the board and order those crab cakes.
author: robin w.

description:
Always delicious and always a long wait. On the plus side free wine at the door! Service is always good. Friendly people that are busy, but don't forget about you. If you are into crab cakes get them here. They are almost nearly all crab and really delicious.

My rating is 4 stars!
author: urban r.

description:
SO I'm gonna give this place 4 stars for the food, the ambiance and the service and the 5th star for the free wine you get while waiting for a table. 
This is a small place, opened in 1974 and totally a friendly neighborhood seafood spot.
We showed up at 6 on a Saturday, put in our name - No Reservations accepted- and waited outside, we were brought a legit pour of some Chablis for our wait. This was a great touch. 
The host came around with refills several times. When we got in after 30 minutes or so we got a great booth table, this place is small so it gets cozy. We had a great server - Larry who has been there forever. Fresh bread and amazing butter on the table we ordered their house red which was pretty good- great for the price.
I had their clam chowder which was less creamy than I expected but very good. My wife had their shrimp louie salad which I tried a bit of and was thoroughly impressed. I went out on a limb and had their New York steak which was incredible- I know...it's a Seafood joint so what am I doing ordering steak? This is something I often do and it was worth it. 
All in all this place is greta, very cozy, super friendly and had a great vibe. It's always a bit of a wait, but worth it for the food and totally worth it for the wine.
author: Jack W.

description: This place is the perfect neighborhood fish restaurant. Great food, friendly scene, great tradition. My favorites are the halibut parmesan, the crab Louie (sweet, fresh, gorgeous crab, not local), the clam chowder, the petrale and the Mitchell's ice cream for dessert (another SF tradition). Yes, the free barrel wine while you wait is great and builds a friendly scene, especially on a foggy weekend when the wait may be a bit longer than you hoped. But once you're seated, the baskets of great sourdough keep arriving at your table, a very nice salad or soup is included with the meal, and you then enjoy a nice plate of fresh fish (or scallops, or abalone or whatever pops out at you from the specials board). Frank and Roy and Maureen and the other long time staff are friendly, informed and attentive. One of my favorite SF spots any day of the week.
author: Chris K.

description: It was hard to find parking, although that seems to be the norm in SF. The food was excellent and the place was packed. We had to wait a bit but there is complimentary wine while you wait!
author: Corey P.

description:
We have been going here for over 30 years, it is our "go to" seafood place when in San Francisco as it is a neighborhood gem!  

This is a small and rustic place.  To get seated for a 5 pm dinner expect to arrive at 4:30 pm and wait (you will get a free glass of wine), or arrive after 6 pm.   On the weekends you might want to arrive even earlier then 4:30 to make sure you get seated for 5 pm.  

Nice, cozy booths await you inside, your table will have amazing sourdough and butter all ready for you, and service is fast and attentive.

Meals come with your choice of soup or two different salads (Ceaser or shrimp louie, I always choose the shrimp), and a side dish (various types of potatoes, rice or vegi).

Everything here is just perfect, last night I ordered the Crab Cakes and was in heaven.  Crab cakes were tender, not greasy, slightly cruchy and melt in your mouth perfect.

Husband ordered the Petrale Sole Newburg, his go to dish here.

Parking can be a challenge, if you have guests who cannot walk far drop them off and start looking for a place to park (there is no parking lot for Pacific Cafe).

After dinner you are right near Ocean beach for a nice walk!  Or before you stop in visit the Legion of Honor which is right up the street, or even take in a few of the sights in the presidio, whatever you do before, or after, Pacific Cafe will be the highlight of your visit.
author: Jacquie H.

description:
I had been curious about this place for about 5 years. There is always a crowd outside waiting. Having lived only a few blocks away at one point, I thought this was worth a visit. 

Yes. The bonus is having a glass of wine as you wait. I was handed one as I put my name in. At least everyone was happy and social as we waited for an hour to eat. 

My father ordered the clam chowder (their own recipe) and thought it was good but found the sole newburg uninspiring. I ordered the Ahi Tuna rare with wasabi butter (it was more well done).

The severe was swift and friendly. The prices were inflated for the quality of food. Wish I could have given a different review. I would recommend another seafood place that takes reservations in order to waste less time on average fare.
author: Keren R.

description:
I came to this cozy little restaurant for a romantic rendezvous for two. There was a bit of a line to enter, but the staff was kind enough to provide us with a nice dry white wine - I've never seen such service! Entering the cafe, you feel like you step back into the 1930's, into a beautiful little diner that radiates warmth. We were one of the first customers in so bread, water, silverware, and candles were already set for us - it felt like they were expecting us.

The cafe does one thing and does it well - fish. If you love fish, there a multitude of sea food options on the menu and the specials board. You can smell the wonderful aroma of fish being cooked from the small open-windowed kitchen in the back. We had a big broccoli head ($5) and clam chowder soup ($6) for appetizers. The chowder isn't as creamy as the ones from the chains, but has a nicer flavor. I got a spicy red snapper ($20) with a very nice kick to it which was well cooked. My date had the sauteed Petrole Sole ($24) with a beautiful light sauce. The only strange part was the side of red potatoes that came on the plate whole - we would've preferred them prepared differently.

Our waiter was very nice and perceptive, noticing the birthday gift on the table and providing us with a birthday dessert. Have to give the waiter a thumbs up for the wonderful assist!

The five stars are for the tasty (fish) dishes, the service, and the feel to the restaurant.

Breakdown:
Ambiance - 5/5 stars (beautiful, private cozy tables, but small)
Food - 5/5 (Fish, fish and more fish!)
Price - 5/5
Staff - 5/5 (Wonderful and attentive)
Total - 5/5
author: Jose H.

description:
I have no idea how this place got 4 star ratings!  I searched for steak and seafood and this place came up. Only one steak item was listed on the menu, I felt mislead.  This is my experience on a $120+ meal for 4 people (the other one had soup and salad only)

Pro
Free glass of wine 
Lobster bisque was excellent 
Good salad
Good service
Free water

Cons
Cold bread they warmed it up upon request.
Calamari steak was blend and greasy. 
Ahi tuna no flavor and expensive, had to wash it down w a glass of wine
Whole Crab was not the freshest and expensive $32
Difficult to find parking, took 15 min to find a spot-a block away.
Seating/table were small 
Clam chowder was mediocre
author: Ash M.

description:
For the free wine, I'll bump up to 4*, but the prices make it more like 3.5. And with a minimum of $6 per person, it was a bit much. But the food was great and the bread and wine nice touches.

I enjoyed the salmon bisque and also sampled other plates from the table.  The fish tasted fresh and the fried oysters were tender.  

They are open pretty late, which is a plus, but parking is hard to find and even late they were crowded (although we were able to get a table immediately, something that is rare, I was told).
author: Megan E.

description:
We come here at least 3 times a month when we are in town. Most of the time we order the calamari steak and the fried oysters with their new england clam chowder. On special occasions we order the abalone steak and when they have it the diablo whole crab is the best. There's no reservations but you get free house red/white wine will you wait. This place is a institution in San Francisco's Richmond district.
And when you are there say hi to Roy who's always got that welcoming smile as he hands you a glass of wine!
author: RJ C.

description:
This place has been around for a long time and has some old quaint charm. Not very many tables for a cozy intimate setting which is nice for dates and the older crowd. The free wine is a nice touch as long as you're not picky about your wine because they don't give out the nice stuff. The food is okay. Crab cakes were good (but too much of one thing for an entree) and the clam chowder is good. Fish is usually overlooked and the overall good rating is about a 3 for the price. Definitely overpriced for the quality. 

We have been here a few times since we live nearby. The big downfall is the service. Staff is not very friendly and always hurried. They make you feel like you are inconveniencing them by eating here. We would have to be starving to bother going back. They only got a 2 instead of 1 because the food was okay and the quaintness upon arrival is nice...until any of the servers open their mouths.
author: Kristin K.

description:
This is my favorite seafood restaurant in the city.  Their 'specials' menu always has something great - I try to order something new each time I come in. (The crab cakes are the best I've ever had).  My boyfriend and I venture to the new 'hip and happening' places all over the city and end up coming back here often when we want consistently good fish (with great portions). None of that "where is the fish on my plate?" thing happening here. The servers are all wonderful, the service is amazing, you can really tell that the staff loves working there - which I think is really important. 

I'm surprised that there are any reviews under 5 stars for this restaurant. It really is my favorite in the city. 

I've spoken with a number of people waiting outside who don't know what to order -- and I'll highlight some of my favorite items below: 

Crab Cakes (A must! Get them as appetizers if you're not ordering them as a meal - you won't be disappointed -- get at least 1/2 a crab cake per person when ordering as an appetizer. You can dip them in tarter sauce - but if you want to really enjoy their flavor eat plain or with a squeeze of lemon). 

Sand Dabs (are my favorite! ... but it's "bone-in" so that can be tricky -- especially for a date night! My boyfriend thinks most people won't like them - but if you like a nice little light fish and don't mind working around the bones - you should try it)

The Combo is a crowd pleaser (Salmon + Prawns)

The Crab Louis Salad is very large and a little intimidating - but is a great option - especially if you're on a low/no carb diet

The Seared Ahi (with wasabi butter) is my boyfriend's favorite - it's a generous cut of ahi. 

If you love fish, in the sense, that you really love the taste of fish on it's own -- I would recommend grabbing one of their specials off the board that isn't served with a sauce. The fish is really fresh and I've always had a great experience when I'm eating a large piece of fish here with just lemon on it. 

If you're thinking you'll get a soup - try their Salmon Bisque - it is really quite tasty.

Wine? My boyfriend's favorite is Napa Cellars Chardonnay - crisp and refreshing. 

Dessert? Caramel Praline is my favorite ice cream in the entire world and I ask for it every time I'm here (the dessert/ice-cream menu changes often). So if you love rich, delicious, amazing ice cream - then ask for that. If they don't have that -- the toasted almond is also a fan favorite.

The cheesecake is very light and fluffy. It's great when you want a dessert that isn't too heavy. 

If you're in the Richmond district and you're looking for a great place to eat - this would be my first recommendation. I hope you enjoy the food and the service as much as I do.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
This is an absolute gem of a place here in SF.  I have to say its truly the best seafood this amazing town has to offer.  Seems family owned with a waitstaff who are extreme courteous and diligent, friendly and charming.  Chefs who put out some amazing deliciousness!  Crab cake fan?  Best in SF here, hands down.  Nice quite and quaint location on the corner of Geary Blvd. and 34th Ave.  Street parking only, but its good to note here that there is a parking lot located at 34th and Clement just inside Lincoln Park.  Then just a nice quick little walk.

I have been here several times and have never been disappointed.  So rarely do I order off the regular menu due to the fantastic specials of whats in season up on the chalk board.  Portions are generous.  If indulging in an typical 3 course meal,  you will most def be taking some of that good stuff home with you afterwards.

The only potential downer that can happen here is dealing with what can be a long wait at times.  And believe me, most evenings from just after open (5pm) to past dinner peak times, there will be a wait.  However, you are provided with free wine while you wait!  You cannot beat that!  An absolute must try.
author: Jeffrey K.

description: Good, fresh seafood prepared simply. Don't expect anything trendy - I don't think the menu has changed much since 1974 when it opened. Crab cakes are tasty and there's a creamy seafood dish in parchment paper that's quite delicious. Does anybody else still do that? I'm surprised they don't have green goddess salad dressing as an option! And bonus points for the ambiance - free wine while waiting for a table, excellent lighting and a nice staff.
author: Clinton F.

description:
It's a San Francisco institution. Once you walk in, the aroma of fresh seafood hits your nose. Peruse the specials on the board, dig in the bread basket and enjoy your meal. I was craving a nice piece of grilled fish so grilled salmon it was. Nicely presented with perfect grill marks and moist and flaky. The baked shrimp are like a scampi. Delicious as well. Dip your bread in the sauce! Oyster bisque is creamy and rich!

Definitely a dependable establishment for some good old seafood comfort food.
author: Anna R.

description:
I am very much a foodie, but sometimes I want my seafood the old way and this is one of best places in San Francisco like Tadisch Grill that takes your back a few days..  The days of rich sauces like "newburg" or bisque soups.  Seafood is king here, with only a steak in the red meat choices, but scallops, salmon, and other oceanic delights await you.

The wine is flowing, and the sour dough just keeps on coming with huge cubes of butter.  We had just had some appetizers at the Jazz Crusaders show at Yoshi's and were not really too hunger but I needed a fix of seafood before heading home to Sac.

I ordered the rex sole with mushrooms and capers with red potatoes and wasn't totally satisfied with the meal - the sole and mushrooms were cooked to perfection, but a caper/mushroom sauce was missing to bind the dish together. The two med red potatoes were steamed and presented as two whole potatoes - they seemed awkward on my plate.

My wife's Salmon bisque was perfect,  and the two desserts of Peach Ice cream and a three layered chocolate mouse were yummy.  Our waiter was a dud and lacked any charm in fact he was awful no "table presence" - the support staff were very nice and helpful.

I will go back when I need to have an old fix of "newburg" but not for awhile - to many great restaurants in this big city.....
author: Mike R.

description:
We've been coming here for over 30 years, ever since my wife's aunt and uncle introduced us here.  It is an unpretentious place without the high tech decorations or the thumping music.  You won't find Michael Bauer or any of the nouveau restaurant critics here.  Most of the patrons are baby boomers and older that enjoy the service, food, and general relaxing atmosphere.

There is a regular menu which serves things like calamari steak, dover sole, fried oysters, etc.  Prices are in the high teens.  They also have daily specials written on a chalkboard and for those that have a hard time seeing, they bring a miniature chalkboard to the table.

Free white wine is provided while waiting and some people that is a good selling point.  I enjoy this place even w/o the wine as I never drink any of it. There is a wait during busy times such as weekends, but I find that dining on the weekdays is the best time.  Boudin french bread is served and if you eat it all, the staff gladly brings you more.

I generally start with a shrimp salad with a thousand island type dressing.  You could also have it w/o the shrimp as both are served on chopped romaine lettuce.  I enjoy the taste of the salad dressing as it is tangy w/o being overpowering. I've had just about everything on the menu and I crave the sand dabs when they have it.  You have to de-bone it, but there is an art to it and is part of the dining experience.  Rice pilaf or red potatoes are options that provided

The staff is very attentive and seem genuine.  Our bill is usually about $50+ for two.  When we have out-of-town guests, we bring them here and they enjoy it.  This is our go to place for seafood and a relaxing dining experience.
author: Robert J.

description: solid seafood, stable institution in SF. they give you free wine while waiting, and grilled fish is very fresh. Worth trying, just not a place that one is dying to go back.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
This place has a great feel.  The food is a little bit of a throwback, but refreshing in a city packed with restaurants trying to top each other.  They have a solid selection of seafood with basic veggies, potatoes, soup and bread.  

The real reason people love this place?  The free wine while you wait to be seated and nice waiters.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Looking for a good seafood spot not too far from home. I've lived in the Richmond my entire life and never visited Pacific Cafe, which apparently has some pretty cool history (open since 1974 or 1975). Quaint little spot with intimate dining space. Complimentary wine while you wait for your food!

Started off with the Crab Cocktail ($13.95) - holy crap this was delicious. I had the Halibut Parmesan, and my boyfriend had the Salmon and Shrimp combo. I've never ordered Halibut at a restaurant because my boyfriend's dad has such easy access to fish, but I thought I'd give it a shot. The flavor was amazing, but the fish was a bit tough - almost like chicken. I just had expected it to be softer and more tender, but then again, I can't really judge because I had never ordered it. My boyfriend's plate looked good and the salmon was good. Came with soup or salad (I had lobster bisque soup and he had Caesar salad) and red potatoes. Finished off with Cantaloupe Ice Cream. YUM.

I liked the homely feel of the place. Will come back. A bit pricey so not too often :)
author: Lauren Q.

description: Food is always great and the free wine while you wait, well is free wine!  My server this last time was a bit lazy, usually much better and I didn't think it was that busy.  All the bussers were awesome and more attentive than the waitress.  This time I tipped my busser directly, I wanted to reward her for her service and not rely on any tip pooling!
author: barry w.

description: Excellent seafood at reasonable prices and outstanding service. It's a small place so if they are busy it might take awhile to get a table.
author: Chuck R.

description:
What a great business model this place has. There is almost always a wait when I go, but I couldn't ask for anything more. While you wait, a host/server goes around to everyone inside & outside offering them free white wine. They continue to provide the free delicious wine, filling up your glass once empty, until you are seated. 

I got a good buzz when I had to wait around an hour for a table once, but the next time I came I only waited 15 minutes and found myself wishing I could wait longer (to get inebriated more).

Who knew I would enjoy waiting to eat to much! And once the wait is over, the food is phenominal. The fish is extremely fresh and everything is very simplistic, but boasts perfection.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: Have been coming to Pacific Cafe since the 90's and we keep coming back.  Love the service and the same staff that has been there for a long time, free vino when you get in line, and the fresh fish selections.  Have a hard time not ordering the halibut parmesan whenever it is on the menu, but the salmon and prawns combo is delicious as is the swordfish. The fries are my once in awhile guilty treat, although you can get red potatoes or rice also.   Decent prices for what you get (including salad or soup) in a cozy atmosphere.  Entrees with the salad or soup and potatoes or rice typically range from $25-$30.  Decent selection of wine by the bottle or glass with un-inflated prices.
author: Mark O.

description:
My mother and I went to dinner at this exquisite little cafe one night, on the recommendation of someone we chatted up at Safeway!

The parking was a challenge - but that's to be expected in the city. 

We were warned that there was going to be a wait and the lobby was full, but everyone was handed a free glass of wine and it was good!!! 

We sat, we ordered - the wait staff was friendly but busy. I ordered the Ceasar salad and it was one of the best I had ever had. I also had the Lobster Bisque, which also was amazing and the crab cakes were to die for!

I have mentioned this place to a number of people - and we will certainly go back again ourselves!
author: Brandy R.

description: I think the quality of food here has gone down quite a bit since my last visit. It was my birthday.  We were a party of 4 people.   It took about 1hr after we sat down to get served.   We had clam chowder and it was not good at all.  Very disappointing with clam chowder it had absolutely no flavor what so ever.   My wife ordered halibut and it was impossible to eat because it was very dry over cooked.  My abalone was very good but for $50 plate there were tiny 4 pieces.   My daughter did not like her scallops, dish was covered in butter, completely soaked in butter.  Rice had no flavor at all.  So we asked for french fries.  Likely potato was fine.   I will not be back.  It was $200 for 4 people.  I don't mind paying $200 but not for this food.   They also played some music that would simply add to noise level, so we couldn't even enjoy the company.  Very very disappointing.
author: Alex R.

description:
Dinner for 4, got there a few minutes after they opened (5:00PM) and most of the place was filled. No reservations accepted... I tried. 
Seated right away by a courteous greeter, the service by the waitress was efficient and attentive.  Definitely not a hipster joint, but a long lasting restaurant that is consistent & good. 

At our table (of course I talked everyone out of a bite - and two in one instance). Nothing really exotic (they did have abalone on the menu)  well prepared, tasty & nicely presented dishes:

Salmon & Prawns Combo  -  $23.75 - Nice  "combo" of fresh seafood flavors.

Filet of Sole Newburg  -  $21.37 - a baked delight (kinda an old-school dish) - very nicely prepared ... not a drop of the sauce was left on the plate.

Crab Louie  -  $24.00 - beautiful & tasty & GIANT

Snapper Spicy  -  $18.98 - kinda not that spicy if your into the XXX of spicyness (probably not a real word) but tender & tasty.

Accompanying soups /salad / fries rate a "good" comment. 

Just down the road ( 5 minute walk ) from the Legion of Honor museum, so after nourishing your eyes & mind with beauty at "The Legion", delight your taste buds and fill your belly at Pacific Cafe. 

http://legionofhonor.famsf.org/legion/exhibitions
author: Matsuo U.

description: Be still my heart. They have abalone at this restaurant... delicious, lightly breaded, sautéed, cut-it-with-a-fork tender (but not cheap) abalone!  Oh my!  The only other restaurant where I've found this is in Monterey.  It's on the "Specials of the Day" menu but the waitress assured me it's available 99% of the time.  I give the abalone 6 stars!   All of their bisque soups are also delicious.  My husband loved his scampi.   No reservations but if you arrive early on a weekday the wait isn't long.  However, to make up for this policy, the free "welcome while you wait" bottomless wine makes up for any wait.  And, if you love abalone (or any seafood) like I do, the wait is worth it.
author: Nancy C.

description:
We decided to try this neighborhood spot because it looked cozy and welcoming.
The service here was very good and they staff bring your wine when you are waiting for them to set your table. Most of the tables only seat 4 comfortably, so I wouldn't recommend bringing a large group. They dont take reservations!

The food here is mediocre at best. I ordered the baked trout and it came out looking dry and tasting dry. Also, it seemed like the only seasoning on my fish was salt and pepper, and it lacked any real flavor. That was the general sentiment among the other dishes we ordered. The ingredients seemed fresh but were prepared in a way that is neither unique nor appealing.
author: Alfred L.

description:
Yes, they have free wine.  But you really should drink at least 6 glasses of the sour cheap stuff before you think the food is tasty.  We waited 1.5 hrs for a table in a sea of seniors with their walkers who, sadly, seem to have lost their tastebuds.  Neither the bread nor the butter were even a touch warm so good luck buttering the bread.  The shrimp cocktail had the smallest shrimp ever pulled from the sea.  The turbot was covered in mayo and flavorless.  The halibut was a perfect square of previously frozen watery bland yuck.  Our waitress was mostly absent and seemed bored out of her mind.  At least she wasn't hostile, though...which I guess is saying something.

There's a reason no young people eat here and that it is way down Geary where there are hardly any shops or restaurants.  It sucks.  If that wasn't bad enough, the prices are steep.  Never, ever again.
author: Desmo K.

description:
This place was fantastic! 
After a beautiful long walk on the shore, we build up a great appetite. Since we weren't familiar with places to eat in the area. I looked on Yelp for a little assistance. 
I was just down the street and it had 4 stars so I went for it. 
After getting lucky finding parking right in the front ( a sign we were meant to be here) we walk up to this little place on a corner with a big crowd at the door all having wine. We didn't know what to expect. Within minutes we also had wine and were on the list and were filled in by the regulars and locals that the first seating is the best time to be here. That is right when they open at 5pm.
Even thought we enjoyed the wait and the fun crowd we were happy to be seated 2 glasses of wine and 35 minutes later. 
The place was cozy and neat. We got what we called the best seat in the house. Started of with the best crab cakes i have ever had. Followed by a delicious shrimp salad, and clam chowder. For our main course we had Parmesan crusted Halibut and Grilled Scallops. All was all amazingly fresh and very well prepared.
I very highly recommend if your in the area that you treat yourself to some fantastic San Francisco Seafood and stop by here. I'll definitely come here again.
author: Monica T.

description:
Use to hit this joint years ago. Now, I'm hitting it more often. Glad it is still in business. Warning...this will spoil you in many ways. You will move just to be close to this joint. Really. 

Cocktail of Crab 
Halibut Parmesan
Local Dessert from Zanzes
Plus free wine???

You can't go wrong...
author: Grubbinator A.

description: Just there the other night. Still the insider's place to go for fresh fish and wonderful service.  Petrale sole, clams and calamare steak were fine. Always get that extra order of broccoli and the bisque.
author: Fred  D.

description: Free wine?! Heck yes.  Crab cakes and shrimp are my favorite. Just ok steak and I feel the clam chowder is a little watery. Great environment ! Service is hit or miss.
author: Rebecca E.

description:
Two of my favorite words come to mind when I think of this place:

Free. Wine.

My boyfriend took me here on a Saturday night around 7pm. As soon as we walked in, we were warmly greeted with two generous glasses of free white wine to enjoy while we waited for a table. Our wait was only about 10 minutes, which in this case, was both a good thing and a bad thing (the free wine only flows when you're waiting for a table). 

Aside from the free wine, the food here is excellent. My boyfriend ordered the "Turbot in Parchment" and I ordered one of their specials, grilled salmon/fried prawn combo. My boyfriend's meal had an awesome and unique presentation. The Turbot looks somewhat like a puff pastry with TONS of shrimp and crab inside. My salmon and fried prawns were perfection. The salmon was tender; the prawns were so flavorful, lightly breaded, and not greasy whatsoever. I was very, very pleased. They also provide you with huge, thick slices of great sourdough bread. Yum. 

The service is great, too. Our server was very friendly and there were multiple people running around making sure we had water, etc. My boyfriend and I loved the atmosphere---it's a small and intimate setting, yet booming with energy and noise from the other diners. We had such a fun dining experience, and I can't wait to come back!
author: Melissa W.

description:
Great neighborhood seafood restaurant.  Calamari vinaigrette was a delicious appetizer.  The Crab Cake dinner was expensive however haven't had crab cakes that good in a long time.  My wife ordered the Grilled Wild Salmon and Prawn combo, which was also very good (served in heavy garlic and butter...mmmm).  The Salmon was a little more over-cooked than we like...next time will order it a bit more rare.  Everything was very fresh and tasted great.

The Zanze Cheesecake was the BEST cheesecake we've ever had.  Now I don't know if that is what good cheesecake is supposed to taste like or if it's the bakers version...totally wrecked other cheesecakes for me.
author: Zoran L.

description: I love this place, I live right down the street and eat here once every other month.  My go to dishes are the crab cakes and the shrimp scampi.  The staff treats you like family and the free wine just completes the experience......
author: Linda H.

description: Four of us ate here last night. I probably hadnt been at Pacific Cafe in SF in at least 2o years. It was even better than I remembered. I certainly wont wait another 20 years before I go back again
author: Lew W.

description: So very delicious and in the face of a Father's Day Blitz they managed to hold it together. I've never been so well attended to while waiting 45 minutes for a table. I can't wait to come back and try more of this menu and more of the daily specials. Our waitress is Moreen and I hope that we get to see her again too. Sooooo so happy =)
author: Marc R.

description:
This is San Francisco.
The building is from 1899. The restaurant has been there since the 70's and I wish I was there every night.

No matter what time you get there, you will wait in line as they take no reservations and this place is endlessly popular - but you almost don't care because it moves quickly, perhaps this is partially due to the fact that they give you as much free house white wine as you can drink. Or, perhaps it is all due to this fact...

Either way, no matter how long that wine sipping wait, you will feel special and warm inside and out when you finally are seated. The decor seems to not have changed a bit since the first day the doors opened, the booths are wooden, small and so fitting.

The staff is efficient and the seasoned set that knows what you need before you do and full of personality.

The seafood is fresh and flavorful, the menu is very traditional and classic - something that's pretty common, but hard to find done well. Crab Cakes are loaded with crab and not filler, the Abalone Special is definitely a must and the Sole Newburg is a tasty option too.

This is one of those places, like the Tadich Grill and Caffe Sport that are not to be missed in your food tour of the lore of San Francisco.
author: Katie W.

description:
I love this place and come here every time I am in San Francisco.  I have been here about 5 times in the last few years and I love it.  It is a cute little place that serves great food at a really reasonable price.

They give you a free glass of wine when you walk in the door.  The dinner salads are great as well.  I have liked everything I have eaten here.  

I cannot wait to get back to this place, it is a gem!
author: E T.

description:
Got there at around 9:20pm right before it was going to close and they still decided to seat us. There can be a long wait, so we tried to get there as late as possible.
They gave us a glass of wine while waiting the few minutes even at the end of the night.

They were still super kind of us being the last people there to finish. Everything was spectacular. Service is good and everything is fresh. Definitely order the items on the chalk board! 

Perfect space to have a nice evening with someone special. Not noisy at all even when it is full.
author: Anthony Y.

description: We had to wait an hour for the food to be served and it wasnt even crowded on a sunday night--id say about 10 customers only. Then our server (the one with irish accent) wasnt that nice. She literally had to say out loud while chasing us that we made a mistake for not giving her gratuity after counting the cash that we paid, only for her to realize that her tip (altough she doesnt deserve a penny!) was sitting on the table. Will never come back here!! The food is ok. Youre not missing out on anything. My engagement night was ruined because of this place.
author: Shane M.

description:
I am so glad I came here for dinner even though it was out of the way for someone merely visiting for the weekend. Despite the wait being longer than expected, the complimentary wine while waiting was a solid distraction. Time seemed to fly by a lot faster after the second and third glass of wine. Before you know it, a table is ready for you and your food soon after. 

The atmosphere is very cozy and the food was great. I definitely had to stop myself from eating all of the sourdough bread before and save room for dinner. Albeit the clam chowder was lacking in my eyes but the entrees and fish were fantastic! I tried their daily special and it did not disappoint. 

Overall a great experience and hopefully will be coming back soon as San Francisco seems to have won me over time and time again.
author: Alice N.

description: Big 4 stars for sure. I am fishes biggest fan and it just so happens so is the pacific cafe. I do like some Cajun blackened fish but this is more traditional sf the flavor for my trout was on the side mixed with butter ( I did have a bit of it ) the fish was fresh and properly cooked. Big chunk of bread at the table, free wine while you wait to keep the wait tolerable. Honestly I go here at peak hours and stop if I see people waiting to get my drink on! Friendly staff and free wine. Winning.
author: Nathan B.

description:
I'm caught between 3 and 4 stars; my boyfriend rates it at a 3 whereas I'd rate it a 4 but that's because we both had very different expectations here.

First of all, great service and really attentive servers which I like. Sure, you get a free glass of wine when you walk through the door so if you have to wait then it ends up being... well, kind of enjoyable. Where it differs come down to the expectation in the food itself.

I wanted a very homely kind of dish and I got a very holistic one which works out for me. The problem being that my boyfriend was looking for a true seafood kind of dish and was a bit disappointed. I got the salmon Newburg that was stuffed with crab with fries and a side of clam chowder and he got the scallops (also with fries and the side of clam chowder). Both were great tasting, but he mentioned that while the value was good as was the atmosphere, it was still the scallops were a bit overdone and really relied on the butter.

As for my dish, it was delicious -- you could taste each part distinctly since it all worked so well together. Overall, we think it's a good place to go to but you should have a clear idea of what you're looking for or rather, order with care.
author: Shauna S.

description: Pacific Cafe is completely overrated and overpriced for what it is.  Theres complimentary free wine which tastes like a 2 buck chuck at trader joes.  I was buzzed after two glasses because I was starving.  The crab cakes were 2 for $20 and was the highlight of the entire meal.  The shrimp salad that came with our entree was the next best thing.  The shrimp tasted fresh and the sauce they were drenched in was delicious.   For the entrees, we ordered the halibut, snapper, and sautéed shrimp.  The halibut and snapper lacked flavor.  The sautéed shrimp were full of flavor and cooked to the right amount.  Overall, the service was really good.  They have a sign that says they only refill your water when you ask, but the waiter filled my cup at least 3 times without me have to ask.  Three Stars!
author: Steven S.

description: After a chilly evening in the Bay Area. We stumbled into Pacific Cafe. The service was fantastic. We were seated right away and the waitress was in point. I ordered the clam chowder with the Parmesan crusted halibut with rice pilaf. It was the perfect combo. My husband had the scallops which was prepared perfectly, not under or overcooked. Parking was a bit of a challenge but as expected, it's San Francisco. It had a great old school restaurant feel to the place. Would definitely recommend this place if you are nearby. It was a great stop after a visit to the Sutro Baths.
author: Mare V.

description:
This is a gem. Great food great service. 
The wait staff is very professional. Polite but not surly. 

Same owners 40 years. Same cooks and wait staff for years and it shows in their professionalism. 

I heartily recommend it.
author: Stephano B.

description:
Pacific Cafe came highly recommended by the owner of Rockin' Tacos as well as David R. so I knew this place was a must during my recent visit to SF.

Despite it being a $40 round-trip cab ride from our hotel, it was totally worth it.

We arrived early as we were hungry and had skipped lunch, so there was no wait. I was a little sad since the lure of free cheap wine passed out to patrons for enduring a wait seemed unnecessary, but they were still kind enough to pour us a glass.

When was the last time I had a glass of Chablis? I didn't even know they still made it. It totally hit the spot.

We were seated in a booth by the window. This place is no frills as far as ambiance, but that's what I loved about it - let the food be the stand-out.

And boy was it. We started with the shrimp cocktail. Mounds of tiny bay shrimp that were succulent and plump, and served with housemade cocktail sauce. A perfect start.

For entrees I ordered ahi tuna with wasabi butter and my dc ordered grilled salmon. Entrees are served with your choice of soup or salad and we decided to get one of each so we could share; clam chowder for him and caesar salad for me.

I am generally wary of caesar salads as the dressing is often make-or-break for me, but theirs was spot-on. Not overly-dressed and not gloupy, with crisp, fresh romaine and crunchy croutons. Very good enough.

The clam chowder was great too; not too fishy as is often the case, and well-seasoned. 

Our fish arrived, as well as a side of broccoli with lemon butter sauce, and we dove in. Both fish were cooked perfectly; seems an easy thing to do, but I am always surprised at how often I am served overcooked fish. The tuna was a huge, thick slab of pink yumminess and the wasabi butter added a nice bite. On the side was rice pilaf which was fair, but I wasn't there to eat rice, so no harm, no foul.

The salmon apparently was delicious too but I didn't try it as it's not one of my favorite fish. The accompanying steamed red potatoes were more boiled than steamed and were rather mushy and tasteless. Again, not there for the sides, so no big deal. The broccoli more than made up for it.

We forewent (is that a word?) dessert and instead just had coffee and finished our wine, marvelling at the great dinner we enjoyed.

Although I generally try not to visit the same places on subsequent trips to the same city, I will most certainly be back to Pacific Cafe.
author: Melanie S.

description: If you like seafood, you must come here! It is such a cute and cozy restaurant. (Even the bathroom is charming!) It gets really loud, but the table partitions block out a lot of noise, and you can talk comfortably with your friends. And if you have to wait for a table, the host gives you a free glass of wine. The food was really delicious! I had the crab diablo (crab steeped in a garlic butter sauce), which came with clam chowder. The crab was rich and cooked perfectly, and the chowder was hearty. Service was kind of spotty, though.
author: Rachel H.

description: I have been to Pacific Cafe 3 different times and have fell in love each time. I told myself I'd try something new every time I went because everything on the menu is amazing. You cannot go wrong with this place. Fresh seafood, wide selection of different fish, crab, shrimp. Snapper with crab in parchment was creamy and delicious, Halibut was juicy and fresh, and the Parmesan Halibut was just perfectly seasoned and cooked to perfection. The bread while you wait is amazing, free wine, the shrimp Louie that comes with your meal, just great. I have nothing but great things to say about Pacific Cafe. Old school atmosphere, a lot of locals, and very friendly service.
author: Jackie S.

description: The best place worth the wait. A friend brought me here about 9 years ago and I've been looking for the place ever since.  Finally I asked another friend and he remembered we went again. The stuffed trout is to die for. You must ask for it they took this option off the menu. I have only had this meal because it's so good.
author: Georgie C.

description:
The food is good, but if you're not in the mood for seafood or you don't like it.. don't go here. Or be happy with the only non fish/sea food item on the list: A steak. 

I didn't feel like eating fish and the only reason why i went there, was because my mother wanted to go for a celebration. 

The service here sucks. I was out with my brother and mom and when it came time to pay the bill, the waitress looked at my brother ( who was paying) and asked: ''She will also be on the card or should I put ''her'' separate?'' 
The whole night that waitress was just fake. Didn't like her at all. Just how she asked me how I wanted my food prepared (well done steak) and if i wanted salad or soup, fries or baked potatoes. It was very fake of her. She didn't hide it well.
author: L S.

description:
Granted, my date and I popped into the place after already splitting a bottle o' Charles Shaw on the beach, but I think my general positive vibes for this place weren't too disguised by the cloud of lush. First plus was that we had to wait around five minutes for a free table, so we were handed a complimentary glass of white wine to tide us over. 

The waitress was sweet, dealt with all our inane questions about what Newburg sauce is, and even participated in our zombie outbreak scenario planning. Her winning answer was a spiked boomerang on a string.

House bread was cold, which is a :(, but as usual, it's a vehicle for consuming some butter, so whatever. I probably should have asked for another basketful of carbs to go with  my steamed mussel sauce, but now I"ll have more for the linguine that'll feed me tomorrow. I had a bite of the fish done in the Newburg way, which seems like piling a mound of crab flesh and cheese on a fish filet and then baking it. Looks like I lose in entree choice. Mussels are tasty as usual, but I should have gone for something unique, I suppose.

Cute little place with old timesy pics of Cliff House and the GG bridge in its baby years. Filled with the gays too. Well, the gays and elderly couples playing cards and talking about movie excursions.
author: Kevin L.

description: Exorbitant prices for glorified cafeteria food. Seems like a nice bunch of people run the place, but after refusing to accommodate a member of our party's shellfish allergy there was no hope of recovering. We actually had to inform the waitress that scallops are indeed a type of shellfish. The same member of our party shared that the last time he ate at Pacific Cafe, he was assured the salmon bisque had no shellfish in it, only to be told half-way through the bowl that it actually contained lobster. Dangerous, sloppy, dated, bland, and clueless. No amount of free wine could ever convince me to return.
author: SF S.

description: Free wine but it's so awful it will give you the worst hangover. The food is good but don't drink the free wine while you're waiting for a table.
author: Michael A.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. It has the best crab cakes ever and the staff is supper friendly, they try to remember your name and say hi while you wait for your table you get a complimentary glass of wine. If your a sea food lover I highly recommend this place. It is  not cheap but so worth the price it really is a hidden Treasure in San Francisco. This place is always busy so if you don't want to wait you need to get there early. Its not a big place but it is supper yummy.
author: Norell F.

description:
How can you not love a place that brings you free wine while you wait?!? This place is hopin, so be prepared to wait but it's well worth it. There is a huge board with all of the specials. I was drawn in my all of the signs and articles posted about their award winning crab cakes, so that's what I ordered. My boyfriend got the Parmesan halibut, and our friends got the ahi tuna with wasabi butter, and seared scallops. Everything was so fresh and absolutely delicious. I was really happy with my crab cakes. The next day I was ready to go back for some more. Dinner is a little pricey, but with the free wine, bread, soup or salad, and choice of side its really a good deal.  The clam chowder and shrimp louie salad were both amazing. They serve Mitchell's ice cream for dessert. The pear sorbet was some of the best I've ever had. It was so sweet and refreshing.

The restaurant itself is a little older, but really cute. It has big fun lights and is right on the corner. Our server was amazing. We never had an empty glass and food came very quickly. I will definitely be back!
author: Kari G.

description:
-Free wine while you wait? Heck yes! 
-Great sourdough bread and butter? Double heck yes!
-Calamari salad with Italian vinaigrette: fresh, giant pieces of lightly steamed calamari in an Italian vinaigrette dressing. Bits of crispy lettuce and celery for texture. My favorite thing on the menu!
-Crab salad: giant chunks of crab meat...that's is....comes with cocktail sauce but you don't really need it.
-Clam chowder: the only thing that was meh. A bit watery for me, but I'm used to chowder from seattle or new england. No chunks of anything, and needed loads of Tabasco.
-Spicy snapper and rice pilaf: Great! Nice white fish cooked perfectly. Wasn't spicy at all, still great!
author: Alex L.

description: I have been eating here for around 25 years.  Yes I ate here was 11 I am spoiled like that. I hope this place never changes so many places in SF are new and cookie cutter. Most of the time I come here there is a short wait. The best thing about the wait is you get a free glass of wine when you wait.  People that come here are older then 60 I hope to see some younger faces in here at some point. When people ask me where should they go eat, I always tell them if you like seafood you must go to my favorite place in SF. Pacific cafe.  I used to get the shrimp Louisiana sometimes they have it as a special. Now I get the scallops or the salmon and crab new berg. Food is great but I go for nostalgia!!!
author: Trevor E.

description: I love this place. The wait is worth it. The food has never disappointed. Ever.The service is great. It's interesting how some reviewers complain about the prices. The prices are incredibly reasonable! Where else can you get a salad or soup with great sourdough bread as well as your entree AND comp wine these days? Think about it. The cozy old school neighborhood cafe vibe is charming. Remember people, this place has been in existence for decades and is still going strong. There's a reason for it.
author: Mel B.

description:
One of my really good friends wanted to treat me to a nice seafood dinner so she thought she'd take me here. She raves about his place so needless to say I was excited to see what they had to offer.

We went there on a Tuesday night and were seated quickly, we were also offered free wine (red or white.) My friend had the white and I had the red, the red wasn't horrible but it certainly wasn't the greatest but hey, it was free. The white wine was horrible, we each took a sip and just left it behind; once again, at least it was free.
They were out of the tuna which is what we had hoped on getting so I got the clam bisque as well as the salmon with prawns.

The clam bisque was flavorful and hit the spot. It was served at just the right temperature and served in a timely manor as well.

The Salmon and prawns, the prawns were good but nothing special. I don't know if the prawns were supposed to be flavored but they surely didn't taste like they had any seasoning or flavoring. The salmon were extremely hot when I received it, not even the potatoes were as hot as the salmon (odd that it was this hot when the clam bisque was just perfect.) The salmon was far to dry and over cooked. The salmon was so dry and over cooked I couldn't taste any sort of freshness to it. Its like they kept cooking it to make sure it was actually dead.

The bread that they gave us was alright but then again I'm not a big bread girl, my friend on the other hand is. She accidentally dropped the last piece of the bread and put in the basket to as for more bread as she had dropped this piece. The waitress came by quickly with a new basket and tried to dump the remaining bread that we had in the basket into the new basket of bread. Instead of just dumping into the new bread basket which was bad enough, the old bread (that was the one that had fallen to begin with) fell on my plate of food! The waitress muttered the words "I'm sorry" and picked up the bread and still put it back in the basket with the new bread. Luckily we were full by this point and decided to ask for the check and left.
author: Cescilia A.

description: Food was way to expensive for the flavor and presentation. $28.00 for Halibut with 3 red potatoes. Atmosphere was old and dated. The staff was very informal for the prices you are paying. No view, limited parking
author: Dianna O.

description:
Breakdown (I saved my receipt so I can share with the yelp community):

-Calamari Steak w/ Salad & shrimp--$16.75
-Spicy Snapper w/ Salmon Bisque--$18.68

[Dessert]
-Coffee-$2 
-Chocolate Mousse Cake--$5.25
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
($46.74 for two with tax, before tip)

So the actual reason why I wanted to go here was because I saw Rachel Ray made a big deal about how wonderful this spot was. Yes there was complimentary wine while you wait which is a very smart business tactic though I don't drink alcohol so it didn't do much for me. My partner and I were the youngest ones here, the demographics are mostly older caucasian couples. The atmosphere is very nostalgic, lots of historical photos on the walls. Service is friendly and i was surprised with how quick our dishes came. Parking is kind of an issue, keep in mind this is the Richmond District. 

Food: liked the salad w/ shrimp and the salmon bisque. Didn't try the spicy snapper because I can't handle spicy food. It was even spicy for my partner, who's Indian. He liked it though he preferred to have the spices mostly marinated, he felt like it was mostly sprinkled on top for an extra kick. I had the calamari steak, which was buttery and good for the first several bites. After I ate about 1/3 of it I felt like it was too much for me and I couldn't finish it. Even with the potatoes between bites, I felt like it was too much of the same taste. Maybe in small bits in moderation, or with half the calamari steak with something else it would've been better.

The chocolate cake and coffee was very good though I felt a little rushed because the amount of people waiting made me feel guilty. It was very busy even though it was a Wednesday night!

All in all it was a good place and experience, though I feel like it's more of a restaurant my parents would love rather than myself. They are way more into seafood, wine, and that atmosphere than I am.
author: Catherine M.

description: Long line when it approaches to the weekend! Food are good! Staff are friendly! Like their salads,  fresh!! Only one time the baked salmon was kinda raw inside but they took it back and cook it more when requested.
author: Elm E.

description:
Never EVER ever again.

First, bad value. The waitress encouraged us to order fish and chips, off the menu since we had three kids with us. I said, what fish would you recommend? She answered, Halibut is really the only decent option. So we did. They charged us $26 PER order. We ordered two... so we spent $52 + tip + tax for just the kids' super dry fish and chips that nobody enjoyed. It's our fault for not asking the price, but she said it was what most kids ordered so we were expecting kid-friendly prices. This was in addition to our regular meal of seafood, which was regularly priced and regularly  cooked. I don't understand how this place gets the $$ rating. You hear about review fraud, and this place makes me wonder... we left feeling totally duped. 

Second, the place was super cramped and GERIATRIC. With kids, you end up eating dinner at 5:30 and the place was packed with people that were in their 70s-80s. That should give you a good idea for what you're getting. I typically love traditional restaurants that are throwbacks to a bygone era, but this vibe was not nostalgic-- it was staid and smelled like old people that took forever in their one bathroom. 

Oh yes, that brings me to my next point, the bathroom... Let me take a deep breath here. If you need to go to this restaurant for any reason, GO POTTY BEFORE YOU EAT HERE. It is not even a quarter bath. It's like a 1/8 bath. I don't like to touch many things in a filthy public bath, but you can't help rubbing yourself all over the place because just to turn around and flush means that you're bumping up against the sink. Forget about having to take a toddler. Nuff said. Let your imagination fill in with Trainspotting clips here...

Most importantly, the food was subpar. My shrimp louie salad was disgusting. It was thousand island and bay shrimp over dried lettuce (brown edges and all). All three fish dishes (other than the dry fish and chips) were mediocre. I could do better with some salt, butter and a pan. The only thing I ate was the clam chowder (it had a nice kick). 

Aside, the free wine was really bad. It was sour and smelled weird. I wouldn't waste the calories on it.
author: C K.

description: This place has been around for 40 years; typical San Francisco restaurant like in the olden times without reservation or hipster service. Older folks come here and are not rushed around. We waited 40 mns - when you are given a glass of wine to make the wait more palatable - and we dined in 45. Fish is very fresh and prepared simply. Great prices and plenty of wines to select from.
author: J.J. L.

description:
I wish I could post 0 stars. Terrible service and mediocre food. Be ready for 1 hour wait (that is for a waiter to show up after you've been seated + another 30 mins for them to get back with a bill) and mixed up orders.

We had a large party of 10 or so ppl so we were split and seated at two different tables and *served by two different* waiters. Nevertheless they insisted on 18% automatic tip (there's no way we would've tipped that much for the wait that long). Despite of all that they brought two separate bills which they mixed up between two tables and charged one bill to another table (wtf, are you serious?). Refused to apologize. What a dump.
author: Dmitry I.

description:
Ambiance!
Romantic!
Clean!
Fun!
Friendly, professional service.
It's all about the fish. You can ask them about today's responsible choice and they can tell you all about it.
author: Ven B.

description: We try to have a special meal once a year before the holiday craziness and Pacific Cafe was the chosen destination. From the moment we were seated, Maureen was on top of her game. We had 2 gluten free guests and brought a gluten free baguette that Maureen graciously warmed in the kitchen. She was flawless in her service. She paid attention to so much detail; no croutons on the 2 gluten free salads even though we had not made a special request of no croutons on the salad. The food was delicious and plentiful. The water glasses were always full and our plates cleared at all the perfect moments. We ended our meal with the pear sorbet split between the five of us. Dessert portion was perfect and the sorbet was excellent. Four of us took home the remainder of our meals, looking forward to yet another reminder/treat of our great meal. We will definitely be back. Maureen is truly the epitome of hospitality in this industry.
author: Veronica L.

description:
Definitely some of the worst seafood I've had in the city. I would give them one star, except for how they met us at the door with complementary white wine that didn't suck, to drink while we waited. So an extra star for that. The rest of the experience is solidly, unambiguously one-star worthy.

After the greeting, the service was cold at best. The waiter came by only reluctantly throughout the evening and barely looked at us or spoke. That would have been okay had the food been good, but sadly it was awful.

We got the shrimp cocktail to start (hard to mess up), then the crab cakes and the grilled salmon as mains, one with clam chowder and fries, the other with crab bisque and rice pilaf. Wow, nasty... the crab cakes, admittedly, were okay. Not the bland stuff you usually get. The rest was cafeteria-quality food.

Claw chowder tasted like it was out of a can, really gross. Crab bisque was a gelatinous blob of cream and corn starch with maybe a hint of crab in there somewhere. Definitely didn't have that fresh shellfish-stock taste that makes a great bisque.

I had two bites of the rice and couldn't do any more of it. Just really awful, overcooked, seasoning tastes like out of a box. Fries I didn't try b/c they looked so bad.

The salmon was cooked very poorly. Overdone and tough on the outside, raw in the middle, and served with a slab of butter dumped on top. I felt sorry for the fish. Also, we could see the cooks in the open kitchen from our table, and I watched my salmon sit under the heat lamps for over 5 minutes before the accompanying crab cakes came out. Not cool. They also looked like they hate their jobs, which is also not cool when they're practically cooking in the dining room.

All of this might have been okay if we were paying $12.99 a plate, but it was more like $25.99 a plate. You can get light-years better seafood in SF for the same price and eat in a place that doesn't look like they haven't changed the decor since they opened in 1974. 

I would definitely never come back here. Honestly, the biggest impression I got was that this would make a good episode for Gordon Ramsay's Kitchen Nightmares.
author: Aaron G.

description:
Solid.
Several classic dishes (the Parmesan Halibut is flaky and tasty.)
