Plus a smattering of daily specials.  Also high on my list are the scallops.  When grilled, they have a marvelous slightly sweet taste.
Can't go wrong with the broccoli side, either.
If there's a wait, enjoy some wine...that's their thing.
The staff are all marvelous, and most have been there for years and years and know their stuff.
author: Ken B.

description:
CHECK, PLEASE! BAY AREA: SEASON 2: EPISODE 6 (206)

4.5 STARS 

July 11, 2009 @ 7pm, Saturday Date Night with Boyfriend

Saturday nights dates are really important for me and my boyfriend.  It is our time at the end of the week to catch up and just enjoy each other. It's more than going out, it is friendship and keeping that "flame" going.  

So this Saturday was another opportunity. We just wanted a nice, relaxing and laid-back dinner after a really exhausting work week. Pacific Cafe was the perfect place.  It was homey and unpretentious. People were casually and warmly dressed for the cold Richmond district weather . 

This restaurant has been around since 1974 and as San Francisco as you can get--local, friendly and specializing in seafood.  The decor was nostalgic--very 70's. 

True to its tradition, we were offered a FREE GLASS OF WINE each while waiting for a table.  You just walk in, put your name on the clipboard and find a seat either inside the waiting area huddled with other patrons. We didn't mind since it was nice to be cozy in this cold weather--or sit outside of the restaurant and start a friendly conversation with others who are waiting for their table.

Since BF does not drink, so I got 2 glasses of nice Chardonnay. (Woo Hoo!)  The staff came out to REFILL our glasses but 2 glasses of wine are pretty much all I can handle.

It didn't take us long to get seated at one of the wooden booths, probably about half an hour. We enjoyed looking at the memorabilias  (like how much food cost in 1974) and sipping wine while waiting.  A basket of sourdough bread was waiting for us at our table. We devoured it and we got another basket as soon as  we finished the first one.  The service was superb and very attentive. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZiTRspDPY9T_kh4tQDwDMQ?select=mQFbFnJXxAcsBUFgSISOrw
For appetizers we ordered a CRAB COCKTAIL.   It was a huge scoop of packed fresh crab meat with cocktail sauce. Delicious!

Our entrees came with either soup or salad.  I had the SALMON BISQUE and BF had the CLAM CHOWDER.  Let me just say that it was the best fish soup I've ever had!  Not fishy but creamy and really flavorful. BF loved his clam chowder which was not overly rich.

For our entrees, BF had the PARMESAN HALIBUT and I had the CALAMARI STEAK. Both seafood dishes came with a choice of rice, mashed potato or french fries They were really delicious and seasoned well. Tender and not tough or dry.

I didn't finish my calamari steak because I HAD to eat dessert.  BF and I splurged. I went to the restroom and when I returned a CHOCOLATE TORTEhttp://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZiTRspDPY9T_kh4tQDwDMQ?select=lckLBs-kMUdX2yH3qZFVQA and MITCHELL'S CARAMEL PRALINE ICE CREAM  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZiTRspDPY9T_kh4tQDwDMQ?select=KMl91uoJVj2hLxL1mKujUQ waiting for me.  BF finished the torte and our spoons fought over the ice cream.  My gosh, soooo delicious! (Forget about being lacto. My suffering later was worth the creamy bisque and Mitchell's ice cream!)

When we got the tab, we were surprised that our tab was only $84 Iincluding tax and tip! That was after splurging and satisfying our voracious appetites!

The food at Pacific Cafe was simple but comforting and delicious. We really enjoyed our dinner. 

I wanted to drive straight to Ocean Beach to catch the sunset but I was too full, still too exhausted from the week before. BF and I went straight home where I passed out for the 3rd night in a row while he watched "The Unborn"-- a creepy, scary movie. Thank God I was out like a light or I would have had nighmares for a week!

(I didn't get a chance to take pictures of the PARMESAN HALIBUT AND CALAMARI STEAK. We just attacked them as soon as the server placed them in front of us!)
author: Leah E.

description:
Pacific Catch is exactly how a seafood restaurant should be. It's covered in wood, painted in warm colors and filled with San Francisco and sea memorabilia. They serve cheap wine and offer their cheapest for free. They give rustic bread and butter and serve large portions of salmon, prawns, snapper, halibut or another catch of the day. The staff are warm, professional and efficient.
On my last visit, there was a line out the door, but within 20 minutes we were seated. I ordered the salmon and prawns and was delighted by the prawns soaked in garlic and butter sauce. After the prawns, I used red potatoes to soak up the rest of the buttery flavor. My water glass was never less than half full. When we wanted to leave, the check came immediately. In all, a simply lovely neighborhood restaurant.
author: Nicole S.

description: Ive been there couple times and I love this place! They give free wine when you are waiting ! Food is good and fresh.Good service!
author: Kiko W.

description:
This has been a family tradition for us for a number of years. Every time we visit San Fran, we would plan one night to come to Pacific Cafe. It has always been so much fun standing around talking to people from all over while drinking several glasses of complimentary wine, as if you are at a foodie home group. 
To be fair, the seafood has always been very fresh, something that is absolutely necessary and I appreciate this place for that. My son had raw oysters as an appetizer, which he said was delicious. We had chowder, but I am a purist, having grown up in Boston, and the base had way too much flour in it for me, preferring a cream reduction, as well as too much thyme. Maybe that's a regional difference because my son who lives here liked it.
I got scallops scampi-style, once again very fresh, with tomatoes and garlic, but there was almost no flavor to it because the chafing dish was full to the brim with oil; I don't even think it was butter. I want to taste the garlic in scampi!
My husband had fried oysters, which he normally loves, but the fat used to fry them had not been changed frequently enough, as evidenced by the dark color, saturation of grease and burnt taste. He was very disappointed. Fresh seafood is totally spoiled by improper preparation.
Our son's girlfriend had white fish with lemon and capers that was simply and excellently prepared. Our son had salmon and fried shrimp which he also said was very good.
Unfortunately, I think the family tradition has been broken because my husband says he won't go back.
author: Anna Marie P.

description: The food was delicious. I got the Shrimp Scampi and I was not disappointed. The waitress was very busy, but still she managed to be attentive to our table.
author: Sugar M.

description:
Ok, so it's not the most modern/ fashionable place but it's way out there on Geary.   It's a San Francisco Seafood institution and I can't believe I waited so long to come here.

Anyways....FREE WINE while you wait which is cool.   But, the food really is good.  The chowder is amazing, and I love the wood and windows and lighting.  I think it's just great.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Blast from the past . . .  Check out their photo album while you're waiting for your table!  -and walls are festooned with pics of "old" San Francisco and fishing parties.

-and, complimentary white wine. . . a long forgotten touch of hospitality.

Ordering (multiple choices on the daily specials, as well as their 'regular' menu.  Deciding is not easy there.)

oyster bisque or clam chowder (or salad)
Petrale sole dore'
calamari steak
turbot, stuffed & parchment baked.
Everything comes to the table hot, fresh & flavorful.

+bottomless [FRESH Sourdough] bread basket, water & lemon & tartar sauce . . .

+Mitchell's ice cream, if you still have room for dessert.

It's kind of touch of home.  mellow yellow to It's all G.

Enjoy
author: Clifford L.

description: Awesome! My wife and I went there with our infant daughter. There was a wait and they gave us each a complimentary glass of white wine. Fit our seafood meal perfectly. The food was tasty and served in a reasonable time considering how busy they were.  Waitress was attentive despite the high traffic. Wouldn't bring more than a group of four as the tables seem to be all booth style.
author: Sean S.

description: We were in the City looking for a seafood place to celebrate my retirement and my daughter's birthday. I grew up three blocks from the place and attended Washington High. First time back in 20+ years. The place was just like i remembered and still giving away complimentary  wine as you wait. Fresh seafood and fresh waitress. Its not Green, sustainable, or organic, it's Old school SF, just like me...
author: Sherman L.

description:
The ingredients are really fresh and the food is delicious.  The best thing about this place? Free wine if you have to wait for a table! What a great idea! 

The menu may seem limited, but they have a bunch of daily specials based on what is fresh and in season! 

The servers are friendly and polite, but it did take quite a while to take our order and to refill drinks (something I am a stickler for), so that is why I rate it 4 stars instead of 5.
author: Jessyca M.

description:
I loved everything about this restaurant and my experience here - Thanks for the suggestion, way-too-talkative seatmate on my plane ride to SFO. It was a long hour listening to your life story about moving from Detroit to San Francisco, your hotel preferences for the area, and your thoughts on healthcare reform, but the restaurant tip made it all worthwhile.

Food: The scallops with lemon butter were cooked perfectly. The crab appetizer was an ice cream scoop size of fresh dungeness crabmeat served with cocktail sauce. My friend's crab cake appetizer was off the hook. Salmon bisque was really creamy, so depending on your taste that could be good or bad. The grilled salmon was bland, but it was fresh and was cooked well. Most of the dishes are not overly seasoned or doused in sauce, just served with some liquid butter, lemon, and homemade tartar sauce.

Pacific Cafe isn't some hoity toity place, which is what I really appreciate. It's just fresh seafood, cooked by pros, showcasing the pureness of the ingredients. This was my favorite meal during my trip to the Bay Area and I'm putting it on my must-have list for whenever I visit again.
author: Angela C.

description:
Best crab cakes I have ever had in SF! The food is always fresh and good. Sometimes the wait can be long -- just know that and either go early and avoid the crowd or be prepared to have conversation for awhile before you eat (and enjoy a glass of wine while you wait!). 

As others have noted, the ambiance is very sweet and romantic. Servers are friendly and nice -- Maureen and Frank, in particular!
author: R J.

description:
I've been here twice recently and had the Crab Diablo both times.  Best crab ever...hot and buttery and just prefect.  The first time, I also had crab bisque was  wonderful, and the second time clam chowder which was very good but different...brothy and not nearly as thick and creamy as I prefer.  For dessert I had yummy pear sorbet which tasted just like fresh pears...it's from Mitchell's, so I'll definitely be going there to get a pint sometime.
Service was prompt and friendly, though there can be a wait to be seated.  I didn't mind the wait though, as you get complimentary wine if you have to wait.  This is the first restaurant I've been to with this perk, which I think is pretty cool.  Overall, this may be my favorite restaurant in the city.
author: Emily R.

description:
Excellent Service by experienced servers in a traditional SF haunt.

At the recommendation of a cab driver (the best kind), I first heard about Pacific Cafe, years before I had the pleasure to dine here for a farewell dinner on my way out of town. I'd heard that you're given complimentary wine while waiting, that the restaurant has been in business for years, that it was a local / old-school sort of venue (i.e. not hip & trendy), and all of these characteristics appealed to me. 

I also heard that the food was delicious.

My dining companion had the abalone, and I had the petrale sole with white wine, mushrooms & capers. Both: Remarkable.
author: Sally M.

description: With too much hype in this restaurant, I had high expectations. I was satisfied with good food but disappointed after such long wait.
author: Kay D.

description:
1. Waited 90 minutes for a table in the cold, standing and shivering outside on a 55 degree day, even though we were told 30 minutes, because the hostess scratched our name off the list and skipped us.
2. As "compensation" for our horrendous wait, we were given one tiny little shrimp cocktail for a group of 4.
3. Seafood was ok, nothing to write home about.
4. I, as a vegetarian, knew there was nothing for me on the menu, but figured they would make at least a minimal effort to throw something together for me. What they made? A microscopic side salad with no flavor and almost no dressing. 
5. Service was nearly non-existent. Server never once came back to ask how anything was, if we needed anything else, etc.
author: Melissa M.

description:
Been meaning to go to this place for years and finally went for our anniversary. We had about a 40 min wait on a Tuesday night. We got the free wine and even refills. Everything was very good. Fave was salmon bisque soup. 

Unprepared for how much food they give you and couldn't finish my entree. We would go back and order less food, maybe 1 entree and 1 app. 

It has been there since 1973 and is very charming inside.  The crowd is older and a good place to take visiting parents. 

We took the bus and walked home but I know parking is tricky in that area.
author: Denise S.

description: I drive by this place everyday, and I finally got to check it out. We got there around 9pm and there were 5 small parties ahead of us on the waiting list. We were provided with complimentary white wine while waiting. We were finally seated around 9:30, so it wasn't such a long wait after all. We also got complimentary sourdough bread. I ordered the lobster bisque and halibut Parmesan because one of the staff  recommended it. The whole meal was really good, but I was so full from the wine, bread, and soup that I couldn't finish my entree. Overall, it was a good meal, and I would definitely recommend it to anyone who wants an authentic San Francisco dining experience.
author: Lyn D.

description:
This place has been in business since 1974.  That alone should tell you something.  My mother used to come here with her friends, and now the baton has been passed to me.  Here are Pacific Cafe's major assets:

Friendly service.  Nice Irish waitresses that have been there a long time, and are great at what they do.  Also, the owner comes out often to check on guests, and has a great memory for who has been there before.  How many places can you say that for?  

Delicious seafood.  Don't come here if you don't want seafood.  That's what they do, and they do it well.

Cozy atmosphere.  They have lovely booths that feel very private.  They also serve you wine while you wait!  What else could you ask?
author: Siobhan D.

description:
The thing is, if my mother-in-law wrote this review, she would have given Pacific Cafe 6 stars, but I have come to terms with the fact that sometimes, people just have different tastes. (And too bad she isn't a yelper to tip the scale here.) 

What she would have raved about: the free wine while waiting. That won her over instantly. I am pretty sure you could serve her frozen dinners after that and she will still be like "well, they are nice people...." The other couple of stars from her would be for the ambiance and the food, both comforting. The fact that it's a homey establishment older than her eldest kid means there is history and tradition here. And the menu is simple and straightforward. Nothing "avant-garde." You pick your fish, you pick your side, and you get what you ordered. When they say potatoes, you get two solid red potatoes, nothing trendy like sweet potato fries with wasabi dipping or something. 

Now, for me, the reception is a little different. First, I don't drink wine so I gave mine to my MIL. I do like the homey ambiance and decor and especially the nice wooden booths a lot. I also enjoy a simple and straightforward menu, but I was a bit disappointed with the dishes. I had the Snapper "Spicy." They said it's kinda Cajun flavored and my mouth instantly watered reminiscing over the Cajun-style seafood pasta at Maritime Cafe. Unfortunately my fish was over cooked. I am not sure how the fish can seem to be moist but rubbery at the same time. But it was. And as I tried my husband's halibut Parmesan, I felt like his fish was kinda overcooked too. More disappointing was the sides: the red potatoes that came in two solid uncut potatoes! I didn't know what to do with them. And my husband's choice of rice looked like what Airlines serve. The Chinese in me is very picky about rice. 

There was one thing we can all agree on: the pacific clam chowder was fantastic. Not as creamy as New England clam chowder, but so flavorful! 

Dining experiences like this really puts me in awe of how complex food is to a person. It doesn't just provide taste, but triggers a whole array of psychological components that pushes some flavors forward and suppresses others. Why else would my parents still eat only Shanghainese cuisine after being in the States for over 20 years? Do American food not also provide the 5 tastes: sweet, bitter, sour, spicy, umami? But somehow a certain whiff, a certain color combination, a certain smile of the waitress reminds them of something familiar and comforting. And then, they have no desire to eat anything but that.
author: Candice B.

description: The thing I remember most about this place is FREE WINE while you wait. My bf and I came here on a Friday night around 8pm and had to wait about an hour, and we were pretty drunk by the end of that hour. When I saw "free wine" in the Yelp highlights, I was thinking a free glass or 2, but the old Asian man just kept coming out of the kitchen refilling our glasses when they weren't even half done! It was awesome, but it wasn't at the same time because I felt like I was too drunk off of cheap wine to really enjoy my food. I remember having ordered the crab cake, shrimp salad, salmon bisque, clam chowder, and parmesan halibut with rice pilaf. I really liked the crab cake, clam chowder, and parmesan halibut, but I wasn't really a fan of the salmon bisque (but I think I'm just not a bisque person) or the shrimp salad (the shrimp was too soupy). I suggest coming at an earlier time or maybe even later when they are about to close unless you want to get wasted before your meal. Because who can say no to free wine??
author: Stephanie G.

description:
I think this place gets high marks due to the free wine. I was intrigued myself after reading the yelp reviews. No reservations? A line before opening? 

Sounded awfully familiar (e.g. Burma superstar, Kappou Gomi). 

So ... it had to be good right?

Well, I guess that depends on your definition of good.

What I ordered with my bf:

Appetizer crab cake, Turbot in Parchment, Clam chowder, Salmon Bisque.

Yes, that is all we ordered. We don't really eat a lot and I'm glad we didn't order a second entree because frankly I was disappointed.

Crab cake: The appetizer size is $9.50 and you only get one crab cake. One! I expected there to be two small ones at least for $9.50.  All right, it had a lot of crab in it... but there wasn't much crab flavor. It wasn't sweet and the texture was mushy. I'm guessing they used frozen crab for this. In addition, the crab cake came to the table a bit on the cold side. Ick. Seafood, especially fried/pan fried seafood must be served piping hot. There was also nothing special about the flavor. Most times when I have crab cakes in restaurants I go "mmm YUM!" None of that here. Disappointing. To be honest, I've made a better crab cake myself...

Clam chowder: This tasted different from most typical clam chowders. The consistency was a lot thinner and more potato-ey. I didn't really mind it. But the sad thing is... it sorta reminded me of rice gruel (or rice soup... aka "jook" for you Chinese). It was a bit of a turn off... but the taste was acceptable.

Salmon bisque: I read a lot of positive reviews, so I was looking forward to this. I was disappointed. The soup base was too cream heavy. Now, I love cream soups, but I couldn't even taste any salmon flavor. Might as well have called this soup salmon colored cream soup because that's what it was. The only reason why I knew it was the salmon soup was due to the color of the soup and the teeny tiny bits of salmon floating in the soup.

Turbot in parchment: This was all right. I agree with another reviewer who said the taste was kind of bland. Yes, it was rich due to the cream. It was even kind of salty. But somehow the overall taste was bland. 

I don't know, maybe we didn't order the right things. Sorry, but free wine isn't enough to entice me back to this place. The food did not live up to the hype nor the wait in line.  To be honest, Kincaid's and Scott's Seafood do this type of food better. If you're satisfied with mediocre food and free wine, then by all means, give it a try.
author: michelle l.

description: Pacific Cafe sets the standard for seafood in San Francisco.
author: Matt C.

description:
Can we say scrumptious? Came here on a whim because we were in the neighborhood and it was recommended to us. My usual rule with seafood is to never order it at a restaurant on Sundays and Mondays. You can thank Anthony Bourdain for that one. However, after a quickie view of Yelp reviews we decided to take a leap of faith.

Good sign number one: it was a Sunday night around 8:30p.m. - the place was packed! Good sign number two: the place did not reek of fish. Good sign number three (and my favorite): Complimentary wine while you wait for your table. Uh, yes please.

On to the meal. We ordered a crab cake to start - moist, delicious and I loved the tartar sauce. We also opted to try the Pacific Clam Chowder which was quite possibly the best clam chowder I've had in a very long time. For our entrees I ordered the grilled halibut and my fiance had the spicy red snapper. Both were cooked to perfection. 

Why four stars and not five? The sides. Their special vegetable side that night were green beans so we thought we would try them. Unfortunately it turned out to be a  green bean  faux pas. They were way overcooked.  Both of us ordered red potatoes for our dinner sides but they ran out, so he had the rice and I had the steak fries. I tried his rice and it was well...not great (think pilaf out of a box). My steak fries were just fine. 

We topped off our dinner with the amazing Mitchell's ice cream - a San Francisco institution. Who knew vanilla bean could taste this good! 

The bottom line is the lackluster sides didn't matter, the main focus as it should be is the seafood which was just top notch. I think we may have found our new seafood spot.
author: Susan B.

description: This was our first time visiting Pacific Cafe. The wait was not bad, free wine while we waited. Hostess was very pleasant. I had the sea bass which was great!  My wife had the turbot which was also delicious.  Best seafood we have had in San Francisco!
author: Ric H.

description:
Fresh fish for sure. Ahi Tuna and wasabi butter was nothing mouth watering but it was made well.

DO NOT GET THE ABALONE! They deep-fry it. And if anyone of you is Asian and knows anything about abalone, it it that you don't deep-fry it... Perhaps they even served fake abalone.

Clam chowder is nothing spectacular either. 

3 stars for just having fresh fish and complimentary wine while you wait.
author: Betty W.

description:
We found out about this place when they featured it on Check Please Bay Area. We thought their food was yummy when they showed them on TV. We immediately checked how many stars it had on Yelp and thought we should give it a try since it has 4 star review for over 300 reviews. 

So we did and when we got there, it took us a while to find a place to park. Came in the restaurant and while waiting for our table, they handed us a glass of wine for each. So far so good. We were seated on out table and waited for a while for the waitress to take out order. We ordered:

Oyster cocktail - it was okay, the medium or large size fresh oyster are always disgusting to eat unless the middle part is removed, I ordered it anyways.

Pacific Clam Chowder - delicous
Salmon bisque - delicious too 
spicy snapper with rice - didn't like it, horrible. all i tasted was the cayenne pepper. Sprinkled it with salt thought it would help, just made more disappointed.
crab cakes - bland

wine was good, we had the sauvignon blanc. 

Not worth the long drive, I don't think I would come back here again.
author: Lora M.

description:
This place is fantastic.  It's not presumptuous, which I always appreciate.  The focus isn't on the decor or fancy tricks, it's all about great food.  The service was great, our server, Elaine was friendly and attentive, without being overly so.  I had a great experience.

I got the Spicy Snapper at the recommendation of Elaine.  The fish was cooked really well and the spices built throughout the meal.  It was wonderful.  I got to try bits of the Halibut crusted Parmesan and the Shrimp Louisiana, and those were both fantastic as well.  The Salmon Bisque was probably my favorite part, though.  I definitely plan to go back.
author: Wacey T.

description: Honestly ... free wine??  In San Francisco??  Who cares what the food tastes like.  Who even REMEMBERS what the food tastes like. I just remember having friendly conversations with our fellow line-standers out on the sidewalk, the little guy from the restaurant intermittently popping out to pass out wine glasses filled with (cheap) chardonnay or refill the one you just finished, and finally being ushered in to the warm and cozy restaurant to sit and eat fish.  A terrific date night option after a day at the beach.  Be prepared to wait for a table ... but who really cares when you're drinking wine with all of your new friends on the sidewalk!  (Oh ... and the food was good.)
author: Erik W.

description:
I love this place. The service is great and the seafood is extremely fresh. I can't help but order the baked scallops almost every time I dine here. They are the best scallops I've ever had. 

Just to be thorough, they do provide a free decent chardonnay while you wait. They never hesitate to bring you more wine.
author: Kortni S.

description: My wife and I have had dinner here a number of times, so we felt safe taking some visitors from Seattle here on Monday night. We were so embarrassed! Well, the bread was good. Maybe, it was because we arrived too soon after they opened. My parchment wrapped fish was a nasty soup."The fried shrimp and the calamari steak were greasy. It was the food you would expect from a tourist trap, not a local restaurant. Very disappointed.
author: Roger C.

description: They  serve salmon that melts in your mouth. The best staff, the best chowder. The wait can be long, tough it out. You will be giving it five stars too.
author: dave d.

description:
This is a great little old school seafood house in the Outer Richmond, "perch"ed at the corner of Geary and 34th.

The wait is often quite long as it is very popular and they serve complimentary red and white wine while you wait!  I had never heard of such a silly thing, but it is a really nice touch that eases the fairly lengthy 45 minute wait time (although I think they water it down).

The place specializes in comfort seafood without the frills of the trendy seafood bistros closer in to town.  They serve a nice iceberg salad with louie dressing and bountiful amounts of shrimp, followed by your choice of fresh seafood.  The salmon is excellent.  The fresh sourdough bread is very good too....
author: Rick H.

description: Yummmm. I keep dreaming of the day that I can go back here. The wait for a table was pretty long but wasn't so bad given the fact that we were given complimentary wine! The guy who seemed like the owner was friendly and the one passing out the wine! I would say that this place has classic and quality san franciscan fare. Fresh fish and delicious sourdough. Hands down good quality food that let the natural ingredients be the star.
author: Jane L.

description: Pacific Cafe has been around for 40 years and is still serving solid food. Arrived at 8:30 on a rainy Saturday and only waited 10 minutes with complementary glass of wine (mediocre). Had the lobster bisque which was delish and smooth to start, clam chowder is clear not creamy. Had the crab cakes which were two large cakes and ok but rather heavy and expensive at $28. Husband had parmesean halibut which was great and fresh. Rice or potato side no veggies. Wine corkage only $10 which is a deal. Dessert included SF classic Zanze cheesecake or Mitchell's ice cream. Service great and decor a bit outdated but cozy. I would definitely return.
author: Michelle O.

description: The best seafood ever!  Very popular among the locals, but well worth the wait!  Free wine while waiting...nice touch!
author: Colleen L.

description:
Need another try !

Hubby and I came for dinner on Sunday 6/8/14. Luckily, we found street parking upfront and waited only 3 minutes for a table.  It was a quaint place with warm-colored light fixtures.  The wooden booths and tables tightly filled up the little space.  We enjoyed the complementary white wine and crab cake appetizer.  We found the spicy snapper entree unremarkable.

--Crabcake appetizer $20: 2 flat and round crabcake, minimal filler, rich and delicious, a bit too much mayo.  9/10

--Spicy snapper entree with fries and clam chowder $20: tasty fries and clam chowder 9/10.  Flavor-lacking grilled snapper that needed 2 drops of lemon juice to neutralize and tenderize, a pinch of salt and pepper to coat and flavor.  Maybe it was not fully defrosted before the grilling process.  Maybe it was not marinated or sufficiently flavored before the grilling process.  7/10

We did not try the 2 dishes that our waitress suggested: halibut entree and another entree that I forgot.  We may come back to try her recommended dishes next time.
author: G D.

description:
I'll start off by stating the obvious: Free wine. At any other restaurant in the world you hope there is no line, but here... the longer the line the more free wine. Genius. 

For the food itself, we got the crab cakes for an appetizer as various other reviews suggested. They were amazing. Definitely the best I have had in quite some time. They come with a remoulade sauce or something, but really they don't need it. Every main course comes with three options for a side. We both got potatoes and they were what you would expect out of a red potato. I think it is pretty smart to have only these basic (always good) sides as it lets the cooks focus on each order of seafood that comes in. 
My wife got the Spicy Snapper with a side salad. I was a bit envious honestly. It was one of the cheaper items, but oh so good. The Cajun spices were perfect, not heavy handed and it was cooked perfectly. The Shrimp Louie dressing was soooo good. Tangy and simple.
I got the Abalone because I had never had it before. It was the most expensive item and the server (to his wonderful credit) made sure I knew I was about to pay a lot for a relatively small portion of food. It was delicious, and I am glad to have tried it, but when we go back I will be looking forward to getting a cheaper item that is equally delicious with a bigger portion. I gotta emphasize though, it was so tender and good. Fans of abalone will not be disappointed at all. They clearly put effort into this one.

The service was perfect. Everyone seems so genuine. No on is trying to sell to you, they know their shit, and they are very helpful and attentive. The host is on top of his game with the free wine. He even went outside to make sure anyone in the cold had some too. The beer selection was a bit lacking, but they got a few locals. I am not a big fan of wine, but my wife loved their selection and the Chardonnay she got.
author: Cahde H.

description:
Probably the best seafood restaurant in SF! 

Overall the experience was positive. Complementary wine, tasty seafood, moderately priced wine, with seafood salad or clam chowder to boot? What more could you ask for? I went with a big party and our food was all good, service was attentive and food arrived in a timely matter. Expensive, yes, but pretty reasonable for a "seafood" restaurant. Definitely coming back!
author: Justin L.

description:
It's off the beaten path for tourists, which perhaps is why it has kept it's uniqueness all those years, and is a place most definitely worth a visit. 

Even though it's located in the foggiest and coldest part of town (the outer Richmond) there always seems to be a line. Parking is difficult in that area, especially at night, but it's really worth circling the block a few times to find a spot for your wheels. 
To make it fun, the restaurant supplies free wine to those in the line. Not the best wine, but definitely makes the wait tolerable. 

The food is simple and delicious. I have been at Pacific Cafe many times, tried many items, and have never been disappointed. I wish I could recommend a specific dish, but I will be doing a disservice by suggesting that one dish is better than others. 

This place is great for good food with a small group of friends. Any party of more than 4 people is a challenge (even though they will make accommodations.) It's not a romantic place per se, unless you like 70's woodhouse decor. But the dated decore somehow works with the place, and adds to the overall atmosphere of a neighborhood gem that has been successfully serving great food for a few decades. 

BTW - the men's restroom is a trip - I find myself spending more time there than I should, just looking at old photos of San Francisco. 

Highly recommended!
author: O Z.

description:
Attended Fleet Week and was taken to this seafood restaurant by a friend that has been coming to this place since the first day it opened in 1974! We got there for the first seating which starts at 5PM...that means we got there a little after 4PM. Within a few minutes, there were a half dozen others now waiting. By the time they started seating everyone, there were at least 20 people waiting to be seated. Visit their web page at www.pacificcafesf.com to see a picture of people waiting outside for the first seating. This is a small place with only 15 or 16 tables (some tables only for two). About 15 minutes before we were seated, they indeed served us free wine while we waited.

They provide sourdough bread while you wait for your meal. I ordered the Petrale Sole with rice. My meal was very, very tasty. My friends ordered the Parmesan crusted Halibut...who gave me a taste...bingo, another great tasting prep. They also tried a shrimp louie...I didn't taste it, but it looked good. The serving sizes were generous and commensurate with the price you're going to pay. That being said, even though you're on the outskirts of the downtown San Francisco area, you're still in SanFran...so prices are moderate. But again, the portion size is large and hearty. For me, it was too good not to finish my plate...however, a couple of my friends took some of their dinner home - doggie style! I like eating seafood and my meal was definitely one of the best I've ever had. Next time I'm in this area, I'll definitely return. If anyone is just visiting from somewhere far away...and don't think they'll be back in a very long time, I strongly suggest you have one of your dinner nights here. You'll be glad you did. Yeah, I'm just a random reviewer...don't believe me, then consider this...they were considered one of the "2013 Best of San Francisco" restaurants. Sorry, they only do dinner and don't take reservations.
author: Terry K.

description:
When my parents were younger, they used to shut this place down on weekends when they lived in The City. And during my last trip home to visit the fam, they decided to take me on a journey to their old San Francisco favorites. After years of them reminiscing about this spot, I now understand why they used to be regulars. 

Pacific Café embodies San Francisco charm. Nestled on the corner of Geary Blvd., this tiny café is full of quirks. Fun pictures on the walls, antiquey brown booth seating and old signage out front. It's very unassuming and can get lost in the lurking fog and maze of up and down, topsy turvy streets that make up The City. But once you visit, you'll never forget it. This place is highly popular. Everyone wants a bite of their authentic San Francisco seafood.  

As a result of its popularity, the waiting area is crowded. The restaurant itself is teeny tiny and the supply of tables does not match the demand. No reservations are accepted, and there are usually more people in the waiting area than those actually eating. My recommendation is to get there a little before they open at 5pm because the early birds will beat you to it and you'll end up waiting for over an hour, especially since those early birds linger at their tables.

I loved the complimentary wine they served while we were waiting. Even though the quality of the wine is close to that of a box of Franzia, I still loved it because it added to the overall experience. It also gets everyone in the waiting area talking, laughing and enjoying themselves... just enough to where the wait doesn't seem to be AS bothersome (even when the wait listed crowd spills into the street out front).

Finally upon being seated at a table I was ready for my feast from the sea, and this feast did not disappoint. I ordered the ahi tuna and it was cooked to perfection - tender on the inside and accompanied by a wasabi glaze. Among my family, they ordered the salmon, shrimp and petrale sole. The shrimp were huge, succulent and swimming in a delicious buttery scampi sauce. The salmon and the petrale sole looked exceptional as well, and both were accompanied by sauces that brought out the natural favor of the fish - or so I was told. 

Some of the menu is written up on chalkboards above the kitchen, and there are always new specials - that's how you know it's a fresh catch. This place will charm you to the core with its quaintness. I left feeling happy, full and nostalgic.
author: Lindsey Q.

description:
Pacific Cafe is one of the best spots I have been to in San Francisco. Their food is amazing, as well as the customer service. For those who want to avoid waiting an hour in line, get to the restaurant before they open. The seating is decided upon a first come first served. I arrived at 4:30 and was still the 8th party in line. The wait is worth it (Pacific Cafe provides free wine while you wait, warding off the San Francisco chilly air and any bad moods from waiting in line). 

As for the food, my favorite was the Parmesan halibut. Amazing. It gets a bit heavy but the flavor is to die for.
author: Alyssa P.

description:
I was visiting friends who live in the neighborhood, and this is one of their local favorites.  I'm glad that we came, because the atmosphere was fun and charming but still classy.  It was perfect for the first dinner of my vacation (also, I was turning 30 at the stroke of midnight...booo).

More importantly, how can you beat free cheap white wine while you wait?  What a brilliant idea!

I'm sure that the menu changes periodically, but I had a pretty good buttered swordfish and some so-so seafood chowder.  And vast quantities of bread, which curiously ended up being the best sourdough that I tasted on the entire trip.
author: David R.

description:
Pacific Cafe, you are my absolute favorite seafood restaurant in San Francisco. I love it when a friend suggest seafood because you are the first place I think of! 

I typically get the Parmesan Halibut. Wonderfully cooked and prepared dish with either red potatoes or rice.

This last time I had the fried scallops with fries. Both items were perfectly cooked. Absolutely perfect. 

I do think the complimentary glasses of wine are a nice touch, but the wine is a bit crap. But, who cares! The food is fantastic! 

I highly recommend this place to anyone looking for a wholesome, filling and satisfying meal.
author: Michael M.

description:
There is a distinctive charm to Pacific Cafe that can only be found in an old San Francisco fish house.  It is true that you are provided with complimentary wine as you wait (even if you are outside) and they pour with a heavy hand.  Yes, you will probably have to wait for a table, but under these circumstances, why complain?

The food is phenomenal, starting with the ubiquitous sourdough bread and Pacific Cafe's delectable Shrimp Louie.  Amongst the four of us, we shared the crab cakes (tons of crab, little filler), fried scallops (great way to prepare scallops), spicy snapper, and Parmesan crusted petrale sole. I give this place five starts because  I would order each one of these dishes again.

There's not much to add to what has already been said here.  This is an old school restaurant that excels at serving fresh, exquisitely prepared seafood.  That they care enough to provide gratis wine as you wait for a table is evidence to me that Pacific Cafe values your patronage.
author: Justin M.

description:
I've seen this restaurant at least 20 years back when my folks owned a restaurant in the RIchmond district. Even then, I would see a small group of people huddling outside on a cold night, which is a frequent occurrence out there.

After all these years, I finally came here to chow down and walked away satisfied although I'm not sure if I would rush back here for a meal. It was raining that night so the crowd wasn't there since we were seated within 5 minutes around 7:15PM. Here are my highlights and thoughts

- Complimentary glass of white wine while you waited

- Crab cakes appetizer were fantastic. I'm usually very weary of ordering them from restaurants since they're typically dry but these were very nicely done. It's not cheap, $10 for 1 or $18 for 2.  I estimate they are probably around 4" to 4.25" in diameter

- Friendly service, our server was attentive without seeming to lurk over our meal

- I ordered the Filet of Sole Newburg  with fries which was decent but made a mistake. This dish is stuffed with crab and topped with a cream sauce. I just had the crab cakes so the flavor is all too similar and too heavy. I had choice between this and a Grilled Tuna with wasabi sauce... although I asked the server for recommendation, all she mentioned was they are too completely contrasting dishes. If she would have kept in mind that I ordered the crab cakes, then she could have mentioned the similarities and warned me. The fish wasn't bad but is definitely not memorable. Fries were house cut thick style and were not bad and not soggy or overly salted.

- My girlfriend ordered fried scallops with small red potatoes. The scallops were very fresh and tasted sweet. Since they are just lightly fried, there isn't flavoring from heavy sauces which is fine by me. The potatoes were just served as whole pieces. I wish they would have done something with the potatoes such as lightly grill them or add some herbs/seasoning. Just seemed a bit lazy to serve plain boiled potatoes.

- I do like the place, it's cozy and the booths offer some privacy. It's a nice place for a date night or just hang out with some friends enjoying drinks.

I can honestly say I've had better seafood, but from what I sampled that night, the food is fresh which is important when eating seafood. Most of the dishes seemed to be grilled in some way so tailor expectations on the flavor if there is no sauce that is cooked with the seafood.
author: Andrew L.

description: Awesome place for seafood!! I got the parmesan halibut and I must say YUMMY!. Being served free wine while you wait is a fantastic thing too but the only downside is the long wait.
author: Jeffrey P.

description:
Okay, here's my guide for eating at the Pacific Cafe:

1.  Get there BEFORE they open, maybe even considerably before--I'm not kidding.  They don't have a parking lot, and available parking is meager in that neighborhood.  You may have to park up to two blocks away.

2.  Even when getting there before they open, there will be a line outside the door.  Get a place in that line and keep it--they do not take reservations.  Plus, make sure YOUR WHOLE PARTY is with you, because they will not seat you if you are waiting for others to arrive.

3.  If the place fills up before you are seated, then you are going to have to wait for a vacancy to open up.  In the meantime you get free wine while you sit down and look at scrapbooks and restaurant decor.  You won't be the only ones waiting, and the customers just keep coming in.

4.  Once you are seated, get ready for some incredible seafood and fantastic service.  I recommend the deep fried prawns.  The place can be a hassle to get into, but it's all worth the trouble in the end.  It's an awesome place that I recommend again and again to my friends.
author: Matthew D.

description:
My sister live in Maryland, and I've found Its hard to get good crab cakes in San Francisco, but Pacific delivers.

Great fish, good prices, the only thing not to love is the line out the door!

Lots of parking.  Check their hours before you go!
author: Kelly D.

description:
At 6pm, a man in the corner stood up and tapped a fork to his wine glass to get the restaurant's attention. We grew silent and turned to him.

"Everyone, it's 6pm, so let's all toast to The Rapture!"

A lady in the corner: "We're all sinners!"

Laughter and a round of applause for ourselves.
author: Stacy J.

description: SO good! Free wine while you wait. Basic preparations on their food, but done damn well. I had the grilled scallops, and it was a large portion. Perfectly cooked. Rice was good. Bread on the table was killer.
author: Amy M.

description:
Here we have another favorite hangout from the olden days.  No Long Islands poured here, but as you might have heard by now, everyone waiting for a table is offered a complimentary glass of wine.

And that's just the beginning of what is always a pleasant dining experience.  You'll start with a bottomless basket of Boudin (sourdough, and if it's not Boudin, pardon my alliterative license).

The menu offers a list of time-tested favorites, and a chalkboard hanging on the wall announces the nightly specials, whose prices are not dramatically different from those on the menu.

With a dinner you'll be offered a choice of salads or  soups.  On the Friday evening I attended, one of the soup choices was, oddly enough, clam chowder, which the waiter recommended over a salmon bisque, and it had a thinner-than-usual consistency (thanks for holding the flour and milk) but plenty of clams and flavor.

One of the specials was ahi tuna, which I chose with well-done French fries as the side, fried just right, always a heartwarming aspect of a satisfying meal.

Dessert choices included coconut ice cream and mango sherbet, of which I chose the former.  Good though it was, and as much as I like coconut, I'd really like to try mango sherbet next time, if it's still on the chalkboard.

This place has been around for about 40 years, and it might give the impression of being frozen in time.  But, oh, what a time.
author: Friscoco C.

description:
(+) Free glass of wine upon entry
(+) Scallops are excellent
(+) Bread is great

(-) Often a slight wait, but that con is mitigated by the wine!
author: Eric H.

description: Yum! My boyfriend and I came here for New Year's Eve and it was fabulous! They don't take reservations so expect to wait... BUT YOU GET FREE WINE. The wait was about 45 minutes not too bad being it was New Year's Eve! I had salmon and fried prawns which was amazing (making my mouth water just thinking about it) and my boyfriend got an awesome New York streak grilled to perfection. Our waitress was super nice, a little Irish lady, helped us with any questions. We live literally across the street and had always wanted to go here but if you aren't used to the area parking can be tricky, just a heads up!
author: Lindsey M.

description:
FINALLY got ourselves over to Pacific Cafe.

Had a great dinner on Friday at 8pm. The looong wait was *spectacular* (lol) as we sipped and sipped on the complimentary wine. In fact, by the time we were seated, we didn't "need" to order drinks, a big savings, particularly for us.

Nice, fresh, hearty sourdough bread loaf to start. I had the combo with salmon and baked prawns ... hubby had the Ahi Tuna and wasabi sauce. We both had a cup of the clam chowder. Very good and enjoyable dishes. The service was obviously well tuned after all these years. They were friendly and prompt at every point.

Look forward to going back.
author: Kimbalee W.

description: What can I say.the food is amazing ,but the waitress is far from curtious. Showed up to put name on registry,advised them we were waiting for 1 more person to come.within minutes was seated by a great guy that works there (even though our friend didn't show up yet. At that point we were completely ignored by waitress even though I was trying to get her attention every time she walked by. She finally decided to grace us with her moment of undivided attitude(oops,I mean attention, only to kick us out of our table when I told her  my daughter and I would like to order some food,stating that "we don't seat incomplete parties""?????!!!incomplete or not,you did,,.we're hungry,,,and all we want to do is eat...(not only did she kick us off the table ,but she basically announce it to the whole world while doing so!!horified at what just happened,my daughter and I were braught to the waiting area only to be reseated at the same table literally 30 seconds later and unfortunately being waited on by the same unpleasant at best waitress who absolutely ruins the whole get to go out to dinner moment we were sharing as a family that evening.food good,waitress -a buzz kill.
author: rick s.

description:
Arrived at 530 and had a 30 minute wait with a squirming infant.Yet everyone in line was so gracious and fun, we made friends just  drinking the free wine!  When we finally sat down, the food was excellent.  Scallops and spicy snapper were perfect.  Even the sourdough and butter were delish.

This is very good quality fresh food. it is a simple presentation, comfortable intimate  and  professional waitstaff. There were no put on airs or looking down at you for not choosing a spendy bottle of wine.

This place is a new favorite.  I will bring my parents here or other  couple when in from out of town.  Perfect place to have a satisfying meal with the ability to hear each other and have a conversation and catch up.  Although, this is not a place to lounge for hours. Probably not the place to bring a group of more than 6.
author: maia j.

description:
Went here after doing a quick Yelp search of restaurants in the area.  GLAD WE CAME!  

My mom and i spent a day in the city and wanted something delicious, filling and decently priced.  

I had the Filet of Sole Newburg, and this is the first time i've ever had it...OMG it was DIVINE!  Not overbearing or super rich, but definately not bland.  The crab stuffed in the Sole was excellent.  Had it with two steamed red potatos on the side, (Suggestion:  Dip the Potatoes in the Newburg Sauce!)
My mom had the Halibut Parmesan and she said it was one of the best she has ever had.  I tried a bite, and it was very light, very flavorful, but not over cooked, or oily or anything.  They gave tartar sauce with it, and you dont even need it.  That is how good their halibut is.  

We luckily got there just before the big dinner rush started, so we were seated promptly, and were given free glasses of wine to have while waiting.  

Ambiance is nice in general decor.  A bit dark for my personal liking, and when it gets busy it gets fairly loud and warm inside.  But the food makes up for that.
Waiter/Waitresses were amazing, very gracious and made sure we were happy, without being annoying (i dont think much of waiters who ask you how everything is every minute...).

For the two of us, the total came out to just over $50.  A little pricey, but worth it.
Will i come back here?  Definately!
Will i reccomend it to friends and family?  Definately!
author: Debi R.

description: I would love to give this place four stars but its a tad expensive for the serving size.  In fact Tadich is comparable but with far bigger serving.  Taste wise, darn good thank you.  Service is very friendly.  Oh by the way, parking is horrendous.
author: Joel M.

description:
I love this place.
It's old school but I like the booths.
Free wine while waiting.
The best seafood salad.
Love, love, love that this is in the Outer Richmond.
Hope it stays around for a long time.
author: Angela K.

description:
I've been here a handful of times over the past eight years and I can honestly say that the quality and service has remained top notch.

Fresh fish!

If you're a seafood lover and you've been sorely disappointed by all the terrible seafood places in San Francisco, you should try this place.

When crabs are in season, you can't go wrong with their crab cocktail.
author: Christopher B.

description:
The fist time I went to this neighborhood restaurant in San Francisco I was amazed by the settings it provides. This was 1998. Today, it is still amazes me with such warm feeling of being at home, wonderful food, and friendly atmosphere.
Although it is far from where I am living, it worthy visiting it even if it is farther.
author: Mehran M.

description:
5 STARS ALL THE WAY AROUND!!!

Actually, I'd give it 4.5 stars only because you can't call ahead to make reservations and even if you arrive right when they open it still takes 30-45 minutes to get a table. But since there is no half-star rating they def deserve 5 instead of 4. 

Fish is perfectly cooked and seasoned
Tarter sauce is angelic
Potatoes are soft yet firm
FREE WINE as you wait for your table to be ready
FREE WINE (oops, I already said that)

Make sure you try this place out! And get there early because parking is a bear and it can be colder than a polar bear's toe nails outside.
author: Mike B.

description:
Consistently a good choice for fresh, simple seafood...
All the salads are GREAT... as is the crabcake.  The oysters are too big and come from a jar - NOT on the halfshell.  Bummer.
However, the fries are AWFUL.  I dunno - there is something perfect about thin. long cripsy fries with fish - whether fried, broiled or steamed.  It is so so so easy to make a good fry - why not do it?  Also, gets too warm and by the end of the meail, downright uncomfortable.
author: Marisa D.

description:
The clam chowder and salmon bisque are excellent. The chowder is a complex mixture of clams, potatoes, and herbs--with a hint of lemon, and enough pepper to leave your mouth feeling pleasantly warm for several minutes after you've scraped up and swallowed that last delicious spoonful. 

The salmon bisque is rich and velvety. Yeah, salmony, too. I only had one bite; not much more to say other than I'll gladly have it for my soup next time. 

The salmon and shrimp are very good, though some people might find them heavy on the butter. I was initially impressed by my dish, the petrale sole dore with mushrooms and capers. (Dore: "The sole is sautéed in butter after applying a light egg batter, and finished with an easy lemon caper sauce.") I've decided that while I do like the dish, and while it is done well here, there might be room for improvement. The sole dore lacked the depth of the two soups; that might reflect the quality of the mushrooms, which tasted like standard bland Safeway fare. 

Really, it's a good dish, well worth having. It just suffers a bit by comparison with a truly excellent pair of soups.
author: Nat C.

description:
I've been here many times and for some reason I have neglected to review it until now. 

Lets start at the very beginning. The decor and ambiance suggest this is a well established restaurant that doesn't need custom art installations to keep the throngs of people lining up at the door. The service is friendly and laid-back but every detail is seen to from the glass of wine while you wait for your table to the way they seem to know exactly when you're hoping for your next drink. 

The menu is fairly simple with a list of fresh daily specials. Most come with salad or soup and a variety of potato and rice options. The portions are enormous - I take half of my meal to go. 

I really love the crab cakes. They are fresh, seem to be almost all crab (hardly any filler of any sort) and are fried to a crispy crunchy perfect crust on the outside. We have tried to replicate this at home but with little success. 

Price range: I'd say this is moderate and appropriate. For a main dish and a drink expect $30-$35 before tip.
author: Stacey C.

description: Crab diablo just blew my mind
author: Gretchen S.

description: My friend wanted to show me her favourite restaurant where she used to enjoy great food and great times. What a disappointment. The shrimp appetiser was soggy and presented as a clump. The Ahi tuna had no seasoning and the two redskin potatoes, which should have been smaller and seasoned, rolled around the bare plate, tasteless, unappetising. The whole experience of tasteless dining at what had once been one of her favorite go-to places suggests that the restaurant had better recover its former winning formula.
author: David A.

description:
So one day while we were in SF (well, we're up in SF almost every weekend), the BF took me here for dinner knowing how much I love seafood. 

We got there about 5:30pm and the restaurant was totally full. But they gave us a glass of their house wine to sip on while we waited. Free wine? Bonus points!

Once a table opened up for us, we settled down to peruse the menu. Everything looked good. I couldn't decide and ended up getting the tilapia. It was amazing!! I had some of the BF's fish to savor over. We shared a bottle of wine (which I drank most of) and had a wonderful evening. 

The food there is just straightforward without any fuss. The service is wonderful since our server was always smiling at us and I had free refills of the house wine (I tried both the red and white wines) during our wait. 

Just be forewarned about parking. It's fairly hard but if you're persistent, this is a great spot to have a fantastic seafood dinner.
author: Julia W.

description: Pacific Cafe is all and more.  Cute little place in a residential area.  Parking was easy. Wine when you walk in while you are waiting. Food was excellent. Waitstaff were great too. I totally recommend.
author: June W.

description:
There's nothing like walking along the coast on New Year's Eve, watching the wispy light of the old year fade away over the horizon, letting the sea breeze wash the Christmas insanity out of your mind as you prepare for National Forget Your Family Exists Month (aka January).  And it's even better if you can warm yourself up afterward with a hearty seafood dinner.

Enter Pacific Cafe, just a short stroll from the Lands End Trail.  I've never heard anyone mention it before, but seeing as they open at 5 and every booth in the exceptionally cozy interior is full by 5:01, I think we have to add this to the ranks of high-demand, low-capacity seafood cult classics a la Swan's Oyster Depot or the Marina's Pacific Catch, albeit a better-kept secret than most.

We ended up waiting an hour for a table, which would normally dock them a star, but when you can sit on a sidewalk bench with a glass of free chablis, the minutes just seem to float on by.  Nor do I freely hand out 5 stars at this price point ($20+ for most dishes).  But the portions on both the Halibut Parmesan and Fillet of Sole Newburg were enormous, and between the former's tub of irresistible tartar sauce and the latter's super-rich cream sauce, we couldn't even finish everything (fortunately they're used to this, and are quick to offer you a compostable take-home box).  And did I mention it was all damn tasty? (Although the clam chowder is really no match for the crab bisque).  In short, I think I've finally found the perfect indie-yet-unpretentious spot for seafood, and it even feels like you get your money's worth.

PS: once again a restaurant with "Pacific" in the name has a decor that strikes me as remarkably Seattlesque (see also Moki's Pacific Grill).
author: Wes M.

description: Come early and drink free wine while you wait a half hour for your table... try the salmon bisque and make your girlfriend order the pan-seared scallops
author: Erik A.

description: Wow! Simple and incredible food!! It's a wonderful time when you can get such a great meal with quality ingredients!! If you're looking for seafood, this is the place to check out. I've only rolled in late night, but have been told that if you get there early and have to wait in line outside, the bring you free house wine to fight off the wind chill!! Check them out. You'll be back for more!!!
author: Michael H.

description:
After passing this establishment near our neighborhood many times, we finally took the occasion on a very foggy weekday evening to try out Pacific Cafe in hopes of not having a long wait. As promised, a nice glass of white wine was offered to pass the 15 minutes or so we waited for our table.  Consistent with many other reviews, the ambiance and warmth of this neighborhood cafe was readily apparent creating greater anticipation for a great meal ahead.

Using recommendations from other Yelp reviewers, we ordered the parmesan-crusted halibut and petrale sole. The salads were a nice accompaniment to the meal.  However there was a long wait between our salad and the entree.  When our meals arrived, they were less than what we expected.  My crusted halibut had the consistency of being fried akin to fish and chips with the fish was anything but flaky as another reviewer reported.  My wife's sole was again quite basic with a overabundance of sauteed mushrooms and capers that smothered the central element of the meal.  We both ate some of our fish but we both left portions to the side because it didn't appeal to us.  

The $25-30 price of the entrees exceeded the quality of the seafood dishes.  There are many better values to be found in the city.

Maybe we hit this place on a bad night with a temporary chef, but it is unlikely that we'll be frequenting this cute neighborhood eatery again anytime soon.
author: Brent V.

description:
I remember it was very distinctly decorated with a seafood theme. I thought it would be more casual, you know, with the wait staff in regular clothes and tennis shoes but I was surprised to see that they were dressed rather presentably well, in formal black and white (with a vest too!)  They have table clothes, use cloth napkins and not paper napkins! I felt it somehow didn't match up with the decor, but I'm not complaining, that just took me by surprise!

I used to live in the area and I always walked by but never got a chance to eat there because, frankly, the exterior wasn't inviting to me.  It looked really old and it wasn't flashy (to catch my eye) in the least bit; a very modest exterior with a classic wooden sign.  I guess here's another example of why you shouldn't judge a book by its cover, so to speak.   I'm glad my boyfriend took me here because I had a generally good experience.  

It's a very small place so expect to hear your neighbor's conversation, or perhaps the table next to mine was just extra loud. hahah..it's funny because I felt like I shouldn't be hearing a lot of their discussion yet I know all about their issues by the time dinner was over. It wasn't my fault they were basically announcing their affairs to the world! 

Anyway, they have pretty fresh fish and they know the origin of where all their fish come from (for those wary of the difference).  You'd be surprised some restaurants don't know or care!  The food was decent and the service was nice enough.  I like their variety of seafood and the nice neighborhood feel. 
 I'd say, it's a darn nice place to dine!
author: Tu L.

description: Nice cozy little seafood restaurant on Geary . Good, expedient service at the door and at the table. I had the lobster bisque soup and trout and g/f had clam chowder and snapper. Very good tasting seafood. I really like this place. Mature atmosphere.
author: B W.

description:
This place is awesome.  Hands down this restaurant is at the top of the list for my wife and me.  From the free wine while you wait to the ambiance of the local small-restaurant feel--and of course and the food is addicting--all make this place an SF treasure.  I like to order the prawns scampi style with a starter of the clam chowder.  

The prawns with the butter sauce, some diced tomatoes, and seasonings with a little lemon and a side of rice are incredible.  And of course, you can't forget the sourdough bread you get before your meal.  We love this place....
author: J M.

description:
This is a really cute, pretty place, with an amazing atmosphere and comfortable decor.  It's been open since the 1970s, and all the furniture is as stately as that'd imply.  The place has a history and it's not afraid to tell you.  The patrons are generally a bit older and perhaps more conservative, at the table next to us was a Russian Orthodox priest in full regalia, with a napkin precariously tucked in to avoid having his habit stained.  

The service, as everyone else noted, is exceptional.  There is wine or beer as you're waiting in line, for as long as you're there, and the serving staff brings you more attentively.  They were also super helpful regarding helping us choose, and then later, when my sand dabs arrived, on explaining to how to eat them.  

Unfortunately, the food was nothing particularly exceptional.  My Sand Dabs were plentiful but pretty flavorless, the bread was a bit stale, and Julia and Robert felt meh about their dishes too.  Definitely not worth the $30 we paid per.  So, in conclusion, if you're interested in a wonderful welcoming atmosphere and ambiance, or just want to drink without paying for it, come here.  Otherwise, check out somewhere else for your American style seafood goodness.
author: Leon K.

description:
I love their fresh seafood and the first time I went there I tried their signature fish baked in newspaper.   YUMMY!  And the staff are great.  The free wine really adds nice touch.

The minus one star is only for the steamed mussels I had during my last visit.  It was okay but I wish it had more taste.

All in all.  I would come back often.
author: Toi D.

description:
So when we were recommended to go here, we were told that we may have to wait around 1-2 hours to get a table. But it was worth it. And there is free wine. YES.....FREE WINE! No-body cares how long they have to wait as long as the wine is flowing. The people waiting along with us (tiny area, very cosy) were LOVELY - they helped us put our name down for a table (you have to write it on their board) and kept us in conversation - locals and tourists alike!
We waited around 90 minutes for a table, and it flew by!
The food - well, what can I say? We had the salmon and the  sand dab. It was INCREDIBLE!!!! Seriously! The waitress was so helpful and and attentive, and to be perfectly honest, I would have waited 90 minutes with no wine for the quality of food we had. Seriously!!
author: Sofia B.

description:
Ditto Tim V.'s review.  This place is very old school and you *always* wait for a table so there is ample time to suck down the vino. 

I have many fond memories of going there with my two favorite Uncles.  Invariably, one Uncle and I will get pretty close to soused on the free wine while we wait - then the smack talk starts.  The other Uncle sips coffee and laughs at our sorry asses.  Good times my friend, good times. 

Don't fill up on the delicious sourdough bread though- it's good but you'll need room for some tasty fishes. Recommend the parmesan crusted halibut and the crab louie when in season.  Dressing on the side please!
author: Julienne G.

description:
I love this place.
First, the atmosphere: This place is totally non-pretentious. Nice, mixed crowd.
They give you free wine(!) while you wait for your table. 
The service is impeccable. The servers know just when to show up and refill etc.
The food:
The Halibut Parmesan is to die for.
The Calamari in the Calamari Vinaigrette was perfectly cooked, maybe a little too heavy on the sauce, but I'm not complaining.
I had the Crab Cocktail. There was a generous portion of fresh, briny Dungeness there.
The side dishes are a little hit-or-miss. The Roasted Potatoes are really just steamed potatoes. The fries are randomly either great or soggy. The rice pilaf is the safe choice.
author: R W.

description:
I guess we had major parking karma on Thursday night because we got a park just across the street!  Wait not too long either.  As usual we had the complimentary glass of white wine when we arrived which is a lovely touch.  We had a great table and I had the salmon which was wonderful and my husband had the prawn and salmon combo.  We were very happy with our choices and the salad was fresh.  We have come here many times and I would say the main draw back would be the lack of parking.  The no reservation policy can be a pain but it seems to work out and the free wine helps!!

Service is always very pleasant.
author: Vicki B.

description:
After visiting the fabulous "Cartier in America" at the de Young Legion of Honor Museum, we had dinner here.  It was around 4:30 PM and there was already a line waiting to get in. Sure enough, they serve you a free glass of white wine to help shorten your wait. 

This is a neighborhood seafood restaurant, unpretentious with reasonable prices.

We had the Turbot baked in Parchment, which has this cream and crab sauce lurking inside this paper bag, which the waiter cuts open for you with scissors. The Scallops were excellent! We had to wait a while for our dinners, but we munched on salads, and I had the Salmon Bisque, which had a little "kick" to it. 

All in all, a pretty good place and even better if you happen to be in the area.
author: Ronald R.

description:
Yay!  I'm a fan!  No really, I'm a fan!  They give you free white wine while you wait because you most likely will.  It's a great little neighborhood restaurant and I hope it stays that way.  The crowd is an overflow from Sea Cliff and California street, its also older and more casual, no pretension here.  It's small but the booth seating adds a ton of privacy, great for dates, great for dinner with friends.  The decor has a New England charm.  I really enjoy all the wood.  It is pricey, which is why it doesn't get five stars.  

This is a true seafood joint.  If you don't like fish don't come here because that's all they are serving.  With the exception of shrimp and sometimes clams.  My favorite point in the meal is the salad and I never look forward to salad.  It's romaine lettuce with bay shrimp on top and Russian dressing.  The portions of fish as also more than adequate.  I brought my mother here and as an avid fish eater she was surprised by how large the serving was.  Don't think Claim Jumpers large but for fish it was big.

If you are in the Outer Richmond this is a must, if you like seafood and don't want to hit up the more touristy places come here.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Kristin Marie S.

description:
A cute restaurant out in the foggy far reaches of the Richmond.

I've been here a few times in the past, and it has always been an enjoyable, comforting experience. On this occasion, while still having an enjoyable evening, I was underwhelmed by the food. 

The place was crowded at 8:30 on a Saturday evening - no room in the foyer area, people waiting on the sidewalk outside. Not a problem, as the host comes out very regularly to those waiting with complimentary glasses (and refills!) of house wine. A very nice touch! Eventually, we were seated, after a wait of about  45 minutes.

The interior of the restaurant is quaint and comfortable - wood-paneled booths and various fish images & other bric-a-brac on the walls all around. There is a menu consisting of (mainly) fish and seafood dishes, and an additional set of specials on blackboards around the restaurant. The staff are friendly in an old-school no-fuss kind of way. Our waiter patiently went through the details of all the specials with us and assured me that the steak dish was good (even though fish was their specialty!) Despite this, I went for the "spicy" snapper, and started with the salmon bisque. (The entrees come with soup or salad making the cost of the meal more reasonable than it first appears when you see the menu.) My friend got the clam chowder, followed by the "combo" of salmon steak and fried shrimp. The combo turned out to be a success - delicious big, breaded shrimp, and fairly tasty salmon. And the appetizer soups were excellent - perfect for the chill, foggy Outer Richmond evening. My snapper, however, was disappointing - bland fish and fries, no accompanying vegetables - a let-down.

Nevertheless, I feel I should be generous in my review. The food is somewhat hit-and-miss, depending on what you choose. All-in-all, however, this is a great place for a different San Francisco restaurant experience.
author: donal c.

description:
This is where you go when you want good seafood, to go back to the days when you feathered your hair, or to take your relatives from Colorado somewhere that's not too "kooky." 

This place is even good for your Uncle Jim, who only eats out in the City so he can give his rant against yuppie trendsheep and art food.

You get great service. Table service is attentive and consistent. Sidewalk service (while you wait, and wait) comes with free wine and free refills.

The menu has good choices (scallops, seared ahi, bay shrimp salad) along with some fabulous dishes (parmesan-crusted halibut, crab bisque, crab cakes). 

Other things you must know:

To beat the crowd, get there at first seating (5:30). No free wine.

For the best crowd, get there at 6:30-7. You could wait an hour but so what, you're drinking free wine and schmoozing with everyone else who's waiting. 

Mixed crowd from 20's through bluehair.

Four stars for food, service, and that 1970's chic.
author: D A.

description:
Pacific Café is constantly good! 

It was actually the first place that my fiancé' took me too for dinner. It was really cute as I had never been and well, we can see that it turned out well and we eventually went on more dates and now we are getting married! All because of Pacific Café! Ok, maybe not but really the food is good and I'm a seafood snob. Nothing fancy pants just greatly prepared with simple ingredients and FRESH good quality seafood. 

They offer free wine if you have to wait for a table. The service is friendly and fast and the specials are always good. Every dish comes with a soup or salad (none of this ala carte stuff). 

Meal Highlights: 

Halibut parmesan - WOW the boom!
Oyster cocktail - Another wow!
Spicy red snapper - so fresh and juicy

Noteworthy or useless information from me: It's not the hipster hangout and you can't walk to a night club from it. You like won't find marina moguls here, nor will you spot Hayes hipness. But it's been there for over 35 years!
author: Kristina A.

description:
We've been coming here for about 15 years now, not because it's gourmet cuisine but more for what we'd consider a  comfortable dinner. Sure there's better seafood places but this place is pretty laid back and homey. Beginning with free cheap wine is all part of the experience. The homemade tartar sauce is good spread all over the warm sourdough bread. All the meals are good, not great. I particularly like the Ahi with Wasabi when on the menu. As Genevieve mentioned, there is a fish served in Parchment that is on the regular menu that is very good.

When you want to dine in your jeans in a cozy neighborhood haunt, this is it!
author: Suzy S.

description:
This was my 2nd or 3rd time here last night and my gf and I strolled in around 6pm for an early dinner. As we guessed, the place was filled with seniors and a handful of younger folks. 

The menu is pretty simple, pick an entree and you get a choice of soup or salad and  rice, red potatoes or French fries.  Don't forget to look up at the board for specials. It is more extensive then their printed menu. I got the  Petrole Sole and Oh boy was it greasy!!  The butter it was cooked in overwhelmed the fish completely. I ate half of the fries and barely made it through one of the two sole fillets. The shrimp Louie salad was ok. I picked out the shrimp pieces and tried to eat the romaine leaves that weren't drenched in dressing. Half of the salad was untouched. The bread was also  very good. It was waiting for us at the table and covered with a towel, but to our disappointment it was cold. We wondered if they got the bread from Azemendi bakery and joked around that it's probably just Boudin bread. We asked the waitress and yes, they do get their bread from Boudin, haha. 

I tried a bite of my gfs dish (Filet of Sole Newburg ), which was baked in a little casserole dish. Omg, they looove butter here. Super rich and almost too rich to eat. She made it through half her fish and pushed it away. Some of it looked raw still but we weren't sure. 

Overall, the glass of complimentary wine upon being seated was nice. We didn't need more after that. There wasn't a wait at 6pm also. The waitress was super nice and cheery. But the food is diner style at best.  They've probably made it this far because its one of the only food options this far out in the Richmond district.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Funny, I've been living 2 blocks from Pacific Cafe for 7 years and just went there for the first time last night.
I passed by countless times thinking "I should try"... well, I should have done so earlier it.

We (girlfriend and I) arrived around 8pm on a Tuesday night. Only 3 people were in line. Bam! A server gives us a free glass of wine. That's already one star right there.
And we wait no more than 5 minutes before being seated. Cool.

We got the fresh oysters (not on the shelf, but whatever), the Salmon plate and Sole Meuniere.
Oyster= delicious, but I think it's always the case when they're fresh.
Salmon= a bit overcooked, but still good
Sole Meuniere=  I am so going back for that!

We also got another glass of wine while dining. That's the only weakness of this place: they're wine list is very basic. All Safeway wines; I wouldn't mind a bit more complex wines that would go better with the food.
Prices were very reasonable for this quality. For 1 appetizer, 2 big plates and 2 wine glasses (on top of the 2 free glasses) we ended up paying $60, a good price considering that we got super fresh fish and we left very full.
