A small minus is the total lack of interest the server had with our table. With us, she was courteous, but kept it to a minimum; she didn't even ask us if everything was ok when we got the food. With her other tables, she was chatting quite a bit.
My theory is that with our 20-something faces, we might not appear like a "good table" in this place with the average customer's age is closer to 45; at least it was that one night.

Oh well, I will go back anyways because the food is good, and 3 minutes walking from my place.
author: Vithiet L.

description: The pacific cafe is a wonderful neighborhood restaurant for us... but a great spot to travel to as well for a fun evening and a delicious seafood dinner.  The restaurant doesn't take reservations - instead, you put your name on a list and then wait inside or outside while drinking free wine and meeting other interesting diners.  We enjoy the waiting almost as much as the great service and excellent seafood!  Try it!
author: Joanne N.

description: Worth the drive to the outer richmond.  We waited nearly an hour for a table and didn't notice thanks to the free white wine while waiting.  Service was fast and prices were very reasonable for portions served.  Everything was good and fresh.  Being lazy, I am a big fan of the giant hill of pre-shelled crab served for the crab cocktail.  Classy!
author: D M.

description:
What is not to love about a place that instead of taking reservations will pour you large glasses of wine. I wish more places did this.
The food was very good. The Crab cakes were awesome, lots of crab meat and cooked perfectly.
The service was great. The food had good flavor and portion size was pretty large for the price.
This is a great neighborhood spot that does food well.
author: Cassandra C.

description:
We dropped by for dinner when the restaurant was celebrating their 36th year anniversary in business. Having passed by this place all the time, we decided to try it out to see why there was always a group of people outside. I agree with most of the previous Yelp reviews in that this restaurant is a cute and cozy place. The service was exceptional and the free wine while you wait was definitely a nice touch. Due to the small capacity of the restaurant, the wait can be really long. If you don't plan on coming here when the doors first open,  make sure you bring a thick jacket to keep you warm. The Richmond fog and drift from the sea will make your knees shake. 

The food was ok but nothing to rave about. We ordered the Calamari appetizer, which wasn't our favorite. For entrees, we had the Rainbow Trout and Salmon and Prawn Combo. Both Trout and Salmon was a little under seasoned. The fried prawns were probably the best item on our table. Overall it was just ok.

The Good: Great service, free wine while you wait
The Bad: Wait is too long, food too simple
author: Yan W.

description:
Reasons why I love this place:

1. Complementary wine while you are waiting for your table. It opens at 5PM and I've witnessed people lining up way before the restaurant opens.

2. Ambiance - All the waiters, servers, and greeters are so friendly. It feels as if you are being served by friends and family. For such a busy restaurant, I don't have to scream across the table to have a conversation. There are so many fun pictures on the walls and the specials are written on a huge chalkboard. I love sitting in their brown antique booths and feeling as though I've walked into a restaurant embellished with San Francisco's charm.

3. Fish - I've tried almost every dish on the menu and they're all perfectly cooked and seasoned very well. Great portions and they're served at the perfect temperature.

4. Clam chowder - The best clam chowder in the West. It's something I always try when dining at a seafood restaurant. I haven't found one to match or beat the clam chowder here.

5. Crab cakes - If you scan the walls carefully, you will see the awards that have been given to Pacific Cafe for their crab cakes. Enough said.

I've always recommended this place to my coworkers and out of town guests who want fresh and authentic seafood in San Francisco. Definitely worth the wait and it's one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. 5 stars all the way!
author: Chau H.

description:
Several friends recommended Pacific Cafe for my birthday - I'm not asking for recommendations from them anymore. 

You will wait for a while for a table and yes they do bring you free white wine but its nothing special. I think they want to kill your taste buds with booze because the food, for the most part, was sub-par. 

Drinks: weak ass selection of wines. Not sure if they let you bring your own with corkage. 

Appetizers: The crab cocktail was overly chilled and did not resemble any of the pics on here. Mostly shredded crab with only a few tiny solid pieces. The cocktail sauce was horrible. No one used it. The caesar salad was weak. The dressing was watery and forgettable. The shrimp louie salad looked gross - I did not taste it. The clam chowder was disgraceful. The bread was the best part of the meal.

Entrees: the grilled halibut was overcooked, ahi tuna was acceptable, and the crab cakes were very good although they had a touch too many chives.

Sides: rice was gross, french fries were inedible, red potatoes came out as 3 boiled plain potatoes. Not cut up, not seasoned, no butter, nada. WTF? Am I in prison? 

Dessert - ordered the chocolate mouse torte b/c it was my birthday. I'm glad they comped it because I ate 2 bites and could not bear anymore. It was so weak. 

Service - efficient but not friendly. 

Bathroom - disgusting. I actually held it and went at the bar we were headed to instead. 

Cost = I didn't pay b/c it was my b-day but I believe our bill was just over $200. Entrees run about $22-26.

I won't go back.

peace, love, and good booze ~ chase
author: Chase S.

description: Best customer service here. The staff here gives you wine while you wait to be seated. Everything about this place is great. The clam chowder here is to die for, and the shrimp louie salad is amazing. Don't forget to check out the board, to see what the specials of the day are.
author: Mars F.

description: Great no-fuss seafood that was an easy bus ride from where we were staying. Our hotel recommended Pacific Cafe for great, but not overpriced seafood and it was a perfect recommendation. This place is an amazing value, you get wine, soup and a side for the price of an entrée. I got the salmon bisque, which was hot, creamy and full of big, delicious chunks of salmon. The fish entrée was also very good and very fresh. Portions were huge, even by my Midwest standards, and the service was excellent. This is a great place if you want good, fresh food cooked simply.
author: Greg W.

description: I had the petrale Parmesan and my mom had the whole crab Diablo-both were amazing! The staff was amazing and the cane and delivered wine as soon as we sat down! Yum yum yum!
author: Cathleen R.

description:
My mother went to Pacifica Cafe on Sunday July 13th. She and my brother arrived at 4:30.  The doors opened up at 4:45 and they went inside to wait. At 5pm the same woman who let them in asks "who was in here firts?" Well she let them in, did she forget?   They seated themselves and waited. Someone brought water & bread. They waited for 20 mins before anyone paid any attention to them. They kept trying to get the wait staffs attention.  Finally they got the attention of a waitress who in turn ask a waiter to come over & take the order. He came and my mom asked what was going on that everyone was running around. Others had already been served while they waited.  The waiter proceeded to say, "we have to wait on on regulars first"!  What?  He was very rude about it. He took the order and the food arrived.  He came by once to ask if they wanted water.  My brothers fish wasl cold because it was frozen. Unfortunately he did not tell him that. 
The waiter continued to be rude. When the check came they decided this lack of attention did not deserve a tip.  So they left the money for the bill and departed.  
Well this you will not believe.  This rude nasty man chased them out the door and yelled "come back another time when you are not nervous".  
What a nasty mean person.  He should loose his job.  This seems to be a new group of help at Pacific Cafe. I know this is their anniversary but if they keep this up it could be their last year. I know we will not be back and i will make sure all of the people I know who go there think twice about going back.  They have cut their menu down and frankly the food is less than stellar.  Oh and the prices have continued to rise.  If you are going to raise prices you should have better food.  If I could have given no stars i would have but Yelp does not give that option.
author: Susan K.

description: Everyone is great here except one. One waitress ruined our night over her assumptions of our disposition. Put simply, if you get seated in her section ask to be seated somewhere else.
author: M W.

description:
Let me start off by saying Pacific Cafe, that your complimentary wine while waiting for a table, is evil.   Delicious but evil.  Do you have any idea how many glasses a person can consume, on an empty stomach mind you, while waiting 30-45 minutes?  Too much, thats how many.  By the time our name was called, i was feeling mighty relaxed, glossy eyes and all.  On the plus side, you dont even realize how long you've actually been waiting for a table.  I suspect this is why they hand out the complimentary wine.  Im on to you Pacific Cafe!

Wine before dinner would be a good thing for most.  Me, well, i tend to lose my appetite for food once ive been cruisin the booze train.  At any rate, i browsed the specials and the dinner menu and decided to have the grilled salmon and red potatoes.  God im predictable.  Before our entrees came out we had an oyster cocktail appetizer.  I cant say i was a fan of this, sorry.  I dont know why i was expecting them to still be in the shell.  The raw oysters were cut up into pieces and put into a little glass.  Dont get me wrong, they were good, but i wasnt won over.  

My salmon was a nice sized hunk of fish and was very good, perfectly seasoned, with a nice herb butter on top.  I wasnt able to finish my meal at all, i was stuffed to the brim, but that didnt stop me from trying someones parmesan crusted halibut.  It was very good as well and i was kicking myself for not stepping out the norm and ordering that instead.  Next time, definitely.  Aside from the free wine before dinner, i also had a glass of sauv blanc once we were seated.  Im ashamed to say, i sent it back.  That was a first for me.  I replaced it with a glass of pinot grigio and that was more to my liking.  

I'll definitely be back to dine here.  I love seafood and Pacific Cafe has wonderful fresh seafood and there were many other things on the menu that i want to try in the future.  They dont take reservations but trust me, you wont mind waiting.  Service is beyond friendly and the restaurant itself is nice and quaint inside.  Im very much appreciative of being taken here....but next time, you've got to keep me away from the complimentary wine.
author: Juv C.

description:
I don't mind waits, but if YOU do... then i would take off 2-3 stars since its that long of a wait...Thats the price you pay for popularity. The place opens at 5pm so i would be their at 5pm just to wait at the most 20 minutes... One nice thing about the waits...They give you some nice little glasses of red wine for your trouble, which can be a lot of trouble if your stuck outside on a blustery outer richmond afternoon with 80mph onshore winds howling.

But we're here for the food so lets tawk about dat..
The wifey got the salmon with rice i believe.. it was soooo good, the salmon tasted unbelievably good!!!!!  I got the halibut crusted parmesan with the red potatoes... damn that was good!!!!!!! And i think when we were their the ahi tuna was all sold out after only being open for 2 hours, so that tells you something too...

All the food is buttery good (sometimes a little too much) and the bread that they give with the sweat cream butter is almost too much and will fill ya up. I've tried their soup a few times and its off the hook as well (not using my urban voice but my fisherman's voice..argg matey). Give the PC try.
author: Lindonesia S.

description: I'm not a big seafood person but my buddy and I were both craving it so we checked Yelp and found this place. The wait was about 10 minutes. They offered us complimentary wine which was nice. We were given seats promptly and delicious sourdough and Caesar salad was provided to us. I ordered the Salmon which was absolutely great. Perfectly cooked and moist. My side of potatoes was also spectacular. Prices are great and the quality of the food is as well. Definitely will come here more often.
author: Darius A.

description: I have been to this place a few times now, and from my experience its the service and system that needs to change for this to be a 5 star restaurant. The food is quite good, not the best in the city, but good. If your in the area then make an effort to try it at least once. The gentleman working there is nice and friendly, but the lady who works there needs to lighten up a bit. She seems moody all the time when we visit, and makes the experience a bit unpleasant. You will know the one I'm talking about when you visit. Service and experience is important to us customers to keep on coming back. I would recommend the bowl of mussels to share for starters, and the combo of salmon and giant shrimp to finish. If you have room then definitely order the toasted almond ice cream there. I would recommend for them to get a cappuccino/latte machine instead of serving basic coffee. The system they have there is lame for the seating. I would recommend having your whole party there at one time or they won't seat youeven though you are starving and willing to order more. I think it is a stupid system to have to wait for you whole party considering all the tables are empty almost when you arrive there at 5pm. I figure while you wait you provide more revenue to the restaurant by sitting at your table a few minutes longer instead of standing at the front. They do give a complimentary glass of white wine while you wait, but they do need to improve their wine list big time. Prices aren't bad if you share, but they could bring down the food prices a bit especially with the moody lady walking around. I'll be back, but the restaurant needs to improve a bit with their system and service. And, that isn't only coming from me. Overall, good food if your in the area....Enjoy
author: Mark L.

description: Amazing resturant.  Great service and food.  Would Definatley come back again. Scallops/ Salmon and the mini red potatoes were amazing.
author: Danny G.

description: Been loving this place since 1983....always on point... Relaxed atmosphere with a 70's feel . Neighborhood gem ...
author: T S.

description: We've been coming here since 1977, dozens and dozens of times.  You always know what you're going to get at Pacific Cafe.  Fine food, good service, free wine, fun times...  But being served by Frank likely ruined us forever.  Not sure why we'd never seen him before (since he said he's worked here for 40 years!) but he was the rudest server EVER!!!  Impossible to get his attention, totally unprofessional (even rolled his eyes, and argued,) never checked back in on us...  Really really did NOT enjoy this meal because of Frank.  We are always 20% tippers, but no way for him.  Shouldn't have tipped even a penny, but our years in the restaurant business won over and we ended up leaving a small tip (which was way too much.)  We will not be returning to Pacific Cafe, nor will we continue to recommend it to our myriad houseguests.  *The other servers there are great; too bad for this one really bad apple in the bunch!!!
author: Elaine M.

description: This has been my go to place for my birthday and other special occasions since the 1980's.  Everyone who has come here with me has loved it.  I had salmon for my last visit, though I love the scampi, and it was cooked to perfection.  We like to walk at Land's End then come a bit early to get in the first seating at 5PM.
author: Lynn A.

description: come early (like before they open) to ensure avoiding a super long wait. the food is really good and fresh, and service is great. when i went, they also gave everyone a complimentary glass of wine to sip on as you wait to be seated! definitely will come back one day when i'm in the mood for an early dinner.
author: Sabrina L.

description: I've admittedly only been here once, and it was fine. I enjoyed their soup.  A little expensive, but it is seafood. The main thing that can be rough is the wait, there is almost always a line at this place. If I had been able to go more, maybe there'd be more stars.
author: Barrett I.

description: I live a few blocks away from the café, and I've been there numerous times. I guess my first dinner is dated by 1998. Unfortunately, the quality of food and services declined since that time. Food: rice looks more like mash, not like steam rice. One big baked potato with butter inside, replaced by three small potatoes now. Salads were much better in back days. The servers are swift, but not friendly enough. I think is good café for local people, who do not want to travel far from home, and do not want to spend much money for dinner, because prices there are reasonable. Bottom line: it's casual dining place for locals.
author: Igor B.

description:
I've been looking for seafood in the Richmond so what a surprise it was to see Pacific Cafe pop up on yelp, and mere minutes from home. 

WHAT A DISAPPOINTMENT!

First of all, the "free" wine? It's not free. The prices for the food more than covers off on that. Let me drill down into the specifics of this crime scene. The place has been around forever, since the 70s. As such there are plenty of seniors who like to frequent this joint. They get so drunk and happy off the "free" wine that they love to tell you what a fabulous place this is on their way out. My party of 3 got spooked when one senior citizen popped out at us from a corner booth to tell us what a great decision we made coming to PC. She drawled on about how she's been coming here since the 80s. Spotting drool on her lower lip, I leaned away from her as a younger relative helped her with a coat.

Shaken, but undeterred, we sipped our overflowing glasses of wine. Only after a few sips, the waiter came back out to return our status back to overflowing.  Generous would be an understatement. In total, we only had to wait 30 mins for a table and once we were seated, the ambiance was quit cozy. Unfortunately the moment of comfort was kept brief when one of my guests noticed large white flecks in her water. We requested a new one without a problem, but we stopped sipping our wine after that. 

We ordered the oysters cocktail. Gross. Why would you present oysters chopped up in a glass? Why remove them from their shells only to have shell pieces floating in the oyster juice? Not a good sign.

Entrees arrived. Crab Louie for me, Mussels for one, and Prawns for the other. Crab Louie was OK - not sure why they have to have giant, 3 inch diameter slices of cucumber and tomatoes that require me to work so hard. Prawns were OK, nothing special. The mussels, however, were super dry with almost no broth. Throughout our meal, the wait staff was attentive and very polite, I had not problems there. But there was certainly concern in their eyes and we all detected a tone of suspicion from them due to our untouched glasses of wine. 

That's right, we weren't drunk, and so the food had to stand on it's own. Well let me tell you, it couldn't. 

I like to try every place twice just to be sure, but for over $30 per person? No thanks, I'm done with PC. If you want to get drunk for "free", and you're over the age of 50 with money to burn, you will love this place.
author: Cherry P.

description: Excellent food, with fresh catch seafood cooked on the daily. Completely unpretentious atmosphere with a family-owned vibe. Be prepared to wait a few minutes at dinner time, but the free wine doesn't hurt.
author: Dave T.

description: They served some of the most awfully overpriced, barely edible food in my life. The cocky waiter basically tossed plates on our table. Why does this place have 4 stars on Yelp?
author: Sally R.

description:
Do not order the Sole in Newberg Sauce with Red Potatoes.  

This was the greatest disappointment of my life since not getting in to Colgate.  Yes, yes, I know it sounds delicious but what you get is a soupy creamy mess with the crab and parsley just making it worse.  Read the reviews below, and you'll see I'm not alone in calling it out.  

It's a huge shame, because everything else about Pacific Cafe is super.  Dinner included free wine to compensate for the wait, sourdough bread, and a delicious salmon bisque.  Sounds like the way to go here is avoid anything with sauce.  I'd like to come back, but point everyone towards something like the calamari steak, ahi tuna, or trout.

Not all that expensive when you add it all up.  A couple can eat well here for under $50.
author: John H.

description:
I liked the warm colour lighting and its simple design. I don't think seafood places need to be fancy. We were waiting for a while but that didn't matter because as you all know, we were given free wine while we wait. I don't normally drink white, but it was free!  
The food was stupendous. I had the turbot, succulent chunks of fish meat cooked in a parchment bag with a cream sauce  deliciously soaked up by the red spuds.
My girlfriends food mad me jealous, however. She had the parmesan encrusted halibut . It was to die for. We finished off the night with some chocolate tart with a dollop of cream. 
This meal cost very  little as we were both given more wine  before we were seated and it lasted till the end of our meal.
I will eat here again, and I'll look forward to bringing friends and family.
author: Johnny N.

description:
My parents have been visiting the Pacific Cafe since they started dating in 1978.  When we went for dinner last Thursday night we had the same server that they had so many years ago.

We were greeted with wine, for free while we were waiting.... I had 2 free glasses.

BEST TARTAR SAUCE YOU HAVE EVER HAD!  I can promise you that!

There are plenty of reviews, so you already know the seafood is excellent.  

Order some tartar sauce and lemon with your bread, it is delicious!

This place is so cute, it is a great date place!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
The complementary wine seemed nice, until I experienced an incredibly long wait time...so long that they should've offered me a complimentary appetizer....almost an hour.

But I was really in the mood for seafood. So I waited.

The food was good, but nothing that I would rave about. The rice on my dish was lukewarm and the fish was very dry. The soup (Salmom Bisque) was excellent.

Unless you have a ton of patience, I wouldn't recommend this restaurant simply because of the wait time. The servers were very pleasant, but I'm guessing most nights, you're going to wait between 20 minutes to 60 minutes for a table. And they don't do reservations either.
author: Nate T.

description: We arrived around 7:30 and had to wait for an hour to be seated.  However, one of the waiters kept handing out complimentary glasses of wine to everyone waiting.  After we were seated, if was no nonsense, old fashioned, seafood.  Old school SF at its best.
author: Oleg A.

description:
FOOD SUCKS DON'T BOTHER. Unless you're a non San Francisco person, then go for it. 

Free Wine is ok. Food is either luke warm, msg overpowers the food or service never comes to you. VERY PRICEY. 

For the 2 by 2 square meal you get, I think this place just doesn't want to give you good service.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
This place has been around since the 70's and from what I can tell (not that I'm an expert: I wasn't even born yet) it hasn't really changed through the years. With menu items like "Sole Newberg" and "Fried Oysters", I like to think of this as a retro seafood place. Their menu is classic, and tastes like what I imagine food would taste way back when we weren't so carb conscious and liked thick sauces over everything.

The most amazing, exciting food ever? No, not really. But it's good old fashioned seafood in a nice, unpretentious environment and they offer all the free wine that you can drink while waiting in line.

And bonus points for being walkable from my place. :)
author: Bekki J.

description:
Three words: San Franciso Jewel.

My mother (big foodie) and I found this place a couple of years ago after spending a day at The Legion (its within walking distance). What a fantastic treat! 

There is often a wait, and you'll get a complimentary glass of wine for your troubles.

The Halibut Paramesan is pretty good. Quite simply, they make an amazing newburg here.  I'm not a fan of the salmon & crab newburg combination (because I am not really a salmon fan), so I always have the salmon substitued for extra crab. 

If you're looking for that perfect little "local" spot, this is it. Plus, you'll find the owner often checking in on his guests. You definitely get a sense of his love of food and it shows in the care of his dishes and the guest experience.
author: CB S.

description: I liked the food fine as long as i am in the mood for seafood, and more specifically - fish!  They offer you a free glass of wine when you get there to help keep you company.  I like the shrimp louis salad that comes with my meal and most of the fish entrees on the menu are easy hits.  The only thing that keeps me from giving it 5 stars....they do a lot of neighborhood business, so many customers are usually regulars.  The wait staff to these regulars are usually EXTREMELY nice and CHATTY.  That said, depending on who you get as your waitperson, your meal may come quick or kinda slow...  When i get there, i try not to sit in the section of the female who i know is not very quick in getting orders in!  Other than that, this place is not a cheap hole in the wall so don't dine here thinking that it's a quick and cheap experience where you can get out for less than $30.
author: Amorette K.

description:
The wait is half the fun- complimentary vino! But the food is worth going back to over and over again! I had the crab cakes last time I went and they were amazing: warm and crispy, fresh crab meat, great flavor.

Great for any occasion. Best seafood in the Outer Richmond hands down!
author: Diana H.

description:
We stumbled upon this restaurant during New Years Eve. As my boyfriend described it, this place is like a senior center cafeteria as all the diners were 65+ except for us. They were all very friendly and nice...but we felt a little out of place.  Next time, we'll bring some seniors with us to blend in.  

The place has a warm/comfy feel of home.  Service was efficient.  Food was good. Generous portions.  We left stuffed!!!

Soup - Crab Bisque and Clam Chowder (with no diary)  - Great!
Crab Cakes - Lots of crab and very little breading.  Portion was huge (a meal in itself)
Salmon and Shrimp Combo - Nothing special but cooked perfectly.  Problaby should have tried something more adventurous.
NY Steak - Yes, my boyfriend ordered this despite all the seafood choices...It was juicy but could have used more salt.
author: Cin T.

description:
One of my student's dad was always giving me crap for having never been here, because I live less than 2 blocks down the street. Until he mentioned it and looked it up on his iPhone to show me a picture of the street view, I'd never even seen or heard of this tiny, hidden gem of the Richmond district.

So, after making a list of restaurants we wanted to try, my coworker and I decided to bring our girlfriends along for a "show and tell" of friends and try Pacific Cafe, since all of us live in the Richmond. We'd heard that they doled out free wine while waiting, so we set a time to meet up - 7 pm on a Sunday night.

At first we were told that it was a 45 minute wait, so we took our wine and stood outside, feeling somewhat like yuppies (well, I guess we all are yuppies in a sense). Thirty minutes passed. We looked at the wait list, and there were still about 7 names ahead of us. More wine. Another thirty minutes passed. 4 names ahead of us. Finally, we were seated after about an hour and a half.

Normally, anywhere else I wouldn't have waited more than 30 minutes. However, Pacific Cafe was such a great place; the ambiance was very warm and cozy, and the people (other customers and the wait staff) were all very friendly (maybe it's the wine?). My girlfriends and I decided to order 4 different dishes with all different sides and appetizers, so we could all try everything out.

We ended up ordering:

- the rainbow trout with fries, which were basically a quarter wedge of a potato. The fish was absolutely delicious; we didn't squeeze the lemon on top (oops) but there was a lump of butter in the middle, which we spread over the fish.

- the sole, with a mushroom and caper sauce, served with rice pilaf. This was also delicious, although I wasn't a fan of the sauce. I like my fish very plain, so I can taste the actual meat of the fish itself. The rice was excellent though, and I'm convinced I'll never be able to do the Atkins' diet.

- the ahi tuna, seared on the outside and served rare on the inside, with a side of wasabi mayo. This was probably my favorite, because the tuna was very, very tender and the wasabi mayo went so perfectly with it.

- the red snapper, which was seasoned on both sides with a spicy mix of ..well.. spices. This fish had the most flavor on its own because of the way it was seasoned, and the meat was also very tender.

As for the appetizers, we had the Shrimp Louie salad, the Caesar salad, the clam chowder and their crab bisque, which was the special for the night. As an anti-fan of creamy soups, I ditched the bisque in favor of the clam chowder, which had no cream in it. It was the first time I'd tried a non-cream-based clam chowder, and it was absolutely delicious because the seafood taste wasn't overpowered by the cream.

We couldn't fit in dessert, but there's always next time, right?
author: Tori S.

description:
This place is awesome!  They've been there forever and had the same servers and cooks forever.  I think the server told us two of their main cooks had been there for like 30 yrs each.

They give you free wine while you wait.

You get soup or salad and delicious sourdough bread with all meals.

I've loved just about everything I've ever had there and the food is always consistent.

They don't take reservations which can be a bummer, but I totally understand why so I wouldn't knock them for that.
author: McKenzie M.

description: One of my very favorite places for more than 30 years. Whatever the wait, whatever the weather, it's always worth it.
author: Gregory L.

description:
Fantastic, simple-yet-complex seafood in a comfortable setting.  

The service is friendly, apt and appropriate.  The server brings you a complimentary glass of wine to start and lets you browse the daily and specials menu while you enjoy some homemade sour dough bread and creamy salty butter.  

I ordered the Grilled Salmon (slathered with an herb-filled butter cream) and fried fresh prawns with Salmon Bisque and red potatoes.  Alison had the Snapper Spicy with Clam Chowder and french fries.  Both were totally delicious, the Snapper boasting a crisp, robust char of chili powders, pepper and herbs, the Salmon being a more modestly straight-forward piece of fish, wish the aforementioned slathering of garlic-herb-enhanced sweet cream butter.

The red potatoes were cooked to perfection, as were the fries, both delicate and crisp.  The prawns were delightfully butterflied and lightly fried.  The Salmon bisque had an incredibly delicate hint of fishiness, creaminess and small bits of salmon which worked well texturally.  The Clam Chowder was the surprise stand-out with it's stew-like consistency and taste - a flour and oil based flavor that reminds me of my own Mother's beef stew - with pieces of mussels and potatoes reminding the brain it is actually, in fact, a chowder.

I will be back again, when lovely company deems it necessary.  The Pacific Cafe is one of those neighborhood joints you frequent when it's time to impress loved ones with simple, elegant food and an excellently laid-back, friendly environment.
author: Blake C.

description:
Anytime we're driving down Geary around dinnertime and see that there is no line here, we find parking as quickly as possible and get our name on the list. 
Once that is accomplished we're handed a free glass of wine to enjoy while we wait. (if there is a line and you have to wait for awhile, your glass gets refilled) That alone is worth several stars. I mean, they don't have to do that- the place is so popular and so good there would be a line out the door anyway- but they're awesome, so they do. 

Now, let's talk seafood. 
It's good. Like, really good. The bisques and chowders are always rich and heavenly. The salads are crisp and fresh (go for the shrimp louie) and the fish... omg. 
The chalkboard always has specials that get erased as they run out, but never fear; the standard menu is full of tasty treats too. I'm a huge fan of the sole nuremberg (which I'm pretty sure I've spelled wrong.) It's sole stuffed with crab and baked in this cheesy cream sauce. Just thinking about it makes me hungry. The spicy snapper is also amazing. Hell, it's all amazing. AND the staff is friendly and patient and not at all pushy (happy to let you linger even if they have a line waiting for your table). 
It really doesn't get much better.
author: Valerie G.

description:
i dont know...maybe i ordered the wrong things here but i thought the food was disgusting.

i ordered 6 raw oysters, which came on a plate with the shells off, first bit i took of the oyster, it was so fat and gigantic that all this cream just filled in my mouth & i was literally about to barf.  now bc of this i am very hesitant 
to try "big" oysters again.  Lets just stick to the smaller sized ones -.-

i also ordered the seared tuna, which came out very dry & has no flavor at all !! 

i also saw that they were known for their crabcakes, so my bf ordered them, and the first bite i took, made me feel like there was nothing special about them, they were actually too heavy & nauseating. 

never again.
author: Evelyn S.

description: Soooo good! They keep it simple and let the fresh ingredients speak for themselves. My better half and I had three courses: oyster ap, soup/sald course and entrees. Bought a half bottle of wine with dinner plus the free glasses while we wait... our bill was under $80!!! Amazing! Service was on point and there was a classy but low-key neighborhood vibe. We will return!
author: Shienberg G.

description: This place is easily the busiest place in the Outer Richmond.  It feels like you are in a suburb.  Portions are generous, service is genuine--they turn tables quickly, children are welcome, wine is free while you wait...The food is good, but it is not all local/organic, SF Foodie standard beautiful food.  They are very good at what they know, and the locals come back over and over and are willing to wait.  For about $20 an entree, which includes a soup or salad (where else do you get that anymore), it is a bargain.
author: Rita G.

description: Went here last night. Waited about 45 minutes. Had a glass of their free white wine, and when we finally got seated we were not asked if we wanted anything to drink. I guess the waiter assumed that we were good with the white wine they offer free while waiting. I must say food came out pretty quickly. I had the salmon and shrimp ($24.95), it was really good. I give the food 4 .5 stars and service and wait time 3.... I don't think I will go again. We have twins and wait is too much.
author: Ines C.

description: Great eats, complimentary wine while you wait and good service. Nuff said.
author: Leanne S.

description:
The only downside is that the restaurant is a bit small and there is usually a longer than average wait.  HOWEVER, they do give you complimentary wine while you wait.

They have their daily specials on the chalkboard that you can read to plan your meal while you wait to be seated.  It is also a great opportunity to strike up a warm conversation with your fellow SF neighbors.  

For starters we had the crabcakes and they were so large we could have shared one and been content.  For my main course, I had the spicy snapper and would recommend to everyone especially if you like spicy foods.  I forgot to mention that you also receive a cup of soup or a nice sized salad with every entree.  That is a great deal that you don't always see in SF restaurants.  My roommate had the parmesan crusted Halibut and loved it.  She doesn't care for fish all that much but she commented that it was less fishy than she thought it would be.  

They had some great looking desserts, Mitchell's Ice Cream, Zanze's Cheesecake and a lemon square that caught my eye.  I was so stuffed from eating only half of my entree that I couldn't have dessert.
author: Trisha H.

description:
A group of us went to this place for our friend's birthday, and since from out of town, chose it based upon the yelp reviews.  We were NOT disappointed!

There were about 4 groups waiting in front of us (it's a pretty small/intimate place), but we were immediately greeted and brought glasses of free white wine (note to all wine drinkers - the free wine is just a white house wine, but it is good - not too sweet, but not tart... think a house merlot, but white... drinkably good).  The glasses were constantly being refilled by this sweet waiter named Ron.  He spoke with us for awhile and even prepped us that our waiter had been there since the restaurant's inception.  

I got the Rainbow Trout and it was woooonderful.  Not too buttery like some 'fish' places.  All five of us were very happy with our fish selections - though it IS filling and none of us were able to finish our plates.  

On price - well yeah, it IS kind of expensive for the Entrees ($18 - $28), but if you include the glasses of free wine... (you don't really need an app. with the yummy free bread)... it wasn't outrageous.  And the service was great - because the waiter knew WHEN to come over - and when to stay away to let us talk... he even helped call us a cab at the end of the night because they let us stay to finish up as the restaurant was closing.

I would recommend this to anyone wanting a relaxing, wonderful, neighborhood restaurant experience.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I don't know what to say about this place... typically, my philosophy is that fresh seafood is best served with as little added as possible to enjoy the taste of the fish. I was super excited to come here and my expectations were probably high. Too high. I loved the idea of having a tiny menu - meaning that they know their fresh fish and they will cook it well, right?

I will admit that it was part my ignorance that I didn't fully understand what I ordered. I saw some fancy French word that described the sauce (or technique) paired with "Sole" and it was the first thing on the menu - I thought, in a place like this, everything has to be good. Plus it was supposed to be "stuffed" with crab. Yum, right?

Unfortunately, my Sole came covered in cheese sauce that looked like Velveeta. I don't care if there's a name for that special cheese sauce that seems fancier than it actually is... it was overcooked fish covered in Velveeta. I tasted the crab a little bit but the sauce was a bit overwhelming... and I'm a girl that loves shells with Velveeta, but that comes in a box for $4. This was in a fancy restaurant that cost me $24.

We had a group of six (five of us ordered fish) and it looked like everything was a bit over-cooked and over seasoned. I don't think I would have raised this much stink if the prices were affordable... which it wasn't for the food that we were served. At the risk of sounding like a San Francisco snob, we live in a city where fresh and affordable seafood is plenty and accessible. This place is not worth the drive, when there are hundreds of great seafood places in the city.

To their defense, maybe I shouldn't have ordered the first thing on the menu. The ambiance was nice, clearly it's a popular place, we got free (but pretty gross, but free) wine while we waited for 20 minutes - not too bad considering how many people were waiting after we left. 

Conclusion: Over priced, over cooked, over it.
author: N S.

description:
(Cue the steel drums and xylophone)

No reservations. Yay! Go early on the day of. Perfect!
Free booze (if there is a small wait). I don't care.. But you do!
Tasty fish and excellent clam chowder. Yummy!
Daily specials posted everywhere. Got it!
Dated decor, but nostalgic. Mmmm... childhood...
author: Andrew M.

description:
I am not a big fan of American version of grilled sea food.
Because its always way over cooked.
They ruined the good fresh fish.
Well, come to think of, it doesn't need to have fresh, 
that's why this place have to over cooked.
Because the fish isn't fresh.
So as vegitables.
I think that this place just doesn't like crispy vegitables or you are just lazy to check the timer or just for senior citizens.
My X-wife always made over cooked broccli.
I hate over cooked broccli.
No wonder she is my X. Thank God.

I have an opinion when I come to sea food.
I become a Tough Mxxxxx Fxxxer.
But,
It doesn't matter what I have at this place. 
Because when I was seated, I am always already bombed by few glasses of cheap wine.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I'd rather go to "all you can eat popcorn shrimp night" at a Red Lobster in Fremont than dine again in this over-hyped dump. The fact that this place is always busy just proves that there are areas of SF (cough, cough, OUTER RICHMOND) that are as lame as any East Bay suburb...

The fact the reviewers here rave about getting free wine (cheap jug Chardonnay) while they wait for the table proves my point.
author: Stinky M.

description:
I love this place! Not only for the fact that we live just a block away from it, but their variety of daily specials! I'm a big fish person, I love anything fillet/grilled/baked/blackened/seared.

So, here's what I got!
Parmesan Halibut special. Crispy baked cheesy top. Not the melting-kind of cheese, but more of a crisp, crunchy baked. Sliced into it, is the clean, juicy thick fillet of the halibut. I had it with a side of steamed red potatoes. Go with the fries, I think it tasted better. My girl ordered the spicy blackened red snapper with fries and side of crab bisque soup. I had the side ceasar salad. We were also served with a pair of complimentary white wine with is really fruity and crisp, goes really well with the seafood dishes they served.

no doubt a deliciously worthy evening.
author: Rika P.

description:
THE WAIT
Ridiculous.  At least on a Friday night.  :)  Even at 5 when they freak'n open!  They gave everyone free wine who was waiting so... very nice.  Where is the free Root Beer for the friends of Bill W? :)

THE SOUP - comes with your meal, or salad
Crab Bisque and Clam Chowder tonight.  Crab was off the chain.  A little spicy, which I love, and just a hint of creaminess.  Clam Chowder was correct, as in not creamy (no flour)... though I like it creamy so bummer for me.

FISH
Plenty of it here... though a token NY steak is on the menu.  ;p  Had the Turbot Baked In Parchment with crab and shrimp.  It was good... I prefer my fish raw though... what can ya do?

DESSERT
Mitchell's Ice Cream!  And a about 3 scoops for 4 bucks... good deal.  Should get it here for take out and save the drive. ;p  Zanze's cheesecake up in here... got to love that.  Though I had the chocolate mouse with the home made whip.  Dame!  Very tasty.

PRICE
Ice cream is the most cost correct thing on the menu.  Still, 50 bucks for a meal for two in a fish joint aint bad.  Still, I'd rather up it by another 50 and make it a sushi night at a proper sushi place (Can you say Sushi 69 in San Anselmo... I new you could.  Holy MOG... had the Hotate there a few days ago with the lite pan sizzle with butter and soy sauce... drool drool drool... buddy blurted out that it was the best thing he has ever tasted, anywhere, ever)...
author: Dan M.

description:
I love this place! Great for dates, family dinners, etc. Parking is pretty easy. 

They open at 5pm, so if you want to get seated right away show up at 4:45. They start serving wine in line before they open.

And yes, they serve wine while you wait. (And 7up/etc to kids. Older kids can get 7up in a wine glass if they ask!) So don't complain about them not taking reservations. If you want to take full advantage of the free wine, show up at 6pm (probably the busiest time). They'll also give you bread in line if you ask. 

Another bonus... They aren't super pretentious about carding in line. I look young, like really young, I know that. I don't blame people for thinking I might be under 21, but I do hate when people see my ID and give me crap about it. I look EXACTLY like my driver's license. Someday when I'm fifty and still being carded I'll appreciate people giving me grief, but for now, just trust the Driver's License. 

Anyways.. tangent... Back to the review... 

Fish is pretty much the only thing they serve and it is tasty! They switch things up a lot, but whatever you order you'll enjoy. 

Crowd here is definitely mature and people dress like they are on their way to the Opera. But it's still always fun. My favorite part is the conversation while waiting in line. Everyone is happy and drunk. I LOVE watching older couples get drunk with you. The stories about the good old days always make me laugh. Plus once inside people are so friendly that they'll lean over and ask what you ordered. I've even given people bites of my food here. (With their fork of course! ewww... Did you really think I let them eat off my fork? I'm not THAT friendly!)
author: Ali R.

description:
Everything about this restaurant was just a little too OLD for me...old decor, old customers, old style of cooking.  I'm sure a lot of people would find this charming and comforting.  If the food were good enough, the long wait and the fact that it's way out in the Outer Richmond wouldn't matter.

To be fair, we only tried one fish dish, the ahi tuna.  The tuna steak was huge, but it was dry and cooked all the way through.  I guess I've just been spoiled by delicious seared sushi grade ahi.  The wasabi butter did nothing to revive the flavors.  I wasn't very hungry but I was really there to try the soups.  I ordered the bowl of the crab bisque, which was good but a little too creamy.  I preferred the clam chowder which wasn't creamy like New England clam chowder.  It was chunky with clams and the soup was thick, kinda like gravy.  Yummm gravy in a cup.  The side dishes were also boring like the red potatoes that were just boiled and flavorless and the whole head of lemon butter broccoli. 

Most fish dishes were about $20 and I think the crab cakes were a little more.  There seem to be a lot of regulars and I saw a senior couple making out as they left the restaurant so there must be something about this restaurant...maybe I'll find out in 30 years or so!
author: Mimi L.

description:
My parents used to come here just after they'd married and moved to SF. This place is old and my parents are old and 80% of the customers are old too. I wonder what's going to happen in ten years when their clientele starts to move to Phoenix or Palm Springs or their doctors start to put them on special diets and they can't eat out so much.

Another thing about this place is that unless you're down to eat dinner at 5:30 or so you can expect to wait a while. But this is ok, because they'll serve you free glasses of cheap strong wine (it's a chablis; who drinks chablis anymore?) while you wait, even if you're standing outside on the street. So after a few glasses you won't mind waiting so much, and when you do sit down you'll be a little buzzed and inclined to order more.

The food itself is not particularly unique; pretty standard dishes made with fresh seafood. The fried oysters are tender and buttery and the Ahi with wasabi butter is also worth checking out, but bear in mind that I've been buzzed on cheap wine every time I've ordered these. The clams are good too but honestly it's hard to screw up clams.

The service is also really friendly and attentive. Their waitstaff has unusually low turnover; You'll see the same faces there over and over again.
author: matthew r.

description:
I don't really like seafood, so my review will focus on this place's ambiance.

I'm a big believer in a place's look fitting its feel as an establishment.  I don't think all places should look hip and modern.  In fact, a lot of the hip-and-modern looking places spend too much money on presentation and not enough money on food.  Places with really dated interiors (the hip and modern of the '60s, usually) aren't always that bad, because their complete lack of regard for updating their decor often denotes a commitment to doing what they do best, which is serve the food they served in the '60s.  If they've been around that long, they are probably doing something right.

Pacific Cafe looks like it will be one of those old-school seafood places.  You get that vibe from the decorating within and the really nice warm colors you see when you're looking at this place's windows through the Geary Boulevard fog.  But when you actually order and get your food, it's as if you're in a slightly hip restaurant.  The portions aren't really small, but they're not as hearty as you'd expect from this kind of place.  Basically, this place has multiple personalities, and they don't get along.
author: John S.

description:
THEY TOOK THE LOBSTER OFF THE MENU!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Please excuse me while I attempt to gain composure....
.....
.....
.....

Pacific Café took a nose dive from the Sunset's best kept secret to a truly mediocre restaurant with one very very poor decision...

Bright side? You no longer have to wait for a table...
author: Taylor E.

description:
We popped in for an appetizer before hitting the Legion of Honor, which is just up the street.  The clam chowder may possibly be the BEST I've ever had.  It was not too creamy/thick and nicely peppery/flavorful.  It just hit the spot on a cool, foggy evening.

As we hadn't read the other reviews, we were surprised and delighted to be greeted with two free and quite drinkable glasses of white wine.  I thought for a split second the guy was going to take them back when we told him we just wanted appetizers and I did notice the menu had a $6 per person minimum which we just made with my bowl of soup and hubby's shrimp cocktail.

We arrived maybe 10 minutes after opening (5:00pm) and there were two tables left.  When we left, the small waiting area was packed.  Entrees were $20 and up.  The focus is seafood.  Wait staff is old school and professional.  I'm pretty sure we were the youngest people in the restaurant, which hardly seems possible.  If the clam chowder is any indication of the rest of the food, I'd brave being part of the "mature" crowd to try dinner.  There is no bar area...so even if you just want an appetizer...you'll need to nab a table in this busy spot, and they don't appear to take reservations.
author: Linda M.

description:
All I have to say is complimentary house red and/or white wine while you wait!!! Yes they will refill your glass as long as your not seated. This can be a wonderful thing Sunday through Thursday evening but the wait is longer Friday and Saturday nights so watch the refills. No reservations available. 

Parking is a beotch and there is usually a wait for a table. You can usually estimate the wait by how many people have spilled out onto the street with their glass of vino in hand. The food is worth the wait. This is an old school SF establishment with an old school staff to match. 

The restaurant is dark, on the smaller side, and the atmosphere is  loud. The seafood is always fresh and cooked to perfection.  I have never had a bad meal at Pacific Cafe. The specials are worth hearing about and if you are undecided don't be afraid to ask your waitress for suggestions, they are not shy about making recommendations.
author: Frankie F.

description:
I gotta agree w/ some of the naysayers here.  Pacific Cafe was a complete disappointment for me.  I had a salad and crab cakes, both were mediocre at best.  My friend ordered the clam chowder - pretty standard fare.  And the food ain't that cheap either, so be warned.

The free glass of wine was what you would expect - cheap.

I guess the positives are the neighborhood feel, loved the booths and its tough to go wrong w/ warm sourdough bread to kick-off a meal on what was a foggy, cold night.

Unfortunately, I can't recommend Pacific Cafe...
author: John R.

description:
Came here the other day.. and the food was great..Free wine also! 
I had the grilled salmon/ and baked scallops which was really good. The salmon was cooked perfect and the baked scallops were soaked in a lemon/buttery sauce.  Yummy!! Also, the meal comes with a small cesar salad and red potatos. The waitress was very nice and the service was very quick. Came during peak hours which wasn't so bad because we had a party of 2 only.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place.  I'd been there years ago and had a good memory of it.  We decided to go this evening when we found ourselves looking for a place to celebrate my husband's birthday.

First, the pluses.  The staff is really nice.  Free jug wine while you wait.  Friendly service.  Even the customers waiting tables were friendly and chatty.  The room is warm & comfy, a nice neighborhood place.

Then, the food... I ordered prawns scampi.  It came with a "shrimp louie" salad that consisted of a handful of shrimp drowned in what looked like a cup of thousand island dressing on a bed of iceberg lettuce. When the scampi came, I was really disappointed.  It was about a dozen medium size prawns and some mushy overcooked bits of tomato swimming in a ramekin of yellow oil.  It didn't taste like butter, it didn't taste like white wine, it was indefinable.  And it was $24!  We were having a great time otherwise, and I didn't want to spoil the mood, so I ate the prawns.

When I asked my husband about it later, he said he was also disappointed in his dish, the special combo (salmon and mussels, also about $24).  For four people, this was an expensive evening, and we both felt sick to our stomachs afterword. I would not go back.
author: Kim M.

description:
Ah, the Pacific Cafe.

Where else can you wait in a ridiculously long line drinking cheap wine?

Where else can you can you get seated and get your order taken in under five minutes?

Where else can you get a bland, Americanized piece of fish with mayonnaise or some relative drowning the meal?

Where else can you get the stink-eye from wait staff if you take longer then ten minutes to eat?

Where else can you get asked fifteen times if they can bring you the bill?

Where else can you get upset stomachs - you and your date even though you ordered different meals and did not "share" plates?

I tried to like this place when I lived in the neighborhood but I got really tired of their service.  The place is all about turning tables - not the dining experience.  While the fish selection is very good one has to be very careful how to order it / have it prepared lest it be drowned in sauce.  Kitchen hygiene can't be that great because I know numerous people who have gotten sick there - I came dangerously close myself.

Great place if you want to try and get tipsy on cheap wine while waiting for your seat - then get pushed through your meal as fast as possible then chased out the door.  Decor looks like it is stuck in the bad part of the seventies.
author: jeff b.

description:
So, I recently made it out to this place (after reading about it on Yelp), and it did not disappoint!

I went on a Sunday evening as part of a group of three for a friend's birthday, and the wait was not as long as expected...it was, however, long enough for me to enjoy a glass of free wine. Per some of the other reviewers' comments, the wine did seem a bit watered-down, but 'free' watered-down wine kicks 'no' watered-down wine's ass any day...

I enjoyed some of the best petrale sole I've ever eaten here, and the wine we ordered with dinner was also good (and priced fairly). We didn't have room to enjoy dessert, but any place that serves up Mitchell's ice cream (among other treats) is doing it right!

The decor is old-school, the staff was cool and the prices were fair...I'll definitely be heading back here again. Maybe this time around I'll save room for dessert...

For you animal lovers out there, it was cool to see the kitchen staff feeding a bunch of (feral?) cats at the side of the restaurant when we left...sure beats throwing food away!
author: Art D.

description: Simply fantastic.  The food is great, the atmosphere is friendly, and the free wine is such a nice touch.
author: Mara H.

description:
There is nothing fancy and nothing creative here, but the food is usually good, and the service is normally friendly, except for one asshole who works Saturday nights. (there are two who look alike, the slimmer whiney one with shorter hair is the asshole!!)  

WHAT I LOVE: I love their calamari steak, because I do not Meunière anything at home! Their crab cakes are really great! I sometimes ask for their scallops sautéed instead of fried and they come out absolutely orgasmic! Their free Caesar salad that comes with the meal is really good; I also add anchovies! Their Petrale Doré is OK... I look forward to their sand dabs season! Their muscles and/or clams are usually good. Their Calamari cocktail is really low fat and delicious! Their fried oysters, and their seasonal crab are good too!

WHAT I REALLY LOVE: two people can eat good food, tip, and drink lots of wine for under $50/$60 

I miss their lobster tail! 


WHAT I DO NOT LIKE (MAYBE EVEN HATE): I do not like their Halibut parmesan, as well as some things that I can make at home that I never order there, such as the salmon and the spicy snapper! The rice and the fries are not good, but the steamed potatoes are good and honestly how can you fuck them up! Their steamed broccoli tastes like it was marinated in clarified butter for weeks (seriously!)


You feel as if you stepped into the seventies when you walk in. does anyone still do newburg? They give you free wine while you wait, and they will gladly sub red if you're not a white drinker... 

On the very rare occasions you do not wait for what feels like days, they still give you a complimentary glass of wine! 

Again: There is nothing fancy and nothing creative here, but the food is usually good, and the service is normally friendly & professional --unless you get that asshole as your waiter! and honestly even the "asshole" is quite efficient!

THEY GET AN EXTRA STAR BECAUSE: MOST of their employees have been there for over 10 years--some even twenty! MEANING: the owner(s) must be great people to work for!  EXACTLY the kind of establishment I would like to support!
author: Maddy S.

description:
Are you kidding me? This place is soooo relying on the endless lines of people who've "got to try this place." The restaurant is like it's clientele- past it's prime and WAY outta fashion. Gotta admit, the free, and disgusting, wine you get for waiting is a plus. After all, how often do you sit down to dinner (nearly) drunk without a bar tab? It's pretty much downhill from there though.

Bland soup? Check. Bland rice? Double check. Fish I could have microwaved à la Gordon's Fisherman? Unfortunately, check.

Skip this place if you can. Resist the urge to check out "this great seafood place everyone goes to." If you pay attention to the morons who wait outside of the place every night you'll see it's time to let this place go...
author: Thomas S.

description:
I've always wanted to try this place!!  There is always a long line waiting outside everytime I drove by!  The fact that they offer free wine while you wait is always a plus.  So I was pretty excited when we finally decide to go & give it a try on a warm sunny day.  The food was just ok, not as good as anticipated.  I don't think it's worth the price they're charging tho...food was pretty salty and the portion is quite small.  The salmon bisque was the highlight of the meal...

Minus one star because the waitress poured wine all over me =(
author: Connie L.

description:
A friend who grew up around SF took me.  This was probably the best situation because she knew better and insisted we get there just before opening to snag a table before the place filled up.  As everyone else has explained, we got the free glass of wine, which was really great.

Simply put, the food was great.  I'm not a huge fish fan, but I loved my meal.  I had rainbow trout, and one of  the things I loved about it was that they really didn't have to put too much else on it to make the meal great. Everything was cooked perfectly and the quality is really excellent.  The price is out of my normal budget, of course, but it's a great deal.  Especially if you figure in your free glass of wine!
author: Lizzy G.

description:
sure its sweet, the cheap wine while you wait is nice, and I realize its been there for forever. But you guys do seafood right? Why do I feel like you are getting it from Sysco freezer packs? 

If you have a little Southern cafe in mind with lots of mediocre seafood for cheap being served to a clueless audience, this is your spot.
author: Jeremi M.

description:
'where'd i park my car?'
'i don't remember what i ate.'
'did we pay??'

- - typical things stephen and i will say to each other, the day after a pacific cafe evening.  

we like to wait outside, wine in hand, watching the stray cats lingering around the side entrance for scraps.  one evening, there was a noisy raccoon nearby...  after a couple of glasses of wine, i addressed two couples who were also waiting outside...  'do you think that that raccoon is hungry or horny?'  ...yeah.  well hey, one couple responded to my mild outburst.  we've become friends since that evening.

i'm a fan of this place.  i'm protective of this place.  some people take advantage of the free wine.  drunk, i once thought that a guy w/a short mohawk, who walked up the street, followed a couple of people in to get some free wine.  the following conversation ensued:

me (to stephen):  (shocked)  he's just here for the free wine!!
stephen:  really?  how do you know?
me:  i KNOW.
(i follow the guy inside, to where the sign-in sheet is.)
me (to guy):  yknow, you have to write your name in to get seated.
guy:  yeah, i'm just looking to see where i am on the list.
me:  (pauses, looks at list):  where are you?
guy:  (points to the last name on the list):  here.
me:  (pauses again.)  you sure that's you?
guy:  yeah.
me:  (pauses again.)  ok.  (i walk away, still looking at him, as if to say, 'i've got my eye on you, foo.')

oh, the things that are said at pacific cafe.  you'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll get into arguments, and apparently, you may even harass patrons (who may not be patrons).

the lights that greet you as you walk through the door cast a reddish hue on the patrons, old paintings, and seafood dinners in this quaint restaurant.  one needn't be worried about looking a little pink in the face from all the wine.  - - the lights are a perfect disguise!

pacific cafe has the friendliest staff you'll ever meet.  roy's always very engaging; he's becoming my pseudo-uncle.  reny, laura, and aubrey are also very pleasant.  i DID have a sour evening w/a certain gentleman who gave us a hard time about wanting to order veggie entrees (for a change, since we come here so often).  at the end of our meal, he boxed up my leftovers in a sizable oyster bucket.  i thought that this was very inappropriate.  though, since then, i haven't had anything to complain about.

the food is pretty good.  i usually get the halibut parmesan w/red potatoes, and the salmon bisque.  i also occasionally get the crabcakes or the petrale dore stuffed w/crab.  may be a good idea to ask your server if the entree that you've ordered has bones in it.  - - trying to debone a fish while tipsy can be a little difficult.

**my only criticism is that i wish that they had some sort of seafood pasta dish.  also, for regular pacific-cafe-goers, it'd be nice to have a weekly special.

otherwise, it's a great place to bring your significant other, your friends, and out of town guests.  cheers to pacific cafe!
author: Ting A.

description:
I really wanted to like Pacific Cafe because there seemed to be a lot to like from my first impression.  Upon arriving the host hands you a complimentary free glass of wine, that's pretty awesome.  The waitress was attentive, ready all the specials and answered questions about the menu.

I started with a clam chowder which was probably the best I have ever had, it was strangely spicy and very unique.  However, the entree was a pathetic attempt at seafood (Sole in Newberg Sauce with Red Potatoes).  I have had frozen dinners with more taste and larger portions but at $25 this was completely unacceptable.  It was  soupy bowl with pieces of sole sprinkled throughout and despite all the sauce it had no flavor at all.  NONE.  The potatoes were simply baked, no seasoning, no presentation, just red potatoes rolling around on the plate.  I would pass on the Pacific Cafe or at the very least avoid the Sole in Newberg Sauce.

Here my breakdown for scoring:

Free Wine: 5 Stars
Service: 4 Stars
Atmosphere: 4 Stars
Appetizer: 4 Stars
Entree: 1 Star
Price (Value): 1 Star
author: Ryder M.

description:
They serve you free wine while you wait. That is such a great idea. We waited about an hour to be seated but I did not mind one bit. 

I had a white fish in this really thick and creamy lobster sauce. I didn't totally love the dish. I tend to order the wrong thing on occasion. I will definitely go back though.
author: Stacy F.

description:
One word.

"meh"

Stay away from this place because if you drive, it makes it rough to park in my neighborhood as well. There are better eats in the Richmond, seriously.
author: Jay S.

description:
This has always been one of my favorite restaurants in The City since my parents started taking me when we would visit when I was a kid.  This is not a four star place, and if your looking for a lavish meal of something you never tried or could make at home, this is not the place for you.  This is simple seafood (think traditional 1970's ish), done very well, in an intimate and nastolgic setting.

They do not take reservations, but the perk is you get free house wine while you wait (its house wine, not the best, but free and the wait is usually at least an hour if you come after 6pm).  There is limited waiting room inside, but seats outside; bundle up because it can be cold.  The menu varies little but there are daily specials so take a look at the chalk board near the kitchen.

I have never gone and not enjoyed myself here.  Maybe its the company, but there isn't a restaurant I have ever gone to where I have felt more at home.
author: Vince T.

description: This is a small but amazing seafood restaurant @ 34th and Geary in SF ~ we shared a wonderful dinner last night (Mike had the scampi and I had the stuffed turbot, yummmmm) and enjoyed a complimentary glass of wine while waiting ~ no reservations, but definitely worth planning ahead!
author: Marion P.

description:
Every time we drive by this place (often - we live just down Geary from it), we wonder why it's so packed. "It's not worth it!" we always think. 

We went here once, and the free (cheap tasting, naturally) wine was neat but a bit gimmicky. You really pay for it with the food. And in the 45+ we waited, she was never back for a refill... 

The food we received was not memorable apart from being pretty bad (apart from the starter soup - that was v good), and my husbands plate was tasteless and overcooked. His rare tuna was grey the whole way through (!!), and there was no sauce or anything to actually give it a bit of flavour. His "wasabi sauce" was actually a large hunk of wasabi like you'd get with sushi (???). My scallops had a very odd taste to them - like the butter (or whatever) was sour or off. I seem to recall it was accompanied with steamed vegetables or something ... And we were hungry when we left, but paid a ton for the meal (60-70 at least). 

We'll never be back - long wait for overpriced poorly prepared food when there's so much choice in SF -  however, sure, the atmosphere was nice and service OK.
author: Jen D.

description:
With most entrees listed in the $20 to $25 range, it will never qualify as a "deal", but the value you get here is consistently good quality seafood prepared in a way that makes the core ingredient the hero.  No fancy preparations to hide imperfections of the fish, but that's not to say some of the dishes can be rich.  Take, for instance the Turbot baked in parchment with crab and shrimp, or the top of their standard entree list, Sole stuffed with curried crab and shrimp in Newburg sauce.  Has it invoked a Pavolvian response from you yet?

The specials make it even more difficult to choose an entree as there typically are even more selections from THAT board then there are on the menu itself.  And they're all so tempting too (such as a combo plate of grilled wild salmon and scallops you could have either baked or fried).  Shoot me.

You can also choose your entree accompaniment:  rice, potato or veggie.  Pick the red potatoes and you'll get boiled potato -- I say go for the rice instead, or a veggie (you just might get a whole broccoli crown on your plate).

Appetizers?  Calamari vinaigrette is refreshing, the oyster bisque I had was a delicious and compact A-bomb of a meal in itself, and the shrimp louie I tasted was almost as rewarding (but I guarantee you won't like it if you're turned off by salad greens swimming in dressing).

Dessert?  You probably won't have any room left unless you save part of your entree in a to-go bag.

Everybody likes to comment on the free wine they pour for people waiting to dine.  What an effective ploy, I say -- the wine is remarkably bad and gave me a headache, but I say kudos to them for upholding some basic customer satisfaction principle.  But I say dine early or late, and you'll avoid the wait.
author: Alfonso E.

description:
AAAAAHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!!!!!!!!!

Again!  It's happened again.  I see a review from foodies getting all hyped up about a restaurant with a unique and original feel and menu, only to get so disappointed I want to dunk my head in the free wine they hand out.  

I freaking love Seafood and when I started to see Amazing Spiderman reviews for this place I naturally got that excited feeling down below.  

The fish was dry and had a texture as old as the wood varnish.  The scallops where quite bland as well.  The chowder had a gamey taste and no not the great Wharf type of fresh gaminess.  

Even the company whom I ate their with somehow managed to over promise and under deliver, AND I WAS THE ONE WHO TOLD THEM ABOUT THE RESTAURANT!  

Don't think I'll be heading here again unless I feel like driving my car through the old window.
author: patrick o.

description:
They don't take reservations, so come at peak dinner times and wait with your free wine, they'll keep it coming.  The fish is always really fresh (no farm or frozen) and their specials menu reflects what's available and usually has more items on it than the fixed menu.  Everything comes with soup or salad and a side, so the typical entree' price of about $24 is fair.  Their wine selection by the bottle is good and there are five or six by-the-glass.  

The place is old-school SF, opened in '74 or '75, it's small but cozy inside, not too loud, and they sat me right across from this cute little brunette last time I was there.  Service was great: fast, friendly, and not pushy.  And one of the other waitresses knew me from a night at Hockey Haven and bought our desert.  Parking is a little tight but just go down to Lincoln golf course and you'll appreciate that one block walk after dinner.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
Shhhh, this place is our secret. Don't tell ok? It's a secret for SF locals.

It's an old school SF seafood restaurant. Kind of a neighborhood joint. Decor circa 1978.You have to bet on a long wait which they sooth it with a free-bee glass or two of wine. It's not a dressy place.

The hot bread is yummy, soups and salads are delicious.  You review the menu posted on the chalkboards strategically placed around the restaurant.

Sweetie loves the sand dabs when they have them.  I can usually get him to even go see a chick flick with me if I suggest sand dabs from Pacific Cafe afterward. My favorite is the Parmesan halibut. Crunchy, savory, goodness. Throw a few red potatoes on the side and call it a meal.

It's not fancy schmancy food, but it's perfect for what it's meant to be.
author: Brandi L.

description:
I had been super excited to check out Pacific Cafe. I liked the retro-ness aspect I had heard about, and I do enjoy a "no-nonsense" meal once in a while (e.g., a nice piece of fresh fish cooked simply, vegetable side, good bread.)

Neat place...way out near the ocean, so it had the beachy quality which is great. Kind of gives it that "going on a mini-vacation in my own city" feeling! Good service, lots of smiles... 

To the food... right when you sit down, a basket of bread awaits (which was delicious.) Big slabs of sourdough w/chewy crusts and a big stick of butter. 

I started w/ the oyster bisque. Good enough, tasty...a little too thick for my taste and not hot enough (although I admit-I like my food piping hot.) My wife had a Caesar salad. Fine, nothing amazing...anchovies were the highlight.

And the fish...we ordered off the chalkboard. My wife got the Parmesan Halibut. Just OK. It was on the dry side...it tasted fine, but we weren't overwhelmed by any stretch. I had the Grilled Spicy Snapper. Again, OK. The fish, oddly enough, didn't seemed grilled, and just like the halibut, did nothing to overwhelm the senses. 

Expectations were met  in the "no-nonsense meal" sense. And we wanted to LOVE this place. However, the fish (the most important variable at the end of the day) just didn't do it for us--not awful, not outstanding--just kind of blah.
author: Carmine D.

description:
Looove Pacific Cafe!!! I have been coming here for year's and even before that my husband's family had been coming for almost 30 years. It is a great "local" place. Kind of off the beaten path, and from the street you could easily pass right by it. But it is wonderful. They are only open for dinner nightly, and often have a wait (which isn't bad because they give you free wine while you are waiting). They do not accept reservations, but that's not so bad when you are getting free wine while you wait. Their menu is awesome and changes daily, to include fresh, local seafood. Over the years I have tried the fried oysters, shrimp louie salad, oyster bisque, lobster bisque, salmon bisque, sand dabs,ahi, salmon, halibut,  fish in parchment paper, and virtually everything else. I have never disliked anything.
   The decor is vintage, but that is what makes this place unique to me, that it has been very succesful for so many years and hasn't really changed at all. We loooove the and always request for Frank to be our server. He is THE best server in SF, in my opinion!
author: Kay A.

description:
okay, let's start with the food. it's fresh but nothing fancy. the prices are fairly high and the portions are tiny.

and that infamous wait. yeah, you get wine when you're waiting but i don't feel like it's worth it, especially when you actually start eating and it's not enough to fill you up.

i live a few blocks away and the place is always packed. honestly, i don't know why so many people frequent this place. 

just wanted to give folks a fair warning before they visit.
author: Art O.

description:
I had yet another great outing at Pacific Cafe last night.  

The wait is long, so be prepared.  While waiting, you have options. You can
a) stay in line, drink  the free wine and converse with your companion or others in line
b) stay in line part of the time, drink a couple of glasses of wine and go to the Art Bistro coffeshop on 33rd and Geary and read magazines http://www.yelp.com/biz/OfbRaVdL41hRR65Y9UXMZw
c) just go to the coffeshop while you wait

Anyway, it's worth the wait!
The menu is simple.  Fresh Fish Galore!   

There are a lot of great seafood restaurants in SF, but I wish there were more like this that serve a varied selection of fresh fish, grilled, fried or baked.

The parmesan encrusted halibut is really to die for.  It's hard to imagine it would go so well together but it was indeed sensually perfect.   fresh succulent moist halibut in a  crusty chessy shell....mmmmmmm

The waitstaff is also attentive, knowledgeable and very fast.  

One warning:  The portions are huge.  i overate last night and had to go to bed at 8PM. absolutley stuffed.

sigh, great seafood
author: Spencer G.

description:
I hope my friends who took me there for my birthday dinner do not see this review, it was not their fault.  I expected the wait, and was  told 20 minutes when we arrived, but were seated over 1 hour later! The endless wine got a couple people in my party intoxicated.
Had to return my dish ( I almost never do that) because the fish was overcooked. I tried a little of my 3 friends dishes and they all tasted bland and uninteresting.
The service was ok, and the place has a homey feel, but the food reminds me of someone who takes a cookbook, follows it and does not have the ability to make the dishes creative. In other words, I have made better seafood dishes at home!
author: Bill B.

description: The Pacific Café is the bomb!! I haven't been here in about 10 years, but I use to go all the time!! The shrimp Louie is EXCELLENT, and although it's worth the wait and as you wait you also get FREE house wine!! This place was also established in 1975 when I was born!!! They don't take RSVP's but just go wait enjoy the wine and food, you'll keep coming back!!!!
author: christina a.

description: I absolutely love this place!..... I'm from San Jose so I don't go very often but every time I do I'm more than satisfied. Like most people I think it's great that they serve free wine while you wait (I recommend not drinking too much of it though, it's very strong) however, I wasn't even able to enjoy the free wine until recently because I was underage before. You see I've been coming here since I was a kid and I've always had a great experience. The atmosphere is very homely and welcoming. The waiters are always very kind and extremely attentive. All that is great but the food is superb! I love it and seafood is not exactly my favorite food. I recommend the crab cakes as well as the fried prawns. Delicious!
