This place is a tad bit pricey but definitely worth it. It's a great place for many different occasions and as long as it stays open I will keep returning.
author: Ashley K.

description:
My favorite, cynical gay friend who hates EVERYTHING and NEVER leaves his apartment took me to Pacific Cafe for my birthday. If a hermit who has no intention of getting in your pants offers to take you to dinner, you do not argue!

Pacific Cafe was packed. Crotchety old man dropped me off at the door to put our name down (they don't take reservations) and went off to find parking for the next 20 minutes. Fine by me - I enjoyed the free wine offered to waiting patrons. Automatic 3 stars before even being seated (not that they need it!)

The food was fantastic! We shared the calamari appetizer. I had a crab louie salad that was effing tasty as well. For the main course I tried the freshest, best-prepared halibut I've ever had!  We skipped dessert because we were both SO full (and had our girlish figures to worry about).

Amazing dinner, but the best part of the evening was my birthday gift: massage oil and batteries. Gotta love opening R-rated gifts in front of unsuspecting diners!
author: Valerie N.

description:
How can you not like a place where they serve you free wine while you wait for your table???  The friends we were with specifically come here hoping for a wait so that they can get their buzz on while waiting for a table.  They even serve wine outside on the benches in front of the restaurant if the inside is too full.  That in addition to the friendly service from Roy, our wine provider, just makes me the hugest fan of the place!  

Once we are drunk on free wine (which by the way is pretty good also), we get seated to a table with bread and butter awaiting us.  Our waiter is friendly and the service is great.  The food also is pretty good.  My favorite thing of the night was the oyster cocktail!  It was amazing...............After stuffing myself on bread, butter, and the oyster cocktail, I barely was able to eat my crab cake.  It was large and made of real crab.  Served with a few french fries and I was ready to roll out of the restaurant.  My BF had the sauteed shrimp scampi, and Ben and Jenny had the trout and the sole, I believe.  All of their dishes were good, in fact everything that everyone had was good.  We were a satisfied bunch.  

Can't wait to come back on another night when there is a super long line..................looking forward to the buzz and the filling dishes.  

(BTW, all the entrees come with an option of a carb (fries or rice) and soup or salad............so come on a night when you are hungry!)
author: Denise B.

description:
An old-school seafood joint in outer Richmond.  This place is sweet.  Be warned, if you are choosing seafood  as a healthy alternative, then this ain't your place.  Like I said, this is old school seafood cooked with plenty of butter or deep fried and served with enough carbs to make Atkins spin in his grave.  This is kind of like the food you get at one of the older Fisherman's Wharf establishments, heavy and delicious.  

There's almost always a wait but, as mentioned in every review here, they give you plenty of free wine. I went on a Sunday night at about 7 and had to wait about a half-an-hour, which isn't that bad I guess....

....especially with the free wine.
author: Mark G.

description:
Free wine while I wait?  Don't mind if I do.  Seriously, they had me from "hello, would you like a glass of wine?"

There can be a long wait, so like I was advised, get there early (but not too early, you still want to enjoy your crappy glass(es) of free wine).  As another reviewer put it, the food is classic.  The menu is simply, the fish is fresh, the sauces draped all over the fish are rich.  The desserts aren't bad either!

Parking is a challenge, so safe yourself the trouble and ride the bus!
author: Clara F.

description: Best seafood in SF. Small, neighborhood place. Bring your own wine.
author: Chuck V.

description:
Been coming here since college when my roomate overheard someone talking about it on the bus. We were a little leary, but we walked there and waited in line for over an hour while being plied with wine. We had the large table by the kitchen and had a memorable 2hr. dinner. We were pretty rowdy, but the noise level is pretty high, so nobody cared. The Turbot stuffed with shrimp & crab is still one of the best things on the menu. The Abalone steak and fried Pacific Oysters are favorites too. They have remained absolutely consistent over the years, while the one that was in Fisherman's wharf never could get the same formula. I love how they add a small Anchovy to the salad and the clam chowder is the best! 
Come here early or late as they don't take reservations.
author: Arlene C.

description:
If free wine is your thing, read paragraph 1.

(1) To ensure that you and your party recieve the maximum amount of free wine possible, show up from 6:30 - 7pm during peak hours.  You'll be waiting a while yes, but you'll be waiting with that glorious glass of free wine.  And when you finish that one, just put it to the side and zOMG they'll bring you another one.  Oh yea, and make sure you get a 3rd as you're being seated to avoid actually having to order any at the table. 

(2) Once you're actually seated, you'll see the menu which has about 9 or 10 main courses (of which i've had about 5 or 6).  Most of them are fairly good, with the exception of one of the Sole dishes, which was awful (it was the one with the sauce, sorry i cant remember the name, but watch out...seriously). Do yourself a favor and get one of the specials, which are usually far better than the normal menu stuff.
author: Eric W.

description:
This restaurant has set the bar for me in terms of crab cakes. Seriously people, you have to try their crab cakes. It doesn't look like much when they bring it to you (I apologize for not having pictures...I forgot to bring my camera with me), but when you take that first bite, it melts in your mouth. Be sure to savor every bite you take. It doesn't come cheap.

The entrees were good too. I ordered the Parmesan Halibut. I was a little skeptical at first, but the texture of the halibut and the tang of the cheese actually worked pretty well together. I ordered it with rice (which was nothing special), so be sure to order it with fries. Crispy golden brown goodness on the outside, and soft deliciousness on the inside. 

The desserts weren't very good. My cousin ordered the apple crumb dessert. It wasn't even warm (which is how ALL desserts that are baked SHOULD be)! Still, we killed it. 

The service was really good at this place too. Every time I drank HALF the water, someone would come by and pour some more water. Like...if ninjas were to serve you water at a restaurant, it would sorta be like the waiters here at Pacific Cafe. It might be because I don't pay attention to these kinds of things, but I never noticed people coming by. I only noticed my water being full every time I went to grab it.

Take home points: eat the crab cakes, get down on the free wine before you go inside (if you want to really enjoy the food, then don't get too wasted), don't expect too much from the dessert, and just enjoy yourself a good meal!
author: Daniel M.

description:
*The BF and I tried this place last night upon referral from his co-worker. We are no longer taking recommendations from said co-worker. Before any of you read this scathing review, please note that I have worked in three restaurants, even managing one of them. So as far as food and service go, I almost ALWAYS grade very leniently.*

Sure, we get free wine while we wait for 20 minutes for a table of two at 730 on a Wednesday, but we also get to wait 20 minutes for ANYONE to even acknowledge we've sat down. I mean, seriously, even a simple, "Sorry, we're so busy tonight. Someone will be right with you." would've quelled our impatience. To boot, the couple who came in 5 minutes after us, sat down 5 minutes after us, got served 10 minutes BEFORE us. Nice.

As for the quality of service that finally did show its face? Let's just say he left something to be desired. Jerk. Don't freaking rush me when you took 20 minutes to even come over to our table. We saw him visit the same table three times before he even started in our direction. The whole time we sat there, I wasn't sure who was actually supposed to be our server. Quality. We had to flag down a different server to actually get the bill. I actually considered just walking the credit card up to our server just to expedite the process.

The food itself is overpriced, and as far as seafood goes, I had the Snapper "spicy" special, and my boyfriend had the Sole Newburg. His was alright  but nothing special (he didn't even take the half he didn't eat home). As for mine, it was spicy, but I don't consider fish dredged with spices on the outside, and bland and mushy on the inside "tasty." 

Bottom Line: You might as well stay at home and try and cook yourself if you want seafood like this. There are plenty of other options in the City. Try those instead.

It gets one star for the generous amount of wine, and for the awesome "Pacific Clam Chowder," which is basically more on the butter, less on the cream/milk New England, but yes, it was definitely tasty.
author: Sachi T.

description:
They give you all the house wine (your choice of red or white) while you wait which is nice..because..you will wait.
Their marinated calamari appetizer was okay but I doubt I would order it again.  Basically if you want fresh fish prepared in a rather minimalist fashion check them out. Oh and the wasabi mashed potatoes were pretty good but could use a bit more kick.
author: Natalie G.

description:
It's amazing how free wine can make the wait for this restaurant so bearable. Pacific Cafe serves up great American style seafood. The food is simple, but filling and worth the wait. 

Things to note:
1. They don't take reservations, but they totally make up for this by offering free wine while you wait. And the longer the wait, the more refills you get. It's just table wine, but wine is wine, and after my second glass I don't even realize that I've been waiting 30 minutes for my table.
2. Entrees come with a salad or soup. You can choose from their clam chowder or, my favorite, a shrimp louis salad. And it comes with lots of shrimp for a side salad that is included in the meal. 

I have tried most of their dishes, but the only one that I didn't like was the Ahi tuna steak. It was a bit overcooked for my taste. Otherwise, great halibut parmesan, good trout, fresh scallops. Also love the crab cocktail. 
Service is usually great. Attentive waiters, timely service. Price is reasonable for good seafood. Parking is a pain. The wait can get long. So I'd recommend going on a weeknight or going early on the weekends.
author: Jessie C.

description:
Every time my parents come to town from the East Coast, I try and try to find a restaurant that we'll all like. Nothing too spicy, no sushi, nothing too far removed from the Italian restaurants, good Irish pubs, and other traditional Northeast American fare.

I took my folks to Pacific Cafe, and it was just perfect. We went on a Friday night, but with the glass of gratis chablis, the nice park benches outside, and the beatific smile on the waitress/hostess, the wait didn't seem long at all. We ordered the calimari vinaigrette, and the calimari was nice and tender--not at all chewy like at many places that serve unfried calimari. I had the ahi tuna steak, which was delicious. Service was friendly and efficient, and the atmosphere was warm and inviting. And for you ladies, there's a funny message in the bathroom stall.

The only reason I'm not giving it 5 stars is that they don't have oysters in summer! My mom was so disappointed!
author: Nicole S.

description:
Yo fog-challenged drivers, even if you have to use sonar, navigate your way to the Pacific Cafe. It's a very down-home, friendly, warm-hearted spot. There are only two drawbacks: 1. It's located in the OUTER Richmond (you're practically breathing salt water in those outer ave's); 2. waits can be as long as 40+ minutes on weekend nights; 3. Did I say it's in the OUTER Richmond already? On the Plus Side: Fantastic Oyster Bisque; amazing mussels; great tasting fish dishes. The Clinchers: free wine while you wait; Mitchell's Rum Raisin and Zanze's Cheesecake on the apres meal menu; really nice owner who works the floor as well!!

Good date place. Great place to meet up with old friends, out of towners or family. Table/booth seating works best for parties of of 2-4, but the table of 6 I saw seemed to be having all kinds-o-fun. 

4 yelpstars w/ one extra for the Mitchell's RR.
author: Johnny C.

description:
My story of the Pacific Cafe starts in April 1976;  I had just moved to Palo Alto from SoCal and I was cruising on Geary Blvd. at about 5:15 headed to the Cliff House when I caught a glimpse of a very long line outside of what appeared to be a restaurant.  At the next block (35th) I made a fast right turn, went around the block, double parked (didn't take me long to pick up on that nasty San Francisco habit) and jumped outta my car.  I started interviewing the people outside the restaurant (there were several) with glasses of wine in their hands and they all raved about the place.  I usually don't like waiting for a table so I mentioned that and I was adviced to show up at about 4:45, 15 minutes before it opened and I would get right in.

The next day, I did just that and got right in.  Well, I've always been a seafood lover (did lots of deep sea fishing, crabbing and claming growing up) so I know good seafood when I see and taste it; I wasn't dissappointed.  The sour dough bread was to die for.  I quickly learned that forget about the butter on your bread and instead ask for the tartar sauce as soon as you sit down and dip your bread in it.  I don't know what their secret is with that sauce, but take it from someone who ordinarily disdains that sauce on seafood or anything else, this stuff is world class.

Anyway, as the years went by I feasted on their simply prepared halibut, salmon, swordfish, occasionally sea bass. (I would always remove the big square of butter that they put on top and instead used the tartar sauce -fab-U-lus.)   Then one year I stumbled upon the Louisiana Shrimp, WOW (provided, you are a garlic lover).  I discovered something new to dip that fabulous bread in- as well as those fried potatoes.  Let me pause here about the side choices of those fries, rice and red round potatoes.  Unless you are a glutton for punishment, DO NOT order anything other than the fries.  The rice and red potatoes are hopeless boring and besides with the fries you can dip them into the tartar sauce as well as the garlic sauce of the Louisiana Shrimp.  And speaking about the extras, the price of the entree includes clam chowder or salad.  Can't go wrong with either so long as you are not expecting some heavy cream based boston type chowder.  If that is your cup of soup, better go for the salad.  However, if you are willing to be a little adventuresome, then indeed try the chowder (dip a little bread in it) and add a little pepper and tabasco sauce to it, you'll love it.  As for the salad, I usually go for the tasty Louie dressing (also something to dip some bread in-- I guess by now you realize I love dipping that sour dough in anything that tastes great (just not butter).

As far as the appetizers, forgot the oysters because as much as I love this place, me thinks those things are out of a can.  If you like tangy, unfried seafood try the marinated calamari- very tasty indeed (don't forget to dip some bread in that light sauce).  When crab is in season go for the crab cocktail or any crab entree offered.

All this and I haven't even mentioned the free wine while you wait.  It took me 10 years to get into that.  The reason is that I was in no mood to wait anywhere from 30 to 75 minutes for a table.  Well as luck would have it, one day because of traffic I arrived at 5:15 and had to wait the standard hour.  And the free wine started poring.  Damn, I said, what was I thinking all those years?  From now on I show up and wait the darn average of 30-45 minutes and enjoy the wine.  I also learned that very interesting people are waiting in line with you and you can have some terrific conversations with them.  It is always interesting hearing their story about when they first discovered the place.  While most are from SF and the rest from around the Bay Area, you'll find the occasional tourist who has stumbled onto the it and of course will have an interesting tale of how they found the place.

Lastly, there is the staff and the water.  Back in '76, I was a 12-13% tipper (hey, what you'd expect? I was just a young guy.)  When I go to Pacific Cafe I usually tip about 25% (that's just me).  I have come to know and love the several people who have worked there for years and years and years.  When I am there, it feels like home.  As for the water, well its Hetch Hetchy water, the best water in the world; it's mountain water right there in SF.

So, go to Pacific Cafe enjoy the free wine, the people waiting with you, the 70s decor (at least they repaint the place often and in fact have modernized their choice of orange; it's now more of a burnt orange), the staff and of course that stupendous bread, water, tartar sauce and fish (and remember don't get the rice or red boiled potatoes).
author: Frank G.

description:
Great great seafood place. & it's not THAT far! The city's only 7x7!

FOOD:~Grilled salmon was the best. Theirs & the salmon i had at Michael Jordan's restaurant 23 in North Carolina were the best salmon I've ever had in my LIFE.

~Baked scallops: good if a bit rubbery. Love the garlic butter.

~Halibut parmesan: fish a tad dry, but the parmesan crust was super delicious. 

~Oyster bisque: good, but didn't live up to expectations set by other Yelpers. Too many chewy oysters in there for my taste.

SERVICE: Extremely helpful, polite, kind, friendly, classic.

DECOR: Amusing articles & old menus for decoration. I love the sense of history!

BATHROOM: Single stall. Why cut off access to the sink? Small, low ceiling, cute.

OVERALL: will DEFINITELY BE GOING BACK.
author: miss b.

description:
I enjoyed my time at Pacific Cafe.  You start off with a free glass of wine while you wait.  And if you are there on a busy night, you might end up with 2 or 3 glasses of wine.  Its a small place so you will wait an hour or more.  If you love to drink for free, this shouldn't be a problem.

I ordered the Calamari Steak and it was delicious.  It was exceptionally good the night I went and I couldn't tell if it was the wine talking but I really enjoyed it.  You get a choice of soup or salad and a side with your order.  I choose the Caesar salad, which just a typical Caesar salad, and the rice pilaf, which again was not great but not bad.

Once you're seated you get a basket of bread.  I kind of wish they would serve you this as you wait because if you're hungry and just drinking wine you can get pretty tipsy until you are seated.

Overall, a fun outing to the Outer Richmond and a place I will visit again.
author: Bianca R.

description:
This is probably my favorite restaurant in the bay area. I've been coming here since 1974! This place is an icon, on the level of Legal Seafood in Boston.

Most everything is fresh, presented simply, perfectly cooked. Salads are great, desserts are killer. very good wine list, warm intimate interior. I strongly recommend dishes from the fresh menu, the chalkboard; the regular menu dishes are very good, but not as over-the-top as the fresh menu.  Service is good, usually outstanding. Most of the folks who work there have been there for decades. No reservations. You get a glass of wine if you have to wait for a table, and between 6:15 and 8:30, you will have to wait 20-45 minutes. This is a popular restaurant, well known and loved.

The building is older and a bit eclectic, with a tile entrance that harks back to a century ago.  Lighting is balanced, decor is historic, the finishes are rustic, functional and pleasant.  It's cheerful and noisy inside, but not overwhelmingly loud. 

The wait is hard on kids, so if you bring them, arrive before 6. There is only one table that will seat more than 4, so this is not the place for a large group...however it's great for a group of 4.  The restaurant is wheelchair-accessible, but I wouldn't recommend it during peak dinner hours.  People will be polite and helpful, but you'll have to maneuver through a crowd and around moveable partitions, down somewhat narrow passages between booths.
author: Tom C.

description:
In terms of seafood restaurants, Pacific Cafe is as good as it gets...and this is coming from a non seafood eating person.  I love that it's decor is all original from it's opening in 1974, homey feel and family friendly.  Service is great--greeted with a free glass of chilled white wine as you wait by a smiling friendly host.  The servers are attentive and friendly as well. 

So, again, I'm no seafood lover by any means, so the fact that I've gone to this restaurant twice in the last two years say a lot.  The sourdough bread they serve is usually still toasty and lovely, that my party and I can eat two baskets full no problem.  Every entree is served with a soup or salad and a side of rice, potatoes or veggies of the day.  My companions and I may be boring, but go with what we love; we all order the halibut parmesan, and I order it with a side of steamed broccoli.  With a little lemon and some tartar sauce, that piece of fish is as good as a steak (well not  exactly, but i would imagine so if I was a pescatarian, which one of my companion was).   The crusty goodness is delicious and only heightened by the lemon.  Mmmmmmm...I'm looking forward to my leftovers!  And that's another thing, the portions are generous.  

Go to Pacific Cafe for simple, no frills, well seasoned seafood and exceptional service.  I might have to take my non seafood, hamburger eating boyfriend once for a change of pace.
author: Marie B.

description:
The Pacific Cafe is San Francisco at its finest. It's in the Outer Richmond, so it has no way to be trendy even if it tried, which of course is great. It's a hole in the wall and you will wait about an hour to be seated, but they will serve you free wine in the meantime. 

The menu and specials never seem to change, but they know how to do well what they know how to do. The servers are long-time, career people who are efficient, courteous and helpful. 

This place is perfect for treating out of town east coasters to something a little more their pace. Forget Union Square and "Swig" or whatever the latest place is called, and go to Pacific Cafe. I don't even care if I have to wait longer. That just means more free wine.
author: alexandria r.

description:
My favorite restaurant in The City.  It's always nice to get free wine while you wait (yeah, it's house, but come on), and the wait usually isn't too long, which you will probably have to do since they don't take reservations.
The food is fantastic, and the atmosphere is great.  Genuinely nice people.  In fact, I've met the owner a couple times when I was there, and he's a real nice guy.
A little story:  I went with my family when they were in town once, and long story short, my grandpa and the owner's father had both been stationed at Point Reyes with the Coast Guard.  He ended up sending my grandpa a print of a photo he had taken of Point Reyes, after meeting him once.  Made my grandpa's year, and, yeah, helped make me love this place even more.
author: Chris M.

description:
I've enjoyed PC for years, for simple grilled fish, rice and salad. I usually order the salmon and scallops combination---not cheap ($25?). The baked scallops were, once upon a time, 5 or 6 plump fresh scallops baked in garlic butter in a small pyrex dish. They have always been meltingly delicious, and I order the same thing all the time, because by the time I get around to going to PC, I'm fairly craving it.

 The last time I was there a couple weeks ago, the scallops were not whole, but rather, had been sliced in halves or thirds and arranged in the usual dish looking the same, until I cut into them and found them to be slivers of scallops. Bummer. The price of the dish has not been reduced, just the portion size. I deduct stars from what would have been a 4 or 5 star review. Meh, I've experienced better, indeed...at the PC just a few months ago! Such a drag.
author: m c.

description:
This place is expensive and what you are paying for is the "free" wine, bread, and "caesar" salad made entirely of iceberg lettuce.  Everything on the menu is $20-$40 and the entree itself is not worth that much.  

I had the crab cakes (they looked nowhere near as good as the picture posted here on yelp) and they were really lackluster.  My friend had the shrimp scampi and it was kind of tasteless as well.  The entree + fries definitely doesn't fill the plate -- the size of the portions was pretty shocking given the price.  

So, if you think you are going to drink and eat your fill of wine and bread, I guess this would be a good deal.  I don't drink, so I felt pretty ripped off at $52 for a mediocre meal for 2 (no appetizer, no dessert, no beverage, no coffee/tea).
author: Kelly M.

description:
This is a great place to go when you have out of town guests and want to catch up.  You can make an entire evening out of a visit here since the wait can be rather long.  This is our favorite restaurant in the city for the following reasons:

(1)   Atmosphere--the atmosphere is wonderful with happy people chit-chatting and enjoying each other and themselves!  The wait may take up to 2 hours, but this is where to do it!  It's like a party.  The decor is warm and inviting.

(2)  Service--friendly and efficient staff.  Many employees have been around for decades.

(3)  Free Wine--chilled white wine that's not bad!  You can also request sodas or red wine.  The free wine makes it all happen!

(4)  Food--the food is fresh and delicious...especially the crab cakes.

(5)  Dessert--completes the meal.

(6)  History--this restaurant has been around since the 70s.  A lot of history has occurred here.  There's a photo book in the wait area documenting all who have enjoyed this SF establishment.  We met 4 80 year old Korean War vets who LOVE this restaurant.  They drive down to SF from Sacramento just to visit!!  I'd trust their judgment and enthusiasm for Pacific Cafe over others' who have posted here.

ENJOY!
author: The Puppydawg ..

description: This place is a San Francisco gem. It's been around longer than I've been alive, and manages to maintain an "old San Francisco" feel while not coming across as outdated. Every entree comes with a free glass of wine (!!), and every entree is delicious! This place is a classic, and never disappoints in food or service.
author: Allison D.

description:
You want an old-school, unpretentious seafood place?  This is it.

We had to wait, and like everyone else, took part in the complementary wine.  It was a nice, simple wine.  Foodies/wine geeks - don't expect a vineyard designate or something complex for free.  It wouldn't fit with the place anyway.

I got the calamari steak and was happy.  The people with snapper and crab cakes were really happy.  As was the person with the fried shrimp.  I got broccoli with mine (personal choice) and it was not drowned in butter as others have reported.

Don't forget to ask for your dressing on the side with your salad - they use a heavy hand. 

I wish I had room for dessert, as they have Mitchell's ice cream.

I'd go back without hesitation.
author: Lil P.

description:
This is my second time coming here, and I'm sorry to say that this place taste really plain to my standards. I gave it a second chances because every time I drive back home I would see a long line, assuming that this place has improve. 

Man was I wrong, this place is pretty much a tourist attraction. If you want real seafood, go visit the fisherman wharf. Lots more to offer over there.
author: William C.

description: My wife has passed this place a thousand times.  Its small but actually is bigger on the inside than it looks like outside.  If you are looking for someplace to eat for lunch..then this is not your place..they are only open from 5 p.m. to 9 p.m.  That being said we loved this place.  We got there about 15 minutes early and there was already a crowd waiting.  While you wait the host hands out free wine to those patrons old enough to drink it.  I thought that was a nice touch.  Get them drunk so they'll order more.  Menu was easy to read...and the specials were written out on the board.  There seemed to be more specials than menu items.  Everything was fresh...Loved the Salmon bisque and the stuffed fillet of sole.  Reminded me of the old harbor restaraunts, cozy and friendly.  If your in the area...this is a must try.  I will definitely be a return customer.
author: Rob A.

description: This place is just okay in my books. It is pretty hyped up since it has been around SF forever and you have to line up before it even opens to get a seat. I think it is extremely over priced for the type of food you are getting. The price may be due to how fresh it is, but everything I tasted here has absolutely no flavor. The service is great, but the food to me is just mediocre. I have definitely had better seafood.
author: Lia C.

description: Another fantastic dinner this evening. I arrived shortly after 7:00 and then had to wait awhile-nothing unusual. The excellent Salmon/Prawn combo-baked to perfection was delectable-not dry, not over or under cooked. How these chefs do the consistently excellent job they do year after year (I've been going there since the '70's), is beyond me. New hostess friendly and efficient despite letting a couple seat before me who were after me on the wait list :(- OK, I'm over it. The perils of dining singly...); and they didn't have my favorite carmel praline ice cream, but the mocha fudge (Mitchell's so I needn't say more but I will) was creamy and generously marbled with a bittersweet chocolate contrasting nicely with the mocha flavor.  They know how to make a pot of tea that is actually hot when you get it and it steeps merrily in the little pot, staying hot enough to brew a strong cup.
author: Chris B.

description:
There is a reason this place is busy despite the fact that it is so far out 'in the middle of nowhere', by SF standards.  OTOH, those of us neighborhood-oriented SanFranciscans understand the value of our local gems.  

The one negative-this place does not take reservations, so don't arrive hungry!  It is a first-come, first seated place with a small waiting area-some have to wait outside.  The nice thing is that you get complimentary house wine while you wait!

The wait-staff is friendly and helpful.  The food is fresh and good.  Once you are seated, you aren't at all crowded in; in fact, all tables are spaced quite well.

This is a great place to have a pleasant dinner in a pleasant atmosphere.
author: Leslie W.

description: Really fresh Fish, served by very professional staff ,I have being coming here with my wife for over twenty years and it just keeps getting better.
author: Gerard O.

description: If you want fresh and delicious fresh fish, this is place. The menu is simple and almost never changes. You get big slices of fish cooked to perfection along with friendly service. My suggestion is to come early, like when they open, or be prepared to wait. Waiting isn't so bad because they give you free wine and continue to fill your glass while you wait!
author: Adelina W.

description:
Good basic Fish...nothing fancy...far away from the wharf and the high prices for bad food. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a home cooked fish meal.

This way your house doesn't smell like fish!
author: John D.

description:
For the past year, my dear friend and I have had a standing engagement at the Pacific Cafe on Wednesday nights. We roll in around 6:30, chug a glass or two of free white wine and, when our name comes up, we slide into a wood-paneled booth.  As others have noted, the free wine is a brilliant strategy. If I ever arrived at the Pacific Cafe and there wasn't a wait, I'd feel a little let down. We give each other pep talks ("chug-a-lug!") to get the most of our waiting time. 
 
The Pacific Cafe is so reliable. There is nothing particularly innovative about the menu and innovation would be inappropriate.  It seems only right that rust figures prominently into the Pacific Cafe's color palette. But alas, this is the rust of comfort and not neglect. As some fathers say, if it ain't broke don't fix it. 
 
Without fail, I order the crab cakes with red potatoes and the caesar salad or, in crab season, the crab bisque. The wait staff has me all figured out; they know they don't have to ask. The same size and shape as hockey pucks, the dense, creamy crab cakes have a brown buttery crust.  They are satisfying with fresh lemon squeezed on them.  The potatoes are plain old boiled potatoes--undisguised, undressed--just as the lord intended.  . . . and all this with a sourdough bread slice with cold, salted butter. mmm. 
 
I have only strayed from this choice a few times and I was somewhat disappointed--I found the parmesan halibut to be bland and the clam chowder seemed to have more gristly bits of sand than most. However, I did appreciate that the clam chowder has a little kick.
author: Leslie P.

description:
They serve complimentary wine while you wait.  Need I say more? Actually, though the house wine is pretty terrible, it definitely helped ease the waiting time.

Maybe I was a bit tipsy by the time we had been seated (ah hah! that's their secret), but to my recollection, the food was really tasty!  Now, I've heard mixed reviews about the freshness and quality of the entrees, but maybe it's a hit or a miss?  The day I went, it was definitely a hit.  I ordered the parmesan halibut with rice and I have to say that it was amazingly succulent.  The parmesan encrusted the outside of the fish, while the inside was tender and moist.  The rice complimented the halibut very well.  My friend, Tim, ordered the fried scallops which were a bit overdone, but still tasted incredible.

The whole dinner lasted a bit longer than I would have liked, but that may be because this place was packed by 8pm (I think it only opens for dinner at 5pm).  Anyway, be prepared to shell out quite a bit, since the entrees are quite pricey...
author: Anjali M.

description: I'm really sorry to be the downer on this one, but this is the second time I've tried this place and I have to say it's not good. I went for a Seafood experience and what we got was soggy, greasy tasteless food. I had the crab cakes and my friend had the scallops. Who deep fries scallops?? The service is great, the complimentary wine is fantastic and the ambiance is pleasant but I'm afraid to say I'm not going back for the food.
author: Michelle H.

description: Oh, San Francisco.  How I wish we could be together, but you have your life there with your wonderful seafood restaurant...tempting your keep with free wine that tastes better with every glass...your fresh calamari vinaigrette that would have melted on my tongue had I been eating it in Phoenix.... why, why must we be apart?  The Pacific Cafe is overall the best seafood restaurant I've ever had the pleasure to experience. Fresh catches, laidback San Franciscans, a patio that rolls itself out to the locals and out of towners alike... and the wait staff is the best. No pretentiousness, just chill people and fantastic seafood. Parting with San Francisco is such sweet sorrow, but I'll always have the memory of you, spicy red snapper...
author: Joanna W.

description:
I'd call Pacific Cafe retro except that implies an intentional effort to be old school.  This restaurant is simply unchanged, so the decor and menu are entirely authentic.  The free wine makes the inevitable wait for a table in this tiny restaurant much more palatable.  The service isn't fancy and the preparations aren't elaborate, but the fish is fresh and tasty.  

In addition to a small regular menu (featuring my grandmother's favorite Fillet of Sole Newburg) there are extensive specials, organized by whether they are grilled, sauteed and fried.  The bay shrimp cocktail is sweet and succulent and I really like the shrimp Louie salad.  

To a palate accustomed to medium-rare salmon, dusted with Moroccan spices and served served with kumquat jam and couscous, the preparations can seem barebones, almost bland.  I really enjoy the simplicity of such a, well, retro expierance.  It's seafood made comfort food, and it tastes like modern American history.
author: Martha S.

description:
We got here just before 5 o'clock on a Friday evening and the line was starting up.  I got a parking space across the street, so I had a real good vibe about Pacific Cafe.  I haven't visited for over twenty years and tended to avoid it because of the typical long waits.  The staff began seating just after 5:00 PM, but we already got our complimentary glass of white wine.  We have often wondered if the food tasted better because of the wait and wine.

Nice selection, especially with the specials.  I had the "combo"; salmon and baked scallops, and the wife had the fried sand dabs.  Both dinners came with soup/salad, choice of potatoes or rice pilaf, and plentiful sourdough bread.  The portions were generous and tasty.  The service was polite.

A bit difficult to recommend to visitors because it lacks the touristy flavor of Fisherman's Wharf, but you can always recommend the sunset at Ocean Beach.
author: Collin W.

description:
This is by far one of my favorite places in the city to come eat. If you like fish this is the only place for you. Great ambiance and always filled with locals so you know it's good. 

Their soups are out of this wordl! I love them...especially their bisques. The lobster is perfect, deep fried shrimp are my favorite, and they make a great salad.

All the p[eople that work there are fabulous. From the owners to the servers (which are usually one in the same) to the chefs......all fantastic. They definitely make you feel welcome and at home and keep me coming back time and time again. If this place is not one of your standard go to's then you need to adjust your list.

It is generally very busy so don't forget to put your name on the list. The free wine they give you seriously makes the wait a breeze and there is a waiting area to sit down in....though small it is quite cozy.

Go here now.....yes right now. Well make sure they are open first.....it's dinner only here.
author: Josh J.

description: 1st of all, I probally got lucky because there was no wait for my friend & I! But food was all that, salmon was fresh, bread & soup was fresh, overall it exceeds standards if you love seafood...
author: Mitch A.

description: Absolutely fantastic. Great food, excellent service and complimentary wine while you wait for you table. Flawless.
author: Roxanne M.

description: The restaurant has been around since 1974.  It is cute small neighborhood joint with only 15 tables. I came here on a Friday evening with my best friend around opening time and we waited for about 20 minutes. We were served complimentary white wine during our wait. I started with the clam chowder. It was not too creamy but flavorful with vegetables and clams - yum! I also had the fried scallops, which were breaded and friend nicely and came with a generous shrimp louie salad and red potatoes. My best friend had the parmesan crusted halibut with the side of fries and caesar salad. Very juicy and delicious! The staff was friendly and attentive as well. "A taste of old San Francisco!"
author: Kaila Y.

description:
Long wait - key is to catch the 'wave' every 45 minutes or so.  It's as if the restaurant empties out, then fills back up all at once.  Good thing is that while you're in line, you get a complimentary glass of wine.

The place is small, dark and loud.  I love it.  The food is good, but not cheap for a local place.  The seating is mostly booths, so bigger parties will be fighting for the one larger round table they have setup in one corner.

My favorite meal starts with the Shrimp Louie salad (not the one from the menu - this one comes with the meal).  Then Turbot Baked In Parchment.  Fresh fish stuffed with crab and shrimp in a light cream sauce.  Pair that with the rice pilaf...  Ohhhhh yeah!  

It's a simple menu, with fresh and tasty treats.  Daily specials, so don't forget to look up on the chalk board above the kitchen.
author: Denise M.

description:
I'm always a sucker for the out-of-the-way places that feel like a secret, and Pacific Cafe delivers good service, free wine while you wait, and quality seafood (there is one steak on the menu for you fish haters). My tuna last Friday night was a good size, but sinewy and not very warm. Fresh veggies and good wine selection. 

I give it three and a half stars for cozy atmosphere, fresh ingredients, and simple presentation.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
Excellent service, great food -- even the wait wasn't too outrageous (yes, the complimentary wine helps ease the time).  It's best to go with company you want to spend lots of time talking to.  You'll have enough time to catch up with each other before your table is called. We went at 6pm on Thursday and were told it would be a 1/2 hour wait.  It was really slightly more than one hour.

Seafood is top-notch.  Steak was fine.  This is a seafood restaurant, so I have no idea why my husband ate steak.  Wonderful ambiance, warm and inviting.
author: Charlye W.

description:
DELICIOUS, WARM, FRIENDLY but sadly, expensive... i would not say overpiced, however.  big diff. 

we were served immediately with free wine (they will give you something else of your choice if you do not drink) and though they do not take reservations, the wait was not bad at all. 

i had one of the daily specials: salmon and crab newburg with red potatoes and a very nice shrimp louie salad. very very yummy and they are not shy with the bread.

THE STAFF IS ONE OF THE BEST I HAVE ENCOUNTERED IN THE CITY.
author: Sharonrose B.

description:
My friend treated me to dinner at Pacific Cafe on my birthday.

We had to wait about 15 minutes for a table which was absolutely no problem since we sat by the window as they served us wine. Free booze? That's worth five stars on its own.

This dimlit corner restaurant has a very warm, cozy feeling and I felt very at home there. 

To start off, I had a caesar salad with anchovies. Same as any caesar salad but I luuuuurrrvvv anchovies...mmmmmm. Then I had a delicious parmesan-crusted halibut. It was a very flavorful, buttery fish with a nice crispy, parmesan crust that wasn't too cheesy.

I can't remember what my friend had, but I was not ashamed to eat off her plate and I do recall it being just as delicious. I can't wait to go back to this place and try some other stuff.
author: James Y.

description:
5 stars.. is it because the food rates it? no.  The food is OK.  It's even been disappointing one or two times.  Is it because the ambiance is so great?
Nope, not even very comfortable.  Is it the free wine... well maybe, but not because its great wine.  But when you are sitting around this very popular place and are drinking free wine, you meet interesting people, and funny people and it is relaxing and so Outer Richmond.  Don't come here if you are in a hurry, don't come if you are a big time foodie, but if you want to relax and hang out and meet and talk and just chill, this is an awesome place.  Hard to find parking, but you can park down the street at the Golf course parking lot.. its only a friggin' block.  Do it.
author: Sarah H.

description: Enjoyable place with good food. Primarily seafood menu. Parking was a challenge due to residential location. Service was excellent.
author: Serge L.

description:
My expectations were high and met! The cheap wine is just the thing to make an hour and a half wait ok (we got there at opening and the line was already long enough to fill every table), and my mom (who is very impatient) was fine with waiting since we had a nice little seat and a nice little glass.

The food! Amazing, prawns with nothing on them and they are just perfect, no need to dip in the butter they bring you (and believe me, I am a butter dipping in kind of Kate). Everything is simple and fresh and cooked perfectly...
author: Kate M.

description:
Though I have been living in SF all my life, this was my first time to this 37 year old establishment!! Arrived just before 6 and got the last table available (this was on a Saturday night). The complimentary wine was served as soon as we sat down! Service was great all through our dinner! The decor and atmosphere was casual and comfortable. Mostly booth style tables. Crab cakes appetizers were $18 for two cakes but they were chock-ful of fresh crab meat, not fillers so definitely worth it! 
I had the turbot with shrimp and crab in parchment. For those of you who don't know, like me, turbot is a Mediterranian sole. Firm white filets covered with creamy shrimp and crab white sauce all cozily wrapped and baked in parchment. They cut it open for you when it is brought to the table. My friends had the sole newburg and parmesan halibut...both fresh and yummy as well! Our entrees came with either soup (salmon bisque or clam chowder) or salad (ceasar or shrimp louie) Loved my shrimp louie...will have to have that as a dinner selection next time!! Though we were tempted to have a few of their special desserts on the board, my friends had already planned a special outing to Ghiradelli square for some sundaes! For the three of us, an $80 price tag for fresh seafood, great service and free wine and unlimited bread, butter and fresh lemon wedges is a steal in San Francisco!! Check it out!! This place is no reservations and limited crazy Geary street parking.
author: Naomi N.

description: Waiting sucks, but being compensated with wine to wait for a table is a good thing. I have been here a few times, have always had to wait a while, and have left happy, full and warm. Very reliable seafood place that is adored by the locals and has tons of character.
author: John D.

description: Good service, nice place, but it's a bit over priced. I thought the food was just average.
author: R G.

description: I usually order the calamari steak, but I decided to have the oyster cocktail for an appetizer. I have a cast iron stomach, but I came down with food poisioning 24 hours later. Dont know if it was the oysters, but that won't deter me from returning to Pacific Cafe.
author: Dan P.

description: This is my favorite seafood place in the city.  My favorite is the crab coctail and the sturgeon dore.
author: jack l.

description: Been going for years and always pleased. You have to wait sometimes hours, however, some of the best seafood and they give you wine while you wait! Yummy Yummy Yummy! The parmesan crusted halibut is soooo delicious. The caesar salad is one of the best, and the same with the louis salad. Well worth the wait!
author: Danielle A.

description: It's a rainy winter night and you've exhausted the aisles of Green Apple Books on Clement.  Your path leads you to Geary Blvd. And you instinctively head toward the Avenues. Soon you pass the neon lights. 30th, 31st, then at 34th a light beckons from the corner. It's nothing to look at, but the warm glow draws you in. Wine is handed to you as you enter and step back in time. This is where the soul of Old San Francisco is preserved. Fresh fish of the day is written on blackboards above the kitchen. Sand dabs, crab cakes and abalone are listed. Small wooden booths create a very "shippy" feel. The food of course is predictably top notch, but the price is astonishingly reasonable. A platter of fish, wine and a shrimp louis for under $25. It doesn't get better than this.
author: Philip M.

description: This is one of my favorite SF restaurants, I've been going since I was a little girl (so I think its great for well behaved children!) The food has always been excellent, service amazing, and who can disagree with a free glass of wine while you wait for a table! Granted the place is very small and the wait can be upwards of an hour, but even as a small child I thought the wait was well worth the fresh delicious seafood. Baked Turbot in parchment paper and clam chowder, yum!
author: Paige B.

description: Parmesan Halibut = YUM!!!  Free wine if you have to wait for a table = AWESOME!!
author: Cathy F.

description:
Why is seafood so expensive?!?? *sigh*.. price aside, this place is awesome. I've always wanted to try it as I drove by, but I actually thought it was a coffee house or something. 
My friend and I came for dinner, 8pm on sat night, no reservation and were seatly right away since we were only two. We both had the sauteed shrimp scampi with a side of vegetable (one broccoli stalk in lieu of fries or potatoes). Sourdough bread is delicious, salmon bisque was tasty, house white wine handed to us as we walked through the door was a nice treat. 
Service was a tad slow but I think there was only one waitress and the poor thing looked overworked (!) but the other little filpino (?) man was so cute and the other wait staff were friendly, refilled our water promptly, and the ambience is gorgeous and homey. Would definitely return here for a date or two (although it can get a bit loud as it is a festive place).
author: Christine Y.

description:
"Abalone is the American English variant of the Spanish name Abuln used for various species of shellfish (mollusks) from the Haliotidae family (genus Haliotis). The abalones belong to the large class of gastropods (Gastropoda). There is only one genus in the family Haliotidae, and about four to seven subgenera." - Thanks Wikipedia...

Anyway, yes...  ABALONE!!!!!!!!  Make sure they have it on the menu before you go (and that you have about $30.00 to spare on a meal) but I promise you  (as a Seafood Lover) your senses will be out of control at this place...  

Start out by penciling your name onto the list - literally, they don't take reservations to my knowledge - but hey, when they're serving you free wine (white - Pinot Gris maybe, who knows - who cares if it is free hahahaa!!!) it will be worth the wait to get in.

Once inside, the Salmon Bisque, good friendly service, warm bread, a primarily candle lit ambiance (candle lit tone anyway), nice wine selection (the "free" wine is merely a placebo to get your buds craving more of that grape nectar goodness) will be waiting for you...  If you're not into Abalone, that is OK because everything else on the menu (Salmon, Chilean Sea Bass, etc) is great too.

Make sure you wash your hands before you eat (duh, you should always do that) but there are some really great OLD photos in the restroom that I'm not going to tell you about - you'll just have to discover them for yourself...

can I come with you??  man, now I'm hungry!
author: Benjamin G.

description:
There was awhile when we were on a pretty good Pacific Cafe kick, and would brave the crowds to eat there often.  

I got tired of having to sit or stand around, waiting for a table at some ungodly early hour for dinner.  Believe it or not, they are already lined up by 5pm on Sundays.  

And though it's true they will keep your wine glass full while you wait to keep you around, I'm usually not a huge fan of the wine itself, most varietals served being very light Sauvignon blancs of sometimes questionable palatable-ness.

But the food is admittedly always good and satisfying.  If you are in the mood for good value on fresh cooked fish (not raw), this place is better than all those places in Fisherman's Wharf... that includes Scoma's when you factor in the relative prices, Scoma's being much higher.  Meals are not ala carte here, and soup and I believe salad are included in the meal price.

But the outer Richmond is a long way to go to look for parking and then wait in cramped quarters, or worse, outside in the cold foggy night, so I have to knock off a star.
author: Dave N.

description: This is a great neighborhood place.  They give out free wine while you wait to be seated, which is a fantastic idea.  My last trip here I had the clam chowder, the crab cakes, the prawn cocktail, and the cheesecake for dessert.  The clam chowder was nice, but I wish it had just a bit more cream in it.  Other than that, it was fresh and had a nice clammy taste.  The crab cakes were absolutely wonderful, and the cheesecake was light and fluffy.  I was a bit disappointed in the  prawn cocktail because the prawns were actually tiny shrimp that were not that flavorful.  Overall, this is a very strong seafood restaurant with some stand-out dishes.
author: Victoria R.

description: YUM!!!! This place is a bit far from where I live but definitely worth the trip! The portions here are huge and you're served a free glass of wine the moment you step into the place. SUPER! Prices here are decent for the fresh seafood. I had the sole and it sure was tasty! And not to forget: the service here is extremely friendly and attentive!
author: Lisa R.

description:
The wait was not worth our just so-so meal.  The hostess is very prompt and good about accomodating those lingering by the doorway.  You've all read about the complimentary wine given.  Our hostess said it was sparkling wine... it tasted like a watered down Chardonnay.  Oh well, free is free and I really appreciated the thought.

I was happy to read on their chalkboard that the soup of the day was crab bisque.  That was phenomenal!  Decadent, creamy, and the crab flavor was apparent through and through.  I couldn't get enough of it.  I had a halibut with a lemony caper sauce with mushrooms.  They give you a side choice of fries, boiled red potatoes, or rice with every entree.

My halibut didn't have a fresh robust taste to it and I had to season it myself.  Fries... well, I think it came out of a frozen bag.  It only got limper when it mopped up the lemon sauce.  My friend's Turbot baked in parchment paper was THE dish to get and sorely envied her savory cream sauce.  The Sole Newburg seemed to have been a 2nd favorite, but proved to be rather heavy and overly rich... the sauce was like another bisque.  Still pretty good.

So I was a little disappointed with my dish considering we waited about 45 minutes.  The space is real quaint and has a great neighborhood feel to it.  Just doesn't warrant a repeat visit with standard fair of the seafood.
author: Chris T.

description: My wife and I have been eating at Pacific Cafe for over 20 years and continue to be satisfied with the quality of the food and the service by the staff. Yes, we must wait for anywhere from 30 minutes to over an hour to be seated. But that is part of the attraction. We receive unlimited wine and invariably  there are interesting folks we meet. We dined this evening and the total tab, tip included, was $60.00. There is no other place in SF you can find such a good culinary bargain.
author: Lee H.

description:
All you can drink wine: Free

Filet of Sole with some Nuremburg Sauce: 25$

Watching my little sister(who I've never seen kiss a guy) kiss her bf: Priceless
author: Srinivas R.

description:
Went here with my gf the other day, and was somewhat disappointed by the service. We were seated right away (it was late at night), but once we were seated we were treated like we'd never want to go home. It took ages to get our water served, or explanation of specials etc. 

I had the grilled Ahi tuna, which should take literally less than 5 minutes to be prepared, and yet somehow it took foooorrreeevvvveeerrrr. It was supposed to be served with a wasabi infused butter... but the balance was way off.. much more like butter infused wasabi -- (i.e. pure wasabi with a touch of cream). 

In either case,  it's nice that they bring out free wine, although there's no such thing as a free lunch (or glass of wine), and I think the expensive entrees definitely make up that expense for them. 

Would I come back? Maybe.. but with a much better expectation of what I was getting into.
author: Mike S.

description:
I absolutely dig this place. I first went here back in '89....stumbled upon it on the way back from a hike along the beach. We were getting hungry and not much money in our pockets back then. A quick look at the specials board and a check of what was in our wallets told me we could eat very well here.

I ordered the halibut that night, first time i ever had halibut and to this day it still is the benchmark for all future halibut consumed by me. maybe it was just so simply prepared that it has seared into my memory.

any time i have been able to get to SF and have a few extra days of down time, this is one of my faves...unpretentious, priced right and worth any minimal wait you may have.

this past spring i was there and had some awesome calamari to start, great mixed green salad and an incredible piece of salmon. add to that the wine served while i waited plus a nice glass or two with dinner and it was a perfect evening.

look, venture beyond downtown SF and explore a long neighborhood treasure.
author: Bill V.

description:
The food here is great and they have free wine. Yes, crappy wine, but it is free.  I LOVE menu's that change every day based on what is fresh.  A w e s o m e. I take my grandma here everytime she comes to visit, and let me tell you, nothing impresses the old folks like free wine. 

Only problems are the wait and terrible parking situation.
author: Double-Dash C.

description:
I went to Pacific Cafe on a whim and recommendation, and am very glad I did!  Great ambiance (not-pretentious at all, but still classy), great service (wine while waiting on your table?  yes, please), great location (walking distance to the ocean), great food (fair portions, good variety).  It's a moderately priced restaurant, so don't plan on having a quick cheap bite, but you certainly won't need to take out a second mortgage for the halibut, either.  

Pacific Cafe doesn't necessarily seem like the sort of restaurant where one should bring a child, unless he is well behaved and loves more "grownup" dishes.   However it comes highly recommended for date night.  The non-stuffy yet refined atmosphere seems absolutely perfect for romantic endeavors, for first dates, married couples, and everyone in between.
author: D F.

description:
OK - I've got to talk about the butter:

They give you lots of fresh sourdough bread and butter -  a whole buncha butter - and I just happen to like that -   I don't care what other people say, butter is a *good* thing.

Because I live close by, I've been here a lot of times and my favorite fish is the parmesan halibut.  Sometimes they run out of it because it's so yummy.  And when that happens, I am utterly crushed.

PC is a friendly place - always a favorite.
author: Sue U.

description:
This is just one of those cases where owning a motor vehicle in San Francisco can actually be an advantage, you can conveniently get to forbidden locales like this where the city heathens and lower class can't easily access by foot or public transit.  Here's one for the bluebloods.


The food itself is top-notch seameat, if you're into heavy creams, there's large variety of it, and this includes the mind-blowing bisques that can range from vegetable to lobster.  However, as I'm sure everyone else has mentioned, the real kicker to this joint is all the free wine you want while you wait--and there's always a wait.  You may think this is a generous move on their part, but really, when everyone gets here by car and  they know you'll be waiting awhile, what better way to tame the impatient masses by inebriating them past the ability to drive?  It even makes the food taste better when you're actually seated!

Well played, Pacific Cafe, well played.
author: D L.

description:
I guess if the overiding factor to a restaruant getting a high rating is free wine, then this is your place.

It must be as I watch the line outside drinking the wine,but as some one who has been in the seafood buisness most of my life I find the food here VERY AVERAGE.

You could be here or someother place that sells gloppy cream sauces on fish or  freid Captains Platters..........boring.( the sauce did not shine here either )

When I go to a seafood restaruant I want the fish to shine,not the breading, or sauce covering it.

But if you are looking for free wine, then line up and get your fried breaded whatevers
author: Guiseppe B.

description:
Update: Last visit my husband had a live beetle in his salad and all it got us was a free dessert.

It is hard to give Pacific Cafe a star rating since it is so inconsistent.  I've had 2-star visits, and 5-star visits.  If you're lucky, you get a reasonable piece of fish and a complimentary scoop of ice cream with the check.  If not, you wait for an hour (getting drunk on cheap wine), get less-than-impressive fish, and are hurried out at the end of your meal.  In any case, I keep going back for two reasons:

1. I don't really like fish, but know that I should eat it for the health benefits.  When I go to Pacific Cafe there really isn't a non-fish option.

2. Almost every time I go there I get compliments on my hair from slightly older ladies waiting for their tables.  It's happened so often it has become comic.  So, when I need a self esteem boost, Pacific Cafe it is!
author: S R.

description:
I first started coming here about 1975.  I hadn't been there for a couple of years and tried it again last night.  I thought it was still very good.  One thing I really like is the choice of salads, besides the basic vinaigrette, which I detest, they offer Caesar or shrimp Louie.  

The sourdough bread is some of the best, and my dining partners loved both the Salmon bisque and the Clam Chowder.

They had about 8 specials, besides the regular menu.  The five of us all had something different, and everyone enjoyed their entrees.

I love the steamed red potatoes, they are very tasty even though they  are simple.

For dessert we shared one chocolate mousse cake which I thought was just OK, I think they used to have just plain chocolate mousse which was better.  We also shared a pistachio ice cream, the portion was very generous and made me want to go over to Mitchell's ice cream store, I haven't been there in years either.

The service was fine, and I still appreciate the free wine.

I'm glad Pacific Cafe is still around after all these years.
author: Madeline M.

description:
FREE WHITE WINE

Did you read that?  Yah.. Free wine while you wait.. Makes that 30 to 45 minute wait more enjoyable.  Okay not the best wine but who cares... did it come out of a box?  who cares.. its FREE!


but did I also Mention there is great food here?  The crab cocktail is insanely good.  Came on a friday night and it was all gravy.  Enjoyed this place immensely..



Seriously ... what are you doing reading this still? you should be making reservations and getting that jacket on..

get out the door already!  There is FREE WINE TO BE CONQUERED AND DRANKENS!
author: Ray W.

description:
Oh Rachel Rizay, you can do no wrong in my eyes. 
Thank you for first introducing me to Pacific Cafe on one of your San Francisco Tasty Travels episodes.
How you were right, Pacific Cafe is one of local San Fran's favorite seafood destinations.
And how in the world couldn't it be.  
I mean really.  
As you set food in the door, they hand each customer of age a free glass of white wine.  
Upon being seated you are then greeted with a basket of yummy bread and butter.  
Then after looking over menu choices [I recommend the parmesan halibut] you are prompted with a choice of soup or salad.  
Can this get any better?
Well the oyster cocktail is hands down my favorite thing to order at PC and is what keeps me gunning for dinners at this place.
Yum-o this place is good.
And they're not short of service or quality as well!
I can't wait to go back!
author: Kat R.

description:
For starters, a free chablis until you get seated.  An cozy and intimate ambiance with booths all around...

I ordered up the Hawaiian tuna, partially because I wanted the wasabi butter that came with. :-D  I asked for it rare, just ever so slightly grilled. I felt like I was just delivered a huge slab of sashimi grade tuna on a platter, and I was oh-so-pleased!   The portion was extremely generous and the flavor was dyn-o-mite!

My friend ordered the grilled swordfish with drawn butter. He let me a corner of it and it was plenty good, but I was still reveling in the beauty of my tuna steak to take too much notice.

Dessert was a light chocolate mouse torte.  I was pretty much stuffed by the time it came to our table, so I just had a few nibbles.   It could have been a MORE chocolaty, we both agreed, but it was nice way to end the meal.
author: Evelyn K.

description:
Free glass of wine while you wait:)  The wait can be long but worth it.

Know those restaurants where the service can be so so but the food is good....this is the place.  Like tonight: the host was very nice; our waitress must have been having an off evening.  The food - always good:)

Fun neighborhood place.  I am sure the regulars get better service.  If I continue like I have I may be a regular soon.  Enjoy!
author: Cici E.

description:
This place is so delicious, non pretentious and perfectly suited for out of town visitors.  Just about anything on the menu is cooked to perfection - so far we've tried the halibut (amazing), petrale, and Newburg entrees. 

The decor is modest but classic with good lighting, a necessity for that special date.  Complimentary wine doesn't hurt either.

Oh, and there's a sign in the ladies room stall that reads:

  " Women have many faults, men have only two:
     Everything they say and everything they do"
author: Yana C.

description:
I really want to love this place.  The little booths everywhere ... but I can only say I like it here.

The complimentary wine's a very nice touch.  I mean ... it's not really that great, but it's free ... so I can't really complain.

Really like their soups a lot.  Their bisque is thick and yummy and their clam chowder is broth-y without the gobs of starch or cream that many other restaurants do.

My favorite thing on the menu is the dore fillet with mushrooms.  Can't seem to be able to order much of anything else.  I did ... a few times, but I always come back to this dish.

They serve a light fluffy cheesecake that's really worth a try.

Parking sucks around here.

Don't forget to put your name down on the sign-in sheet.
author: Winnie C.

description: Great service, great food, and the price wasn't bad.   Recommend the halibut parmesan!
author: Amanda W.

description:
We received a gift certificate to this little gem over Christmas. 
How can you go wrong when you get free glasses of wine while you wait?
Appetizers, main course, dessert, everything was delicious and perfect. The staff is friendly, the food comes out quickly and I can't wait to go back.
author: Jules T.

description: I'm impressed with the long line but not the food. I think the food is just OK. I expected more for the price i paid. I think they have good catch for providing unlimited house wine when you are waiting for your turn. The environment is good. Anyway, i don't plan to go back there for sure.
author: Nil G.

description: Omg! Fantastic find, totally local but terribly inviting. The food delicious, the service hopping.  Oh, and by the way, where else are you served a glass of complimentary wine while you wait.  Go, enjoy. It's a must,
author: Sherry T.

description:
Granted this place is off in the far clenches of the Richmond District...tucked away in the fog and touristy traffic of those shmucks from Anaheim who just have to drive down to the cliffhouse for dinner...

anyway...

this place is great.  If you are in the mood for a nice cozy retreat away from the hustle then this is place for you.  down home cooking.  not for those on a diet for sure.  They have creamy biques and fried fishes and yummy calamari steaks...fish fish fish.  SO GOOD!

The place is a hoot, so its not suprising that you may have to wait for a bit for a table, but keep in mind my dear friends...they serve you complimentary wine, while you wait.

now thats service!
author: Ariane M.

description:
I don't mind waits, but if YOU do... then i would take off 2-3 stars since its that long of a wait... The place opens at 5pm so i would be their at 5pm just to wait at the most 20 minutes... 

Wait for 2 people @ 6pm = 45min
Wait for appetizer = 5-7 min (not that shabby)
Wait for food = 30 min.. but soooo soooo worth it!!!!

My boyfriend got the salmon with rice i believe.. it was soooo good, the salmon tasted unbelievably good!!!!!  I got the halibut crusted parmesan with the red potatoes... damn that was good!!!!!!! And i think when we were their the ahi tuna was all sold out after only being open for 2 hours, so that tells you something too...
author: Karen F.

description:
I had a great time here during my first time at Pacific Cafe. The whole "bring you free wine while you wait" definitely a great plus. The food was very good. I ordered the Calamari Steak, but I think that my friend's Parmesan Crusted Talapia was much better (which surprised me because I'm a huge Calamari fan).

The wait is a bit long, but as long as you have good friends and free wine, the wait won't feel like 45 minutes. My friends wanted to take me someplace "non touristy", and I think this place was a great option.
author: Timothy A.

description:
I've only eaten here twice in my lifetime...the first time as a kid, and I knew I was such a misfit (I was the brat that accidentally spilled drinks all over the table T_T)...that my parents have never stepped back into the place for fear that the patrons will point at "that family" again...hahah....

The second time was for my birthday (which coincidentally was the same 30 year anniversary as the restaurant). The staff was really accomodating, having able to square away 2 of the booths into 1 table that should have sat 6 people but 2 of my other friends were complete flakes...why keep asking them if they keeping flaking again and again...I must be a glutton for punishment...

Free wine while we waited and the fresh seafood dishes we chose were delicious and light...I love the chowder...it's got plenty of clams, not a lot of potatoes. You know this place is great when the staff can recognize a Schubert's cake from the decorations, and they were wonderfully low key (god, no more birthday carolling!).

Be prepared for a long wait if you don't have reservations, and this place is ALWAYS crowded no matter the day, weekend or holidays.
I haven't seen many patrons bring their children here due to the high seafood cuisine.
author: Pauline L.

description:
Something about this place caught my eye as I was speeding down Geary one evening.  It was the orangey glow and the small crowd that seemed to be gathered outside.  Pacific Cafe is a seafood restaurant of innate simplicity, they concentrate on market fresh fish alongside a few staples.  My first experience there led me to the crab cakes which were melty hockey pucks of shellfishy glory, beautifully textured crab which obviously came from a legendary recipe.  It has been there since 1973 and survived through the years despite attacks from the Lobster Liberation Front and the threat of building collapse and whilst I can't claim to have been dining there since 1973, the ten or so times I've been there have been wonderful.  

Highlights of the menu are the crab cakes and the halibut but the real show stopper there is the calamari steak meuniere.  They take the body of a squid the size of which i've only dreamed of, pound it flat, lightly coat it and pan fry it.  Served, as are all their meals with the choice of rice or potatoes and preceded by a free shrimp louie salad you can dine like kings, drink the free wine (even if it is rubbish!) and generally pig out for $20 a head.

The drawbacks are of course it's popularity and the fact they do not take reservations.  If they did, you wouldn't be able to get a table for months and that is not what PC is about.  Get there early or midweek and you stand a better chance, i've seen waits up to 2 hours on the weekend!

Love this place, it's as old as me and just as set in it's ways!
author: Tony S.

description:
4 star taste, but overpriced seafood = 3 star rating. 

The shrimp scampi was good, but will give you the guilt trip after you eat it... it's so fattening!! I took leftovers to go, stuck it in the fridge, and the next day, it was SOLID from the coagulated butter. Nasty.

The BF had the parmesan halibut, which was also good, but too strong for my taste... but then again I'm not too big on cheese.

The free wine is free for a reason... it's GROSS! Why is this such a perk for some reviewers?

The staff is very pleasant, and gave us a free slice of cake/ice cream for my birthday celebration.
author: Mari K.

description:
This is an old time favorite for me. My mother's been bringing me here for several years now. We've never eaten a meal here that we didn't love. There's a fish that's served in parchment paper that's absolutely to die for.  Their Newburg sauce is also a tasty. Service is always great. 
Ambiance - check. 
free stuff - check (the wine is free while you wait to be seated. Shame on the people complaining about the quality. HELLO! It's FREE. You want them to serve you a $50 bottle of wine for the $40 bucks of food you're going to order? That just doesn't make good business sense, or any kind of sense for that matter).
I could live on bread and butter alone. So, the fact that they provide copious amounts of both is something like bribery. 

I like it. I love it. I want some more of it.
author: Genevieve J.

description:
If you're looking for large hunks of fish prepared simply, come here.  It's noisy and cramped and very popular.  It's got a cozy feel about it.  Most likely from the cramped tables and wood decor.  Stop talking about the wine they give you while you wait.  Free wine is good.  Waiting is bad.  I hate waiting an hour to get in and don't think the wine makes it better.  I'd happily trade my glasses of wine for no wait. Hell, I'd trade my wine glasses in if they got a reservation book.  

It seems like I hate this place.  But something has to be said about fresh natural ingredients prepared simply.  I sound like Gordon Ramsey without all the bleeps now.  A lot of places cover up the flavors of their food for various reasons.  When I order sea bass, I want to be able to identify the taste as sea bass.  I didn't order it for a sauce or spice mix that happens to pervert the flavor.
author: Bruce B.

description:
I WOULD GIVE THEM 1304981204810984 STARS but i can only give them 5. 

my favorite restaurant!! I know all the wiaters and the food is DELICIOUSS!! free wine too!
author: Ava V.

description: I was super excited to try this place. BUT no to go orders for dessert? Lame I won't even bother trying this place out anymore.
author: Dom And Jazz C.

description:
Was lucky enough to hear about this restaurant when I first moved here 12 years ago. Love the food, service and of course the free wine. Highly recommend the halibut!

Always bring out of towners here and hope to continue to do so long into the future.
author: Chris L.

description:
This is my FAVORITE restaurant in all of San Francisco. No tourists here, just locals who want fresh fish.
The crab cakes are to die for. The Parm crusted Halibut amazing and the Ahi always so fresh.  
Go here, it is worth the wait and don't forget the free wine!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
OK, it is true, you often have to wait. But what I've learned in life, is that often times patience has great rewards. This is very much true of Pacific Cafe. Oh, and the free waiting wine is nothing to celebrate... so just don't drink it if you are a picky wino.

I've had the luxury of dining here roughly ten times in my life, and I have never had disappointing fare. I can't believe other reviewers have put down the clam chowder though... that, quite frankly, is insane. They make the best clam chowder I've ever had - and I've had a lot in my day.

Try their salmon and crab newburg, if it happens to be on the menu. One of my favorite dishes. And I quite like the parchment wrapped turbot. Just enjoy the ambiance, and if you aren't a patient person at all, just go early before the rush.
author: Adam A.

description: (unpretentious neighborhood restaurant + warm friendly service + super fresh ingredients) * 40 years = Bay Area institution.  This place is a must try, esp if you like fresh seafood and interested in exploring deep into the avenues into the Richmond district.
author: David C.

description:
I've been about a 100 times in the last 20 years and the menu is pretty much the same...although I never order off the menu.
Go with the Specials of the Day.

Pros:
Complimentary wine...
Sour dough bread and tartar sauce combo is a must while you wait...
The chowder is the best...not that overly white creamy stuff...
Good atmosphere if you go late...
Fresh daily specials...

Cons:
An outdated menu...hence go with daily specials
Wait time for getting a table...(small place)

Advice:
Go early to beat the crowds...but early means you're stuck
with the early bird special crowd (older folk)
Stay clear of the Russian/German waitress...very rude and impolite...
(in the 20 years I've been they've had some great waiters/waitresses
but this one girl they have now is the worst)
author: MEAT M.

description:
I have been going to Pacific Cafe since the mid-70's.
I am from NYC and really(believe) think I know seafood-East Coast style. The food here is fresh and plentiful. The fried oysters and crab cakes are unbeatable compared to any SF dining experience. Peeled shrimp too The best potatoes and dinner comes with shrimp salad
This place was always my favorite for a first date experience. Long waits  and Free Wine. Great opportunity to meet people from all over the area and from all over the country. 
Pacific Cafe is more than a great place to eat . It is an experience. The BEST . We live in Berkeley and drive to  the city is worth going to Pacific Cafe any day of the year
author: Justin G.

description:
My only pseudo-complaints about this place are that:
1. It's pretty far out there from North Beach, but its location suits it. - and -
2. We had to wait quite a long time for a table, but they make it a pleasant wait with a cozy atmosphere and complimentary wine to sip on.

The wait, resulting from the crowd, is your first clue how great the food is.

The warm sourdough bread is top-notch.
Clam chowder looked great although i had the caesar salad (meh).
Trout was excellent (mine).
Crab-stuffed sole was great (hers).
Side of Broccoli was perfect.

As many specials, as items on the modest menu.  A few non-seafood choices.  I will go back, and I will finally have a place to recommend when people ask for a "Seafood Restaurant" that is no where near Pier 39.
author: Mike R.

description:
Pacific Cafe is a decent place. I'd recommend it to my parents, perhaps not my friends.
