Of course I'd be lying if I didn't say that I was lured into this pescateria by their offering of free wine.  I'm not going to complain like some snobs below who state the obvious that the free wine is the cheap wine - how can you complain, it is free!?!  

As far as the food and the dining experience, I was satisfied.  My fish was cooked just right and the server was pleasant.  My dining partner wasn't pleased though because the shrimp weren't de-veined, which would be expected of a restaurant of this style & caliber.
author: Anthony S.

description:
How can a place that gives you free wine while you wait be bad?  If you get soused enough, the wait won't seem so long.  I've had some wonderful conversations with people while waiting for a table here.

The food here is wonderful and tasty.  I love their clam chowda and their sourdough bread.  The service is great too.

I have a special place in my heart for Ross the Boss.
author: Landy G.

description: Love this place, just need to find the sweet spot time to show up to avoid the wait.  Of course the complementary wine makes the wait easier.
author: Toby L.

description: It's been a while since I have been here but started going again with new girl. Yes the wait can be long but doesn't that mean its good? Well if you like wine, no worries cause they will pour you wine at no charge while waiting. Waiting can be fun. Our fav is the sole. Which sole? Any of them. They are all sole good. Some waiters have been there since the 80's, great guys. Sole glad to be back. OK enough of that.
author: Moby L.

description:
I had always wanted to eat here and a few weeks ago I finally got to. Apparently they don't take reservations. My friend and I got there early, around 6pm, and we got a table right away. We also got parking right out front and there were plenty of spaces available on both sides of Geary. This is the outer Richmond so it's not as difficult to park as the inner Richmond. 

We are both light eaters and after looking at the prices we knew we had to split something. I hadn't realized that it was a tad pricey before suggesting it to her. The first thing that was a little disconcerting was that they offered us free wine as soon as we walked in, which was nice but neither of us drink so we declined. Then they offered it to us 3 more times while we were sitting at the table, even adding with surprise "are you SURE you don't want free wine?" which I thought was a little over the top since we had declined it repeatedly by then. I had a vision that someone was gonna come over to our table to strong-arm us, push my head back and pour the wine down my throat whether I wanted it or not. I felt that I wasn't being listened to/heard and that my request was not being respected.

At first we were talking about whether we should split the crab louie or the baked halibut and as I always ask the waitperson what they recommend I waited till our waitress came over to ask her her opinion. I guess she was having a bad moment because she literally rolled her eyes at me and snapped "those are 2 very different things" and would not give me any other answer or suggestion. I thought maybe she was angry that we didn't want the damn wine. We finally decided to split the crab louie and when she came back to take our order and we told her what we wanted she actually snapped at us and said "that's ALL????" I was taken aback and raised my eyebrows at her. We went ahead and each ordered a cup of their salmon bisque (even though I don't usually eat diary). I think that part of the reason I ordered it was out of fear. I was fearful that the waitress was going to become even angrier and bite me and I was also fearful that perhaps the salad wouldn't be enough. Well I was wrong. The salad was HUGE!!!!!!! I had asked the waitress if it was big enough to split but again, she didn't really give me an answer, she answered my question with another question. I finally gave up. But in a passive/aggressive moment (that I'm not proud of but hey I'm human) I exclaimed when it arrived - "this is big enough to feed 5 people" but it really wasn't quite that big. It was perfect for my friend and me and there was even some left over. There was a very very large portion of crab and that crab was delicious. There were sliced eggs and avocado and other delectables. It was probably one of the best crab louies I've ever had - other than at Tadishes. The salmon bisque I thought was pretty good but not fantastic. Mine was hot on the bottom and cold on the top, I had to stir it up for a warmish medley.

After a bit our waitress lightened up and was not as cranky though she certainly didn't become someone I'd want to snuggle with on a cold night.

After our meal we had some time to kill because we had plans that started a little later. I looked around and saw a huge line of people waiting for seats and I stopped a waitress, not ours, and asked her if we should hurry and leave and she said, "oh no, please take as much time as you like, you are customers". I thought that was so amazingly sweet!!! We didn't sit there for long anyway because I hate to keep other people waiting but that waitress really was exceedingly pleasant. 

I would definitely go back for the crab louie and refuse to be intimidated by a waitress in a foul mood.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Pacific Cafe is one of the best seafood restaurants in the city.  I tried to come here for Valentine's Day but failed since the line was too long.  So I tried again for the gf's bday and it worked.  First off, they give you unlimited wine (white or red!) while you wait.  That wins big points with me.  By the time we got our table, my face was redder than the one glass of wine I sipped.  

We started off with bread and soup.  I got the lobster bisque and my gf got the clam chowder, both wonderful.  For the entrees, I don't really remember what I ordered (no, not because I was drunk, but because it was a few months ago), but I got something along the lines of creamed salmon.  My gf wanted scallops, but they weren't on the entree menu.  However, our server was so nice and offered to make her a scallop scampi.  Both dishes were excellent!

After dinner, I gave my gf her birthday present.  Our server happened to walk by while she was opening it, and, noting that it was her birthday, came back with a cup of ice cream, which was also delish. 

Overall, the service and food (and free wine!) make Pacific Cafe worthwhile.
author: Lams L.

description:
All seafood.  The menu is basic but they are good at what they do.  Never had a bad meal here, and the wait staff actually remembers my dad from when he used to frequent the place 25 years ago!  That impressed me.  If you go often, they remember you.

It's not a fancy crowd.  They're mostly older, chill locals.  It's not the young downtown pretentious circle that dwell at most popular restaurants, so don't worry about putting on "a better shirt" before you go out.

My warning:  The bread is fantastic and by the time you get seated you'll be so liquored up and hungry enough to eat the whole basket and immediately ask for more... Don't do this.  I always do and am full before my dinner arrives.  But I never remember not to do this because of all the damn free wine!!!
author: Mariko H.

description: So there was a little bit of a wait when we walked in...who cares they gave us free wine until we were seated! The service was great, super friendly. I ordered the crab cakes which were awesome, and a claw chowder which was pretty good, I am more of a creamy clam chowder fan and this was more of a brothy chowder. Food was great, atmosphere was cozy overall it was a great experience.
author: Adrienne P.

description: It rocks simply put...red or white,wine while you wait, perfect service and a unique menu.  Don't wait...get there early.
author: John T.

description: I don't know how this place gets such high ratings. Soggy, flavorless crab cakes with too much filler. Flavorless veggies taste frozen. Reheated rice with bad texture. Brusque wait staff that rushes your dinner because the noisy place is crowded and they want tables cleared asap. Not a relaxing atmosphere. I won't go there again.
author: Pam J.

description:
Hmmm, you mean I get wine (OK, Inglenook, don't get too excited) while I'm waiting?  OK!  Be prepared to drink a lot of wine, because you're likely to wait a while.  
It's a small corner restaurant that's been there for many, many years (how do I get the original menu prices on this bill?).  I've been 4+ times a year for the last 6 years, and have rarely been disappointed.  The food, seafood, is excellent, especially the bread, the shrimp louie salad and several of the fresh entrees (calamari steak, grilled shrimp, wasabi-butter ahi).  Short wine list, but budgetarily sound (5$ corkage and a similar markup from winestore prices).  Dessert, I'd recommend going someplace else.
The servers know what they're doing, but service can be uneven and god forbid you comment negatively, even in a reasonable way.
author: Charlie O.

description:
Get the crab diablo (only available during dungeness season), local whole dungeness sauteed in a peppery blend of white wine, shallots, and butter. We alternate between enjoying buttery dungeness flavor of the crab straight out of the shell with dipping some of it into the sauce. The hearty bread is also good for sopping up the tasty sauce and we usually can't get enough of it. We start with the moderately spiced and comforting salmon or crab bisque, and the salad with shrimp louie dressing!  In order to afford pricey dungeness for both of us we often split everthing and order an extra salad and perhaps a veggie.  

The rest of the daily menu items are predominately straightforward preparations of fresh seafood, either grilled, baked, or pan-fried. The printed menu seafood is more old-skool continental stuff, still good though. 

Pacific Cafe is basically unchanged since we started going there in the mid 80's, and so is the menu.  No fussy, self-conscious presentations and no Cal, Pan, Neo, or Fusion anything. What a relief. We have been going there for so long that the spicy snapper which used to be 9.98 back is now more like 15.98 due to inflation. We also like the halibut parmesean. 

Notice: the clam chowder is not the creamy Boston style you might expect. It's "pacific" clam chowder, which is broth based. We have learned to enjoy it when we are in the mood for it. Still looking for the best creamy clam chowder, though. You'd think we'd have it here in SF but it's hard to find. Their bisques make up for it!

Enjoy the free cheap wine while you wait and wait and wait for a table, and even if you come for the first seating as we do, they still give you a glass of the comp wine when you are seated. Refills are only while you are waiting. Once at the table you are expected to order from the wine menu. If you still want to drink more. 

An interesting observation is that even when the restaurant is full, the environment is not overstimulating. We've gone here after an exhausting day and enjoyed having a relaxing meal. It's always relaxing to eat here even though it doesn't look like "it's been designed and conceived to be relaxing". Like I said, not self-conscious or considered. Just a regular nice place, with giant huge steak fries.

Avoid the Pacific Cafe over in Marin. It's kinda sorta like this one (looks like a twin) but clearly not owned by the same people (at least not any more). We went there a few months ago and were disappointed in everything.
author: Paris E.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in the city -- where I always choose to go for an anniversary, birthday, or any other occasion (including the occasion of being in the outer Richmond near 5pm).  

Note:  I always arrive before 5pm, thus avoiding any hellish lines.  I deviated from this rule twice.  The first time, I met some great people in line, and the long wait went quickly.  The second time, the wait was sooooo long, and all 3 of us drank so much free wine that I barely remember dinner.  So, we're back to the 5pm rule!  Get there early, get seated, enjoy... and avoid the wait!

My favorites are the specials.  I've been known to call ahead to see if they have the Ahi w/Wasabi butter.   Yum.  The piece of Ahi is huge, so my husband always gets half of it.  However, he never wants to share what he ordered, which is usually super delicious, too.

What makes me like this place so much is the atmosphere (I love the booths, the chalkboard menus that come to your table, the huge orb lights above, and the casual elegance of the brown and white linens.  I find it a great value - you get that free wine, some hot bread, a soup or salad, and a starch...  with really gigantic entrees, most in the $20 or less range.
author: Kimberly M.

description: I can't believe people rate it any higher. The free wine can take you nowhere when the food is not good.
author: Lauren C.

description: I've been coming ever since I moved here in the early 90's and wanted to bring my sister in law here on monday, 09/17/12, as she loves seafood and wanted to go to someplace that was "different and unusual". Since this place is more of a neighborhood joint, and is always popular after 6p.m., we got here shortly before opening and were (as always) greeted with a complimentary glass of sparkling wine while waiting. (Very nice touch!) It's a good thing we got there when we did, as the place filled up rapidly shortly after we arrived. I was lucky to partake in the Abalone Steak and my sister in law had the seafood salad. Mine was scrumptious, along with the rice and salmon chowder and my sister in law's seafood salad was fantastic as well. Also, we had a crab cake appetizer that was fairly decent too! The staff was very accommodating and speedy. All in all, it was a great perfect spot for me to impress a family member for local seafood and an extra plus was that it was close to the Cliff House for a Sunset Irish Coffee to top off the evening!
author: Timothy L.

description: How can you not fall in love with this place? Even before we entered the dining room I was already in love. This place takes no reservations so more than likely you will have to wait. But the wait is so enjoyable. Free wine while you wait and families and doggies by your side. Sweet as peaches waitress and salmon bisque to die for. A nice place for that romantic dinner for two or a family outing.
author: Sophia C.

description: Got here at 4:40pm and we were third in line.  After a few minutes, we were allowed to wait inside which was much appreciated.  Free wine was served as we get close to 5pm.  As far as free wine goes, I must say it was decent.  After everyone in line at 5pm got seated, some were left to wait and I feel sorry for them because it is going to be a long wait.  We ordered a small order of crab cake as appetizer and for main courses we had the petrale dore and salmon and crab newburg.  We also ordered the clam chowder and oyster bisque. Overall flavor was good but I prefer my meals served at higher temperatures.  The crab cake and clam chowder were lukewarm.  It felt like they have been cooked and left sitting for awhile.  Same goes for the mushrooms on the petrale dore (although the fish was still very warm.)  On the positive side, the clam chowder was not heavy with cream and it was quite flavorful.  I also like the boiled potatoes which were done just right with all the original flavor still intact without being smothered by butter or sour cream.  On the negative side, both the clam chowder and the lobster bisque had too much pepper and a bit too spicy for my taste.  The lobster bisque was too heavy with cream and despite the pepper still had a fishy taste to it.  The newburg is an extremely heavy dish that I would never order again.  Overall, the value was good but for the quality of the food I am not going to get out of my way and endure a 30-minute wait again.
author: Amy L.

description: This place is comfy, cozy, inexpensive and oh so tasty! One of my favorite restaurants in all of San Francisco. The first time I went there was about 10 years ago, our server was this petite, VERY pregnant irish woman, she served us about four or five times after that as well.  The weekends usually there is a wait but they serve you house white while you wait. They always have amazing daily specials. I highly suggest getting the shrimp louie salad with your meal and pretty much everything on the menu is delicious.
author: Tawnya C.

description: Nice little place out in the Richmond.  Food is good and reasonably priced.  They also have complimentary white wine if you end up waiting for a table.  The fish is always fresh, never had a problem.  I must have eaten there over 10 times since its around my hood.  One of my favorites is the Parmesan crusted Halibut.  I also like the atmosphere, historic pictures of the old Richmond district...nothing but sand dunes.
author: S F.

description:
heard good things about this place, so decided to check it out.

star for free wine, star taken away for not offering it to me till i asked. maybe i'm supposed to be 50 before they offer it.

food seemed fresh? i think? couldn't tell as much because it was overcooked with too much salt. i thought seafood was more delicate?

service was great afterward, and my friends were fun. there are certain things on the menu that's more desirable than others. i just can't remember which now...

oh, and the wait was not worth it. it's just a small place and people tend to bring huge groups. don't go if you're already hungry.
author: jolie L.

description: Although right on Geary blvd, this cozy little cafe feels to be tucked in the middle of residential district. The food and service is consistently good, but the menu is lackluster to say the least. The owners seem to be stuck somewhere in 80's with this pseudo- European appeal (i.e., formally-dressed waiters in a livingroom setting). On the one hand, quality fresh ingredients, on the other - tourist menu from a chef-less Fisherman Wharf eatery. They serve you some $2.00 wine while you wait, but I am always excited about this little touch of care!
author: Lana L.

description: The wait was a bit longer this time. But the food was still totally worth it!
author: Miss N.

description: Wow. love this place! Great food, great service, great atmosphere, reasonable prices! What more could you ask for? Let me not forget complementary wine while you wait to be seated! Last but not least they tolerated our abnormally rambunctious 17mo old. (Sorry about that!!)
author: Joe B.

description:
Yum Yum!!
Walk in, write name down and the nice hostess brought us a glass of complimentary cheblis. It was tasty too. what a nice touch..
Crab cocktail, good. Lots of crab, cocktail sauce on the side, kind of like that. The bread they give you right away is fresh and fluffy and good with lots of butter.. can't have too much butter!
My PID (partner In Dinning) my special friend who is just as picky as me loves this place too. It's simple and delightful. He had the parmesean halibut, which I didn't try but looked amazing. I had the baked salmon and scallops combo. Both they serve with three red potatoes (or your choice of rice pilaf) we had soup, clam chowder (or choice of shrimp louie salad or cesear). I was stuffed! The scallops were baked in butter, of course! The salmon was cooked just right and both you could taste the meal rather than any spices that most places add, that's nice for a change.
The atmosphere is great for a nice, romantic night out. 

The service is quick and friendly. They have such a long wait usually, they are used to bringing out your courses one right after the other. They give a few moments in between but it's pretty fast service. 

Parking is a bit tricky, there's not a lot around the outter richmond area, so be prepared to walk around and bring a jacket!
author: Jess P.

description:
very simple restaurant. the fish was outstanding, but everything else was just blah... 
i make fish at home, whole fish, so maybe that is why i was not that impressed. 

I thought the salad was bland, the sides were lame.. the desserts just average. i had hoped for so much more.
author: Jippers C.

description: This is a really good relaxing restaurant. The fish is always fresh and tasty.  Always nice to have wine while waiting for a table.  Great service for the past 20 years...
author: Richard W.

description: Found this place from asking a security guard down by the Ferry Building. Had a short wait, with free wine. The wine by the way was very good since I'm not much a wine drinker. Cozy place, was kind of small however the choices and food were great! Service was OK. We'll be back the next time we're in SF!
author: Jason D.

description:
Awfully disappointing.

Petrale sole newburg tasted same as frozen dinner or what you get at Country Buffet. The cream sauce has no taste and quite disgusting actually, the fish was mushy, and the crabmeat stuffing, like I mentioned, tasted frozen and in fact was still cool. My friend had the halibut parmesan. The haibut was extremely dry and the parmesan crust did not complement the fish at all. 

Also had fried scallops for appetizer, which was good. The scallops were just a little underdone - the way they should be. And the ceasar salad that came with the entree had the option of anchovies, which was nice.

For all its hype and price (~$25 per dish that tasted and looked like cafeteria food) and the usual long wait, not worth it at all, and thankfully, I have tried it and there is no need to go back.
author: Kari N.

description:
Free wine while you wait and that is because you have to wait most likely..and the food is not a bad deal either if you like seafood...

Cheers!
author: Ringo L.

description: Took less than 5 minutes to find parking within a couple blocks.  Since we got there right at 5, we were also seated with the first rush of patrons.  Plenty of bread awaited us at the table.  The waiter was also kind of enough to provide complimentary glasses of wine, as we didn't get to do the usual "wait and sip wine" thing.  Ah well.  I wound up trying the tuna with wasabi butter, while my date tried the salmon and shrimp plate.  There was nothing intrinsically wrong with the tuna, but having never tried it served that way, it left me longing for the butter-and-garlic-soaked shrimp of my guest across the table.  Grass is always greener!  Oh, I also splurged on a crab cocktail.  While it was delectable, there's something about not having to do any work to get at that crab meat that makes it less satisfying.  Ah well.   All in all, it was quite filling, and we hadn't left room for dessert.  Perhaps next time.
author: Gerald C.

description:
Frank has been working at Pacific Cafe since the time the restaurant opened up in 1974. Do the math - it's a long time. He can tell you about the daily specials, the restaurant, or even why the prices end the way they do [with nothing rounded]. Very friendly and open to questions, Frank smells of the fragrant flower lei that he wears. Anytime he passes by the table, all I think about is Hawaii. Olfaction and memory - there's definitely a connection. Frank does his job well. Service, in general, is quite good. Water was refilled, and plates were moved out of the way quickly. Even with the limited space, Pacific Cafe is very accommodating to large parties. There was a table of 11 next to our table of 9. While waiting, I was certain that we would only be seated after the other party had left. But nope - lucky us! Wood panels, which are placed in between tables to turn them into smaller/cozier booths, are removed for the larger groups. Ingenious!

The wait can be rather long, even if one gets there as early as 5:30. It is to be expected, so get there when you are not quite hungry yet. That'll help when they start pouring the wine! I wrote my name up on the clipboard. Like magic, wine appeared in my hands after I shuffled my way back towards the entrance. It didn't suck all that much to be the line bitch for the group... Everyone trickling in later on also partook in the free vino, but I probably had the most refills because of line bitch duty. With our large party, we were seated around 6:30. An hour's wait with wine and good company? Not a problem! Of course, it would've been an even more pleasant wait if it was not cold and sprinkling outside. There is an inside waiting area also, but that can get a little crowded.

I had a difficult time deciding on my meal and was fortunate that others at the table ordered a variety from which I could do a little taste testing. There is a printed menu, as well as specials on a chalkboard that change regularly. I ended up with the fried oysters - juicy, meaty, yummy. Spicy Snapper and Salmon and Crab Newburg were also ordered. All entrees arrived with a soup or salad [Shrimp Louis or Caesar], and potatoes [fries or steamed] or rice. The food was excellent, nothing too dry or overly salty. I like my seafood fairly simple, and they didn't overdo any of what I had tried. I hear that the crab cakes are amazing too. That's on my list for next time because there WILL be a next time. [That should say a lot, considering how we live all the way across town - oh no!]

If you have room after all of THAT, you're a freakin' PIG... I wasn't able to finish my rice. But seriously, they have Mitchell's ice cream and Zanze's cheesecake too! SERIOUSLY. This would be on my list of restaurants that represent what this city is about... it's been here long enough.
author: Tinna H.

description:
3.5 really.

ive been meaning to eat here for a long time. i saw it on check please and the food network. i had to try it. took me only, what, two three years?

so the place does live up the hype. it really did impress me. just no tthat much.

right to it. 

i had the fried sand dab. to be honest, i prefer bay fung tongs fried sand dab, but ehhh i liked it here too. funny how they cut the tail and head off first. very round eyes of them. nice.

another buddy had their specialty, the baked halibut. it was flavorful enough, but it was over cooked even to round eyes standards.

want was awesome was the other buddys sauteed prawns, wow. like really wow. awesome. cooked perfectly, seasoned just right. awesome.

reading this review, you might think, why did this place impress the euge. everything was good, i just like to bitch. 

definately worth a try, would i got back? ehhh prob not. the crowd isnt my crowd, and the wait staff pretty much let us know that.

(edit: similiar to lake merrit bakery *if its still there* the crowd was an older crowd, seniors mostly the night we were at pacific cafe. they undersalt everything for their clients. you cook to your clients needs)

ooo wait, is that zanzes cheesecake. holy crap, is euge eating sweets? yes.
author: Euge L.

description:
So we went their last Friday night and they changed the Seafood Newburg recipe so I have to change their rating from 5 to 4 stars.  It has a slightly different filling with no curry in it.  I was totally bummed.  The rice pilaf wasn't the same either.  Please, please go back to your original Seafood Newburg recipe!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This place is awesome!!!  My family and I have been coming here for close to 30 years. We have never had a bad meal.  There isn't much ambiance but the food and staff make up for that.  We love the Seafood Chowder which is a delicious soup minus the cream. They have 3 salads to chose from and specials every night of the week. I, myself, have always been a fan of the Seafood Newburg. My husband, not a big seafood lover, always gets the steak which is wonderfully grilled with huge steak fries that are fresh, not frozen. Most of the servers are great and the cooks/help (and a few of the servers) have been with the business for many years. We live in Redwood City and we make it a point to go there at least once a month.  Everyone should give this place a try--guaranteed you will not be disappointed!
author: Alias A.

description: Probably one of my favorite places to grab seafood in the city. Service is awesome. All the seafood here is very fresh and the prices are reasonable. I've had everything from their fresh catches (salmon, halibut, scallops) to their crab cakes and everything has been great thus far. The ambiance is nothing fancy, and the wait can be a little long during peak hours, however they do offer free wine when you wait and parking in the area is pretty easy. All in all great place to try if you like seafood
author: Steve T.

description: You won't find "fusion" or "pan-asian" or "organic" here. Pacific Cafe is all about traditional North American seafood - cooked through and paried with a solitary boiled vegetable on the side.  Nope, nothing screams traditional American fare more than grey overcooked seafood and a sad lonely vegetable, all nutrients and freshness leached out of it.  So no, this isn't my first spot for seafood, especially when there are so many other seafood restaurants out there. But chances are, your midwestern grandparents and visiting great aunt from Des Moines will absolutely love it.
author: Umami Y.

description:
My boyfriend and I ate a lovely dinner at the Pacific Cafe last week, while I was up visiting the Bay Area; we had chosen the cafe due to both its proximity to the Legion of Honor Museum,as well as previous positive reviews.  
Our dinner was as good as we had hoped; we both enjoyed the scrumptious seafood(he had the salmon, I had crab cakes).  Neither one of us drinks, but were impressed with the offer of free wine and the plentiful refills as well as attentive service.
The coup de grace(?) I must say was the extra nice touch I discovered upon leaving the restaurant and Bay area; I realized that I had accidently left my son's Giants cap (to be a surprise upon returning to So.Cal) under the table; when I called the restaurant and we verified that indeed the black cap under the table was mine, and that not enough time to return to the City prevented our return to the cafe. 
The staff was kind enough to mail the cap back to us, and was pleasantly surprised that I had sent postage on to them.
That is service and most certainly a cut above the rest:)!
Thank you Pacific Cafe, we will be back:)!!
author: Jill B.

description:
I've seen this place in my neighborhood and wondered....I've seen this place on Channel 9 and got interested....
I walked in with friends tonight and got heady aromas of garlic, butter and seafood...
 I enjoyed a free glass of Inglenook Burgundy while I waited. Its their practice to give out free wine for waiting customers.

We sat down and ordered. We all had the pacific clam chowder and thought that is was tasty, not too creamy but a bit salty. The bread is soft but cold.

I ordered my entree with fries. I made sure the waiter knew I didn't want overcooked scallops. I later asked to make sure I got extra crispy fries.

When the food arrived, the fries were extra crispy. However, just about everything was overcooked.

The wild King Salmon was overcooked. It came witha an herbed butter htat helped with the dryness.

The scallops baked in butter and garlic were almost like rubber. None of them were cooked tender and juicy.

The halibut? well I've had lots of good halibut that was moist and tasty. I think they overfried that one.

The ahi tuna with wasabi butter? Don't ask for medium rare unless you want to see it almost cooked. We had to saend that one back.
The wasabi butter was not bad. ask for horseradish on the side to enhance the flavor further.

The crab cakes? actually the most tasty and moist.

The portions? Way big./ Definitely conisder sharing an entree and supplementing with appetizers/soups.

The grease level? You could restore the chain on my bicycle. Ok not that bad but its heavy.

I was disapppointed to find out the cook was [robably there longer than anyone else int eh restaurant but I didn't feel convinced that he had any perspective on the handling and care of seafood. It was a nbit like going to a greasy spoon.

I think my waiter could tell we weren't happy but he never did ask us if things were ok or not. Still, we worked him and gave him his fair tip.

The chocolate mousse torte and Mitchell's chocolate chip ice cream were satisfying. 

I apologize to my fellow yelper who rave about this place. I must have just caught the chef on an off night.

Is it worth coming back? Yes for the soup, extra crispy fries and crab cakes. But don't hold your breath for anthing else. Still, I would be willing to come back if they would try to not overcook the seafood!
author: J C.

description:
as far as a simple, classy seafood joint goes, this place is done perfectly. obviously they're doing something right since they haven't really changed in around 30 years. i came here with my parents who had been there 20 some odd years ago, and they said it's pretty much exactly like they remembered it (including the waiting outside). 

i like the fact that they don't take reservations, actually, since then you get to wait outside and drink the complementary wine that they are more than generously pouring for you. i mean this guy was running around with a big unlabeled bottle of white getting people liquored up so that they don't care that you may be waiting an hour plus for your table. brilliance. more restaurants should implement this strategy.

we started with the calamari which surprisingly ISN'T fried, but is instead cooked, cooled, and smothered in a delicious saucy oil mixture type of thing. really good for a change. and surprisingly tasty. our waiter actually let us sample some when we asked how it was cooked and wondered if it was worth trying. so that kinda shows the kind of service you get. they don't really hold back and are super friendly. you get soup with your entree which is also nice, so i got a little cup of clam chowder. for the main course i got a spicy swordfish fillet, which wasn't that spicy, but was still perfectly grilled and prepared. i'm no seafood snob but this place is definitely worth checking out for both the free wine, friendly staff, and food.
author: Nathan S.

description: As a vegetarian, most will be surprised to see me writing a review for a place that sells on seafood. Attending with my boyfriend and best friend visiting from CT, this place is right down the street from our current apartment, so we thought it would be a good place to go. Yes, there is free wine while you wait, but honestly, if they didn't give that, I don't think anyone WOULD wait. I had a salad, which was $5  made up of just lettuce, two slices of tomato, and cucumber, the ingredients themselves cost less than $2 - big rip off. My boyfriend and best friend DID have seafood, and after moving from the East Coast, it is safe to say they were quite disappointed, especially for the high cost; you'll never find us dining here again.
author: Victoria K.

description: Just plain ole Nasty! Very BLAND...Bring your own season's....Stay clear from FILET OF SOLE NEWBURG.........DISGUSTING! Inedible!!! Crab cakes taste like Mayonnaise and green onions.
author: Inez B.

description:
I'm just going to add my 2 cents to the high ratings for this place. It's only a few blocks from where my wife and I live and we like to walk to it, then wait outside with the crowd. We're not big wine drinkers but Pacific Cafe does make you feel special by plying you with free wine while you wait. The outer Richmond can get bitter cold even in the summer so sometimes it's not so pleasant waiting outside. The restaurant is small and I am sure they would have doubled their seating long ago if they could. They certainly have the continuous patronage to expand.
However, waiting outside and getting warmed from the inside with wine has become a tradition for this place. We ran into a couple who used to live in the neighborhood but moved out of SF some years ago... they come back periodically just to wait in line outside, drink wine and meet folks. It is true you can strike up some great conversations in the outside waiting area. I would say it's not good for groups over 5 people just because their seating is so limited.
The food is great, the service good. I'd go there more often but sometimes you just don't want to wait to eat... especially in the frequently Arctic wastes of the outer Richmond district.
author: Dennis N.

description:
the complimentary wine eases the edge of hunger pangs and the wait for a table. normally i'm not a white wine person, but their chardonay was tasty enough. the restaurant has an old san francisco feel as it is made of great wood workmanship from the tables to the booths. 

the food is simple and delicious. we shared a half order of the crab cakes. they were out of this world, and a must order. i had their salmon bisque and the bf had the shrimp louie salad as our starters, and both were great. our entrees were the halibut parmesan and turbot baked in parchment paper with shrimp and crab. while both were tasty, my halibut parmesan stole the show. we ended the meal with the chocolate torte. 

we were so stuffed by the end of it all we didn't have room for a post-dinner cocktail.
author: Sheri N.

description: Reliably good food, but not great and a bit pricey. The menu and food is simple--salad or soup and seafood entree with potatoes--the sort of dishes you could make at home.  When I inquired about the abalone ($41 for 5oz), I found out from the waitress that it was from a farm in Cayucos.  Apparently, since abalone has been commercially over-fished, restaurants can only get their abalone from farms.
author: Merri K.

description: Yummy. Have eaten here like 4-5 times in the past few years. This last time last month was THE BEST. The crabcakes were probably the best I ever had. Lots of crabmeat and cooked perfectly. I ate the Prawns scampi style. YUMMY. Cant wait to go back- Didn't even have to wait for our table that night, which sometimes is half the fun because of the free wine!
author: Tara M.

description: I LOVE this restraunt!!  The seafood is amazing.  My favorite is the halibut parmesan with a shrimp louie salad.  Expect a long wait, but to compensate you for your time you get free wine.  This is a great place to go to have a great conversation in a fun atmoshpere.  The service is fantastic and the people are friendly.  I am a loyal customer and have always been completely satisfied.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Been wanting to go here since I saw on "Check Please".  

Planned to get there before opening at 5pm since it was Valentine's Day.  Luckily for us, we got there and on Valentines Day (and only this day) it opened at 4:30PM.  No waiting, unless you count the wait for the host to get our free wine! (How can anyone complain about FREE anything!)

The bread was yummy, warm and served quickly.  The selection of fish/seafood was great and the portions were generous!

Upon leaving there was a HUGE wait line...but the fact it was Valentine's Day and there was free wine, people seemed very relaxed!

I will be visiting again soon....
author: Lara F.

description: I took my parents to Pacific Cafe when they were in town visiting. They aren't the easiest to please with food so I was a little nervous. My dad loves seafood and I was sure my mom would be able to find something one the menu.The cafe is just down the street from us - I had no idea it had been in Marin for so long. As soon as we walked in the door, I knew we had come to the right place. The owner instantly greeted us and offered us complimentary house wine while we waited for our table. It was a short wait and were excited to eat. My dad and hubby both had the clam chowder and loved, loved it. I ordered the parmesan halibut - it was delish! I loved it and would def order again. My hubby got the crab cakes. We thought they were ok. Not bad, but nothing extremely special. My mom loved her salad, but didn't seem enthralled with our steak. My dad loved his shrimp. All in all, we enjoyed our dinner. They were very obliging of our one year old daughter and were extremely nice, and the food was really good to boot so we'll definitely be back and recommend you check it out.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
I had such high expectations for this place. I saw it reviewed on PBS and was so excited to go here. I was disappointed to say, even though I have to admit it, I ate a whole lot here.   Came here with a group of friends on a Thursday night and it was packed. About 30 minutes wait. But they did serve us complimentary wine as we waited so the wait wasn't so bad. 
First we all had the clam chowder soup, which was nice. Not creamy or heavy, but a light version, a little spicy(very sensitive to spices) for me, and a bit salty but good overall. My friends ordered salmon with scallops, ahi tuna, crab cakes, and I had their halbut. We all(4 of us total) agreed to try from each other dish. First all, my friend said the scallops were overcooked, and after trying it, I have to agree. It was not soft and tender, but on the harder side. The salmon was not that tasty either, on the bland side for me. The crab cakes were okay, but overcooked on the top, it looked burnt too. My halibut was okay, but I thought it could have more flavor to it, on the bland side for me. The ahi tuna was overcooked and sent back. When the waiter saw it, he agreed and without question took it back. The second one was pretty good. My friend shared a big piece with me and I really enjoyed it. It went great with the wasabi butter! Portions are good size.  We had dessert here as well, Mitchells ice-cream and a chocolate mousse tart. Service was decent, but the waiter didn't ask how our meal was going.  Maybe he knew?  Price is on the upper side.  So some hits and minues with mostly minues. We didn't have a good night here, like we all hoped it would be.
author: Leon C.

description:
My girlfriend lives down the block.  We went here based mostly on Yelp recommendations and were not impressed.  

Yes, free wine while you wait is nice, but not enough.  There were many people ahead of us on the wait list.  When I asked how long the wait would be, I was told that it would be quick.  It wasn't.  

The food was not good.  Almost everything on the menu seemed to be fried or drenched in cream sauce.  I thought I would have a coronary on the way out.  I didn't think it lived up to SF standards.  If you want great seafood in the neighborhood, go a few blocks down Geary to Mayflower.  The seafood is fresh and well prepared there.
author: Brian M.

description: It had been a while since my friend went on a date and he had one scheduled, so he took me on a dry run :) to Pacific cafe and it was the best date ever!!  the food was good and the cheap wine while you wait is entertaining, even for a wine snob.
author: kate l.

description: Do you like free, crappy wine while you wait in the fog for crappy food? Then you are home! There's just no excuse for seafood that isn't fresh in SF. None.
author: A H.

description: Get ready to wait an hour for great fresh fish, delicious red potatoes, and FREE WINE while you stand in line! You couldn't ask for anything better except that they have the most delicious shrimp louie salads. I would come here just to order that, the dressing is drinkable! And the parchment wrapped turbo is creamy delicious and beautifully wrapped like an expensive french pastry. Quite impressive! I reserve this place for fancy friends and special occasions.
author: M K.

description:
Too bad - this could have been a really nice meal. We went on a Monday night, so the famous wait was nonexistent, which was a plus. The place is cozy, nothing fancy, and the servers kept emphasizing the "free" wine. We ordered some appetizers, namely oysters and bay shrimp. Ok people, take it as a warning sign when oysters do not come in the shell! These were small, slimy oysters packed in a serving glass. I didn't try them personally, but only three people at the table (out of six) did and two said they were pretty bad. The bay shrimp coctail was ok, pretty plain, small shrimp. 
Now, on to the entrees...
Everything here is $20-40 per plate, and the fish comes with salad or soup, and a side of vegetables or potatoes or something like that. I decided (regrettably) to have the grilled scallops. There were about 6 of them on my plate alongside some red new potatoes, which were boiled. The potatoes ended up being much more palatable than the scallops, which had a strange, off putting flavor. They were very salty and almost tasted as if they were cooked in rancid butter. Needless to say, I didn't finish them - after a couple of bites I was done. They were also accompanied by even more butter, as if the butter might improve the flavor or something. I think better preparation would have helped, say rinsing the scallops well in fresh water and grilling with just a touch of lemon, salt, and pepper with olive oil instead of butter would have helped immensely. I spoke to other members of our party and all agreed that the food was bad to mediocre at best, and not worth what we paid in the slightest.
The one memorable thing was one of the servers - we asked where we could get a chocolate cake or torte to go and she went out of her way to recommend two places and even call one of them to see if they were open, even though we could have been pushed to purchase desert from them. I appreciated this gesture very much.
author: Mercedes C.

description: The kind of restaurant my grandparents would have loved.  Good fish, prepared in a simple (read sudsy with butter and cheese) manner, friendly service, and free weak white wine while you wait.  Not for the gourmet, but certainly worth a visit if you're in the hood.  Coming after 8:30 on a weeknight is the best way to avoid lines.
author: Gabriel S.

description:
my brother & his gf took me to pacific cafe for dinner & i loved it.  this place is convenient with lots of street parking. pacific cafe has a lively atmosphere, and is very laid back.

pacific cafe is the place to be if u need a seafood fix! i was stuffed from their crab cakes, red potatoes, & salmon bisque soup. (very good!) i had to pack most of it home. :)

the staff is super friendly, they made me feel like a regular customer my first time there.

but most importantly, they give u FREE WINE as long as ur waiting to be seated! :p now ill be looking forward to a wait every time i go! (be sure not to drink too much free wine on an empty stomach, i got plastered!)
author: minac c.

description: Who can beat free wine while waiting?  This place rocks.  Good food and SO not pretentious.  VERY affordable too!  I stumbled upon this place after a walk through Golden Gate park with my fiance.  It actually ended up being a perfect romantic evening even though it didn't even try to be.  Definitely go.
author: Marla L.

description: The wait is certainly worth it.  All the free wine one can drink until called to your table.   The fish is outstanding - love the English sole and the parmessan halibut.  The Louie salad that comes  with the meal is great.  The French bread and butter is a killer (delicious).... The ice cream for dessert is Mitchel' s which is superb.  Also, Zanzi's cheesecake.  Great neighborhood restaurant.
author: Chloe C.

description: Old School fish house. No vegetables on the menu and overly cooked fish. We have too many great options in San Francisco and this is a below average place to eat.
author: MEK O.

description: This place is a little over rated. The food is OK. I'm giving it four stars because the staff is great and I always have a good time here.
author: Opie D.

description: Very limited menu and over priced as well!! I guess the extra charge for "snapper" = "rockcod" is added for the "free" wine which was terrible.....I'd rather pay for a glass of average wine then to pay $19.00 for cajun rockcod. I felt cheated....the food was O.K. but I just diden't feel like I got what I payed for...needless to say I won't be back!!
author: Sara S.

description: I'd say I don't understand the popularity of this place, but I think I do. It appeals to a lot of the 'ol timers from SF of many years ago who are still willing to wait for hours to indulge in mediocre food at an old time location; funky and neighborhood friendly. The food? Well the last time I was there I ordered Sand Dabs and they came out breaded and fried, bones in, which made them very unpleasant to eat, and not very tasty at all. Combine this with some totally plain boiled red potatoes and you have a very dissappointing meal. Argh! The chowder wasn't very good either. I remember eating there many years ago when we lived in the city and it seems like it was better then. Not so friendly either. Maybe they knew we jumped ship!
author: Ron R.

description: Another hidden Gem in SF. You can't beat free wine for waiting and really fresh fish besides fine dining or at the wharf, this place is a long time fav of mine. Be sure to get there early cause this place is small. The menu is on the wall, always good and delightful!
author: Stanley K.

description:
finally made it back here with some friends that live in the area.  haven't been to this place for ages.  was craving fish.  i used to live in the richmond and back then i would go there all the time.  even back when i lived in North Beach, this was one of the few places that we would drive across town just to go to.  there are a lot of good food places in the richmond but this is one of the few that you'd actually travel to go to. 

they serve - as you can probably discern from the name - almost exclusively fish.  come here for the fish and that's about it.  they have about a half dozen grilled fresh fish specials that they put on a blackboard on the front of the restaurant.  presumably a blackboard is their main menu because it changes with whatever is fresh that day.  usually there's a tuna, a snapper, a halibut, etc.... but i like their prepared dishes the best.  the halibut parmesan is unique and totally amazing.  the petrale dore with capers and mushrooms was the thing i had this week and it was full of the tangy lemon caper flavors...  one other tip, even though you may be tempted to keep it healthy by having the salad to start, the soup is incredible! 

you also go there for the historic feel.  the restaurant has that old wood / old world feel.  they have pictures of old San Francisco all over - including my personal favorite: a picture from 1908 of what is approximately Geary and 32nd avenue looking west!  which is about exactly where you'd be standing if you were looking at the picture.  oddly enough, there were some roads and houses in the richmond even back then.  the place opened in 1974 on July 4, so they have entered their 35th year.  

and to add to the homey, historic, catch-of-the-day feel - they don't take reservations.  you need to wait (sometimes up to 45 minutes on the weekend) to get your table.  but don't fret, there's a nice waiting area and benches outside and they hand out free wine for those that are waiting.  when you sit down, you'll notice that almost all the wines on the menu are white and they are all very, very cheap.  everyday white table wine is the rule to go with your catch-of-the-day.  and when you're done, you can always head down the road to Trader Sam's for a boat drink in a foo-foo glass with an umbrella and put some Jimmy Buffet on the juke box.  :)
author: dan h.

description:
the wait was long even for a sunday night (sure tomorrow is a holiday but not everyone gets it off).  we waited for about an hour.  they served wine to people waiting so that was a nice thing (i dont drink so i didnt care).  the restaurant is pretty small and it seems to be pretty popular so i guess be prepared to wait.  

we had the calamari vinegarette for starters and the spicy snapper and parmesan halibut.  i liked the snapper better than the halibut.  the parmesan was a little overpowering.  the spicy snapper was really tasty.  my fiance said it got to be too spicy but i didn't notice.

i dont know if i would wait for an hour again but i would come back
author: Patrick L.

description: I used to live on 40th and Geary, which luckily was easy walking distance.   I visit this place every time I come back to SF.  When riding the 38 home, if there wasn't a line, I immediately got off the bus on 36th.  Loved this place.  Yes, the seafood is simple -- but it's perfectly prepared and very very consistant.  Nothing fancy, and as reviews in the papers have said for years, the waitresses are "salty"; hey that's the charm.  If I want fancy and overpriced and STILL get attitude I'll eat downtown.  Thats ok -- when I have my Halibut Parmesan with broccoli after seven glasses of Franzia I'm doing juuuuust fine.
author: David A.

description: Enh...not that good. You ALWAYS have to wait, although they do give you wine to enjoy. The fish is good and fresh, but not really cooked to perfection. The sides are not wonderful. I've had better.
author: Anita K.

description: Not cheap, but well worth it. With seafood, you get what you pay for. The food here is excellent as is the service. The turbot in parchment, the crab cakes, crab diablo, it's all good.
author: Erik W.

description: This is one of things I miss most about living in the Richmond. The seafood is fantastic. The service is top knotch. They even meet you at the door with a glass of wine. They have regular specials that I encourage you to try. My only complaint is the place is cramped. One time we had the stroller with us....HUGE mistake! There is barely enough room to sit much less park the stroller. No suprise that parking is a nightmare too. Good luck finding spot within several blocks the entrance.
author: Jamie K.

description: Yes, this seafood place is great. The location is mundane and the wait is long but after you can have a drink at one of the places with an ocean view just a short drive away.
author: Robert F.

description:
so i was surprised with dinner here for my birthday last week.... i've heard so many great things, but had never been here... 
let me first say, people that had to wait and got free wine, he and i waited for 20 seconds? and were asked if we wanted complimentary wine. WOW. i thought it was only for ppl that were and had to wait an extremely long time... we got there at 5:30, i kept whining and complaining that we were going so early for dinner, but upon arrival, i was told no reservations, so good thing... it got crowded FAST.

i had the ahi tuna with wasabi butter... i wanted a little more of a wasabi kick to it, but nonetheless my dinner was AMAZING. he had the parmesean halibut which was equally delicious.. we had the mango sorbet, YUM. tasted like real mangoes.

the service was amazing, so attentive.. the food came out quick.. the restaurant is really nice and cozy... i wonder what it'd look like without the xmas tree and lights...... 

can't wait to go back!!!!!!!!!!
author: Esther A.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants.  I love to wait in line and get drunk off of their white wine and then pig out on some delicious seafood.  I like the ambience inside and the booths.
author: Toni C.

description: You might want to call the free wine while you wait a gimmick, but it's hard to argue with such a great and welcoming idea.  Our fish was fresh and tasty, and overall the experience was about perfect.  A good choice for traditional seafood.
author: Pug P.

description:
I moved into the neighborhood a few months ago and have been dying to try Pacific Cafe.  We went on Saturday with friends around 7:45p.  It's an easy 2 block walk from our house.  We were lucky to get a seat in the waiting area (us girls anyway) and chatted away while sipping on the free white wine while we waited for our table.  Can't say exactly how long we waited as we were having a great time anyway, but I'd estimate it to be around 30+ minutes.  It would be nice if they took reservations but I wasn't bothered by our wait especially since it was primetime Saturday night.

I had the ceaser salad and Petrole Dole with capers and mushrooms with red potatoes.  Both super yummy!  My friends also enjoyed their food.  We all shared the cheesecake and a chocolate mouse cake for dessert.  Both lovely. Oh, and us girls had turned down a refiling of wine while were waiting but the lovely man secretly filled them back up after we got to our table.  Usually you start paying for your wine once you are seated.  But we each had 2 glasses of wine and didn't pay a dime.

In the end our bill came to around $120 for the 4 of us, not including tip.  For San Francisco and the yumminess of the food, I thought that was pretty good.  This will definitely be a regular place for my husband and I since we live so close.  Taking advantage of the free wine while waiting and not splurging on dessert, the two of us could easily have a great meal for $50.  Can't wait to come back!
author: Shauna C.

description: This place has the best clam chowder west of BOSTON. Put it this way, my friends and my dumbass went from Los Angeles to San Fran to eat this place's clam chowder, horse around a bit, visit buddies and came back down on the same 24 hr day~! enough said? waiting is a bitch cuz u can't shove more than 4 fat people in there, but ya kno wut, it's worth the wait. The owners are great and the food is simple, tastey, and worth the wait. Their Merlot selection is not that great, but it's ok, ya don't go there to drink wine. If you don't like fishy then not the best place. The rest. is pricey but i highly doubt price is a deterrant for 95% of ya'll out there.
author: John L.

description:
Pacific Cafe is GREAT!  I heard about this place from a friend who lives in the area.  She said, "this may not be the place for you becuase I know you hate long waits, but it's worth it.  Oh, and they give you a wine, while you wait."  Sold!  

We thought, lets try it on a Friday night!  The wait was very long, the lobby was bursting with people trying to get in.  All had a glass of wine in their hands.  We were greeted right away with our glass of wine.  We spent the next hour and a half talking to people and getting the scoop.  Most people in that lobby have been coming since the day the doors have opened.  Everyone seemed to know everyone!  There were a few newbies like us, but we felt instantly welcome.  

An hour an a half our table was ready.  Bummer.  We were really enjoying the conversation!  My meal was fantastic and either the manager or owner stopped by our table just to thank us for coming.  

Now this is an amazing place, I will surely return!
author: Heather C.

description:
I kept seeing this place from the bus, all rosey and cheerful and crowded, and always wanted to go. I finally got my chance and it totally lived up to expectations. The wait is long, but worth it - plus they serve some pretty darn good complimentary wine while you wait. The regular menu looks excellent, though I tried something from the daily specials board. The choice is hard though. I had baked crab-stuffed salmon Newberg, which was heavenly. For desert, apple tart with a marzipan-y overtone and scrumptious ice cream. The service was great and the ambiance is everything it looks to be from the bus. It's pricey (entrees in the upper teens to 20s, unless you order the abalone at $40), but for a nice, upscale seafood meal, worth it. Glad it's in my neighborhood.
-----------------------------------------------
Took my mom to the Pacific Cafe for dinner while she was visiting from LA. Still a five star rating! Another lovely meal (fried scallops, red potatoes, shrimp louie salad and chocolate torte). And actually, the wait was not that bad on a Friday night at 6:00, surprisingly.
author: Caitlin H.

description: Pacific Cafe is the kind of restaurant you might want to go to for your wedding anniversary or your birthday. We go there as a family for almost all special occasions and have been doing so for almost 14 years. The food is very good, but not adventuresome, so you may not get a flavor you've never tasted but you can guarantee that you won't get something that was a creative mistake by the chef. The restaurant serves free wine while you wait, or non alcoholic beverages to non-drinkers if you ask (my daughter always gets apple juice). The service is excellent and the same pleasant people are still there year after year with a vested interest in the coziness of the restaurant. Great deserts too!
author: Myriam K.

description: The food is good but beware there is a marked price difference between the specials and the food on the regular menu. The reason - the specials are fresh and the food on the menu is made from frozen seafood.
author: Kelly S.

description: After a long romantic day at the beach my man and I stopped here for dinner. When we arrived this place was very small and packed. There is no hoestess just a clip bored hanging from a nail so one can sign in for a table. There was about a 45 minute wait and the crowd over flowed to the outside. They waiters provided everyone complimentary glasses of chardonnay or merlot as you waited which made the crowded waiting area much more relaxing as the kept the bottles flowing. We started our meal off with the crab cocktail and a crab bisque that was delicious. We ordered the Crab a la Diabla that was a special on the menu. The crab came cracked and was marinated in a garlc butter with shallots and a bit of paprika. The seafood tasted fresh and was very delicious. The food was so good  that I almost forgot about the flaws that this place has like its shoebox size restroom. My meal was satisffying and I love there homestyle ambiance. I can't wait to come back for the food is worth the wait.
author: Carolina H.

description:
Free wine while you wait - and sometimes it can be a looooong wait, so take this review for what its worth, if you get my drift. 
I used to eat at Pacific Cafe quite often, since I lived right around the corner. I was never disappointed. It's not a fancy place at all, just a reliable neighborhood joint that's been around for a good long time. 
Here are the reasons I think it's been so successful over time (one and two-star restaurants take note):
Perfectly cooked seafood served the old fashioned way. No fusion-y mango-wasabe salsa, no bed of blah, blah, blah tureen, just yummy sauces consisting mostly of butter and garlic (how can you go wrong, I ask?!)
Friendly service that keeps an eye on the flow of your table. No rushing you to order if you're catching up with old friends. Making sure everyone's food arrives at the same time, and piping hot. 
A short but  sweet wine list with fair prices and generous pours. 
Well, after a long absence, I went back to my old friend and again enjoyed a delicious meal in a relaxing atmosphere.  I sure miss living down the street from this place (although my pocketbook is probably not so sad - it ain't the cheapest joint in town, but for what you get, the prices are more than fair.)
author: Delilah P.

description: The corner of 34th and Geary turns into quite the happening place once they start doling out the free wine here at Pacific Cafe. Although I have had some problems with snootishness once when they wouldn't serve me since I'm in my early twenties and most patrons here are middle-aged, if you're looking for great fish then this is the place for you. Beware, however, of the scanty pickings of activities in the neighborhood afterwards. There are some destinations, granted, but this is no downtown.
author: Patrick G.

description: Best seafood restaurant in San Francisco, period. So fresh and with a good selection of dishes to choose from. Appears to be family and friend owned and managed, has that charming vibe anyway. The wait is long but well-worth the amazing seafood. Plus, you get free wine as soon as you step foot in the door, who can complain about that? haha
author: Christy M.

description: Of course free wine is a good start, but the food was quite average and we left somewhat disappointed from this homey little joint.
author: Mei B.

description: I came here during crab season once and all I remember was how busy it was and how lucky we were to eat here during crab season.  Their crab bisque was the best I've ever had and it's made me a bisque lover ever since.  I think I have to come here again so I can remember what the other seafood tasted like.
author: Kit E.

description: It was ok.  Perhaps it is a better place once you pass the age of 65?  It seems very popular.  The food is ok, but it is very simple.  I cannot imagine how this place gets its crowds, but it certainly does.
author: Richard P.

description: Free wine while you wait.  Lobster is outstanding - if there is any left.  Great place for a first date.
author: A H.

description: What a nice surprise.  Haven't had such a delightful dining experience in a long time.  Free booze while you wait.  Woo hoo!  The thousand island dressing on the shrimp louie is divine.  Fish is flavorful and fresh.  The best is the Zanze cheesecake offering for dessert.  Now, we can come here to have just one slice without buying (and eating) the whole cake.
author: K W.

description: The best part is the free white wine while you're waiting in line.  The food is decent, too.  However, I've come on occasions when I've had to wait in line and when I haven't, and I must say that the times I've had to wait in line were much better.  Fancy that.  =)
author: Kelvin K.

description: Well worth the wait. Some friends were in town. The wanted to go to Pacific Cafe. So we drove across town on a busy Friday evening. There is always a wait. We waited about an half hour. While we were waiting outside with everyone else, here comes an employee with glasses of wine for everyone. They cam out later with more wine for the empty glasses out there. When we got seated we were taken well care of by our waitress. I had the Swordfish, one of my friends had the Halibut and the other had another fish dish (I can't remember the name of it) but it had a mushroom saute on top. All I can say is that we were very happy with all of our dishes. We were stuffed. The soup that night was Crab Bisque (excellent) the salad was shrimp Louie. A very enjoyable evening to say the least.
author: Timothy M.

description: The first time I went here, I thought it was the bomb.  Rich ass seafood and free wine while you wait for your table.  Last time I went, I forget what I ordered, but I remember I was disappointed.  The free wine rules though.  I know I aint sayin nothin new about the free-while-you-wait wine, but I thought you should know that the food is not as great as everybody's saying.  Aw, what the hell do I know.
author: Skeptical Spee ..

description: The food was incredible. Not too pricey and even though there was a long wait, you get free wine as you sit. Had a fantastic time and the restaurant ambiance was cute - great to have a fun meal with family or friends (a little more casual, but still nicer than most places).
author: linda t.

description: The _ONLY_ place in the city I pray to see a long line. Yes, the legend of the restaurant with free wine...passed from generation to generation- is  true.... the wine is super tasty, and maybe the rolling buzz you have by the time you sit down skews the review a bit, but hands down, this is my favorite "old-skool, no asian fusion, no gratuitious chipotle additions, extra-taste-ie, free-booze" seafood restaurant in the city. The bisques are always awesome, the ever changing special board is always tasty and dammit, they serve free wine while you wait. What more could you ask for people (hic) ;)
author: Tim V.

description: It's hard for me to be nice.  But, I have to painfully admit that I enjoyed my dinner here.  The staff was attentive, friendly, fast and efficient.  The food was great, fresh tasty fish and some nice wine.  And the feral cats outside tugged at my heart string.  It was my last one, and it broke.
author: Penny O.

description: This is the quintessential old school San Francisco joint. You will most likey only find locals here.  There is always a wait but they give you free wine while you're waiting-INCENTIVE.  The decor is a bit dated, but they serve up some FRESH fish simply prepared.  I had the crabcakes and they were yummy!  I will be back again soon.
author: anne m.

description:
For this review I got some advice from my dear friend Andy, visiting from New York.  He said, at the maximum, Lauren you can only give them 3 stars.  Well, here is why:  (And I agree although there is a part of me that wants to be more generous because the ambiance was cozy and nice) They said the wait would be 20 minutes.  Grrrrr, we both (him and I) hate when restaurants claim a wait of 20 minutes but end up being around an hour.  All restaurants say 20 minutes.  It is often the ubiquitous name for "just take a seat and we'll try to get people out of here as quickly as possible".  well, my friend is from new york and new yorkers know when it is appropriate to kindly remind the host that he is a big fat liar.  This is true.  Tell us like it is, my friend, tell us if we will be sipping wine for an hour.  It might be ok.  But we don't want to be handed lies.  ..."we can handle the truth".  The wine was fun, though, and something we thought was a nice touch.  The service was very attentive.  The host, I thought, very kind and I might add cute.  The crab bisque soup delicious and matched with some nice sourdough: divine.  Our main dishes, though, were specials but weren't that special at all....bummer man!

oh, but my friend andy and I came up with a free way to get some wine.  Go there, drink the complimentary wine, say you have an appointmen and you have to leavet and there you go: free wine.

Wow, I sound like a cheapo and a wino.  I wish it were better.  I live so close.
author: Lauren S.

description: This might be my new favorite restaurant.  My friend and I waited for almost an hour, but it flew by because the lovely host was pouring us wine and telling us about how good the food was.  He called us by name (this was our first time there) and made the wait...fun!  We ordered the parmesan halibut (AMAZING) and the salmon/scallops sampler (AMAZING) and got the clam chowder (AMAZING) and the oyster bisque (AMAZING-I think this is the best soup I've ever had) to start.  The bread was thick and sour, the fish was cooked perfectly and we couldn't stop raving about everything we ate.  On top of the great food, we were amongst the last to be sat on a Saturday night, and the waiter was energetic and fun without rushing us at all.  And he made great recommendations!  We're STILL talking about how great our whole experience was and I can't wait to go back!
author: Katie D.

description: Best Seafood ! The crab cakes are sooooo delicious! I love the Spicy Snapper... not to mention they give you free wine while you wait.
author: Noah T.

description:
Hi, 
My husband and I ate here with friends on 5/16/09 and it was fabulous. I had been here on a date many years ago, and always remembered the Pacific Cafe as 'the restaurants that serves you wine for FREE, while you wait in line for a table'.. It was still true!!  Roy, the waiter, came out,gave us 4 wine glasses, filled them TO THE TOP, as we sat outside and talked. He then reappeared, 20 minutes later and refilled all our glasses.. We had to wait about an hour [as this place is very popular]...but who cares?? we kept getting our glasses filled [again to the top!]...I think we had about 4 glasses of wine by the time they called us for our table. 
The Petrale Dore was amazing...served in a incredible sauce with capers and mushrooms. Their 'dinner salad' consisted of a shimp salad- fully loaded with shrimp, and you can get red potatoes or rice with your dinner. This came with all the wonderful S.F. french bread you could eat, plus the free wine... what is NOT to like?  
Only minus is do not order their cheese cake...it isn't cheese cake,but some fluffy imitation trying to taste like cheese cake..[The Lemon square was 1/2 way decent]. In spite of dessert, it was an incredible dinner, a fun place with separate booths and we will definitely be back-.  'jellybeano'
author: jellybeano b.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in SF.   When we're up in the city to visit our girls, we have to consciously resist going to the Pacific Cafe every single time.  We've committed to try new restaurants since there are so many here, but I would be content to dine here every time we're in town.

This is a cute, homey place.  The chefs, servers, and hosts are extremely customer service-oriented, cheerful, helpful and seem to genuinely love it that you have come to their establishment.  

It is genius to serve wine to patrons as they wait (sometimes 1-1/2 hours - yes.. we have waited that long) for a table.  It's part of the dining experience at Pacific Cafe and even though it is not great wine (Chablis maybe from a box or jug), it takes the edge off and helps you relax and unwind as you chat with the folks around you.  

They serve the best sourdough bread I've had.  Everything we've ordered has been fantastic.  The clam chowder, parmesean-crusted halibut (everyone MUST try this.  It is incredible), prawns, sole, salmon, oysters, scallops, sand dabs, and crab have all been fresh, perfectly prepard and swiftly served.  We like to order whatever specials they offer for variety.  

Cannot say enough good things about this place and have nothing negative.
author: Casey N.

description: Two words that shouldn't go together:  Cafeteria Seafood.  And yet, that is what I feel I just ate.  I always hear people mention this place as a good seafood place and, in a city with a well-deserved reputation for a variety of good food--whether in a fancy setting or in a bar--I can't for the life of me figure out why this place gets mentioned.  The free wine while waiting and the friendly, professional staff certainly make you root for the place.  Granted, this is only my second time, but both times, about 2/3rds of the way into the meal, I was overwhelmed by a serous taste in my mouth that only comes from what seaman and non-seaman alike would call an excess of thousand island dressing.  In fact, the shrimp louie, the calamari salad, even the featured scallops, all suffered an ignoble death by cheap cream sauce, and put together, with the help from a couple glasses of the house white while waiting, caused a gurgling in my belly that left me hovering over the toilet in the men's room, contemplating existence.  I did enjoy the portraits of the Cliff House as I wiped the spittle from my mouth, but it was not enough to overcome the viscosity of the experience.  Now, I am far from a foodie, and routinely am left quite satisfied by the hospital cafeteria where I work, but this place left me feeling quite poopy.  Fool me once, shame on Hugh.  Fool me twice, shame on my knee, at least I think that's the way it goes.  Me no go here no more.
author: David Y.

description: What other place serves wine while you're waiting in line?  None, unless you count someone offering you Nighttrain or Thunderbird while you're walking in the Tenderloin.  This place is great, and the salmon is excellent and the lighting just right.  Not always the easiest place to find parking, but certainly not the hardest.  Pacific Cafe is a solid reliable place.  Even if there is a wait, you can still get a good buzz going before going in and having your meal.
author: Christopher G.

description:
First, pray that you find a parking place somewhere in the neighborhood.  Better yet, take the Muni.
Now, this is where people who grew up in San Francisco before and during the 1960s take their sweethearts for a dinner date.  
OK, sometimes we bring our parents.
OK, very rarely, we bring out-of-town guests.
But frankly, 90% of the customers are locals who have been returning here since it opened ( I think that was in 1974 or so).  
This restaurant started the idea of dispensing free glasses of wine while you are waiting for your table, and that tradition continues today.  Once seated, you will order soup or salad to precede your fresh fish.  
 When you leave, contemplate the entire dining experience that you just had, and you may begin to understand why the City is a "real restaurant town."  
Now go home, and don't tell anyone else, unless you move to California and bring your sweetheart.  
OK, you can bring your parents.
But that's it.
author: Alfredo C.

description: I love the 70's feel to this place,right off the pages of "Tales of the City". I've had questionable service here...and a hell of a wait,and I'd recommended it to only certain people. Like folks that love seafood,non trendy people,and people who enjoy cheap white wine. Basically,my mom would love to just bring a blanket and just live here, drinking all the free wine and enjoying all the old school ambiance. However,I can't imagine if you lived downtown coming all the way out to the Avenues for it. And we don't want YOUR kind out here anyhow.  Wow,this seems like a negative review...just trying to weed some of those Marina types out. I really like this place.This is a quaint,reliable seafood joint and I wouldn't change a thing except put lobster back on the menu,dammit!  And for god sakes,don't bring your kids here,it's not Chevy's!!!
author: Nan H.

description:
Well you see kids -- back in the day -- before Pinot grigio or even Chardonnay, if you wanted white you drank Chablis.  And at Pacific Cafe you still drink Chablis and even when it's free it still taste, unfortunately, like Chablis.  There was a time (the '70's) when using a chalk board to list your fresh specials was quirky and innovative.    
 Oh yes, it was sometime after high school, in '78, when my parents investment in a 16 unit building on Haight Street ("gee Bernie, do you think the neighborhood will ever be worth anything?" my mother asked) started to pan out.  They were going out to dinner every week!!!  Sometimes they invited their poor daughter, the waitress, along.  I can still see mom in her black velvet blazer and white "bow-tie" blouse (Mayor Feinstein was a fashion icon for middle aged women) and dad in his Harris tweed, shirt open at the neck, NEVER a tie, sitting in a wood booth at Pacific Cafe.  They were on the cusp of making it; retirement was visible on their horizon.  No early bird specials for Bernie and Harriet, just plenty of fresh fish at Pacific Caf.  In 2001 dad went to the big multi unit in the sky.  This is where tenants never flush Kotex, dimes never stall garbage disposals and god did what the Supreme Court wouldn't do -- outlawed rent control.  Mom (still here, going on 90) lived long enough to see warnings about both eating fish (toxins), and the probable extinction of many species, become reality.       
 Would the current reality of Pacific Caf live up to my memories?  I went with mom and some relatives last year.  In '78, most salads were iceberg with dressing ladled on top -- a salad tossed in vinaigrette (as I remembered their salads to be) was a gourmet treat.   The current shrimp Louie salad was OK but a bit retro.  My daughter had the chowder and she loved it.  At 15 she is the product of posh private schools (her school cafeteria is "locally grown organic") and, at times, pickier than her mother.  The others had the bisque and they were impressed.
